questions.text: Small or medium sized, sterile vegetations found in either or both sides heart valve commonly associated with SLE patients is characteristic of which of the following disease? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Libmann Sachs endocarditis

 

  • SLE is seen with Libman Sach endocarditis. on both sides of valves.
  • Infective endocarditis causes friable bulky vegetations, which can cause further complications.
  • RHD has small sterile vegetations.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE): Also known as marantic endocarditis, involves the deposition of sterile thrombi on heart valves, typically in patients with hypercoagulable states or malignancies.

 

Option B. Rheumatic heart disease (RHD): Characterized by small, sterile vegetations called Aschoff bodies, which result from an autoimmune response following a streptococcal infection.

 

Option C. Infective endocarditis (IE): Characterized by friable, bulky vegetations on heart valves caused by bacterial or fungal infections, which can lead to further complications such as embolization and valve destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Libmann Sachs endocarditis is associated with SLE and characterized by sterile vegetations on either or both sides of heart valves.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the clinic due to complaints of increased sensitivity to light (photophobia) and excessive tearing. Upon clinical examination, the tear passages appear normal, and the cornea is clear but larger than usual. The image of the eye reveals the presence of Haab's striae. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buphthalmos

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) seen in congenital glaucoma

 

An increase in the size of the eyeball can cause axial myopia and an increase in corneal diameter can cause thinning of the cornea and horizontal/circumferential breaks in the Descemet's membrane, called Haab's striae, which is a classical finding in patients with buphthalmos.

 

 

Other conditions causing buphthalmos:

 

  • Aniridia: Characterized by complete or partial iris hypoplasia. Inheritance is autosomal dominant. Dysplasia of angle structures and Angle-closure is thought to be the cause of the glaucoma
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1: Characterized by multiple neurofibromas, cafe au lait spots, iris Lisch nodules, and axillary/inguinal freckling. Inheritance is autosomal dominant. Glaucoma is thought to be due to developmental anomalies of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Sturge-Weber syndrome: Characterized by nevus flammeus of the face and meningeal angiomas. Glaucoma and associated angle anomalies are seen in 60% of cases. Angle developmental anomalies and raised episcleral venous pressure are the proposed causes of glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratoconus:

 

  • Description: Progressive thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea.
  • Symptoms: Vision distortion, glare, and sensitivity to light.
  • Diagnosis: Characterized by a cone-shaped cornea and usually does not present in neonates.

 

Option C. Trachoma:

 

  • Description: Chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Symptoms: Conjunctival scarring, eyelid deformities, and corneal opacity.
  • Diagnosis: Presents with follicular conjunctivitis and scarring, not typically seen with clear corneas in neonates.

 

Option D. Keratoglobus:

 

  • Description: Globular protrusion of the cornea.
  • Symptoms: Thinning and protrusion of the entire cornea, typically leading to vision problems.
  • Diagnosis: Enlarged, clear cornea without Haab's striae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Buphthalmos is characterized by photophobia, excessive tearing, an enlarged cornea, and the presence of Haab's striae, which are indicative of congenital glaucoma. Early diagnosis and management are essential to prevent vision loss and other complications associated with increased intraocular pressure.

choices.text: Familial adenomatous polyposis

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy had abdominal discomfort on the left side and he went to his physician. His father had a similar condition during his teenage years and later developed some GI malignancy. He then underwent a colonoscopy which is shown alongside. What do you infer about his condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Familial adenomatous polyposis

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of colonic polyps that inevitably become malignant if not treated. It is caused by mutations in the APC gene located on chromosome 5q21.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cancer colon: While FAP leads to an increased risk of colorectal cancer, the condition described is specifically FAP due to the presence of numerous polyps.

 

Option C. Ulcerative colitis: A chronic inflammatory condition of the colon and rectum, not characterized by the presence of numerous polyps.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), it is characterized by fewer polyps and a high risk of colorectal cancer and other cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by the presence of hundreds to thousands of colonic polyps and a high risk of colorectal cancer, caused by mutations in the APC gene.

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • The label marked 2 represents the LH surge, which is responsible for ovulation.
  • Menstrual cycle phases:
    • Follicular phase (days 1-14): Theca and granulosa cells have increased levels of LH and FSH receptors. The uterus grows more frequently when estradiol levels rise. Estradiol's negative feedback impact on the anterior pituitary reduces the levels of FSH and LH. Low amounts of progesterone are present.
    • Ovulation (day 14): Regardless of cycle length, ovulation occurs 14 days before menses. The release of FSH and LH is positively influenced by a spike in estradiol production at the conclusion of the follicular period (LH surge). The spike in LH brought on by estrogen triggers ovulation. The volume of cervical mucus rises, and it becomes less viscous and more sperm penetrable.
    • Luteal phase (days 15-28): There is a high amount of progesterone. The corpus luteum begins to produce progesterone. To receive a fertilized egg, the endometrium's vascularity and secretory activity increase. If fertilization is unsuccessful, the corpus luteum regresses at the conclusion of the luteal phase. Estradiol and progesterone levels consequently drop sharply.
    • Menses (days 0-4): When estradiol and progesterone are abruptly stopped, the endometrium sloughs off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the increase in FSH at the beginning of the follicular phase.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the peak of estrogen which leads to the LH surge but is not directly responsible for ovulation.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the peak of progesterone during the luteal phase, which occurs after ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The LH surge is responsible for triggering ovulation in the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 68

choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy with ORS
Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of 18 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomiting twice in the last 4 hours. The child is irritable but drinking fluids. The optimal therapy for this child is: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral rehydration therapy with ORS

 

As the child is dehydrated, but he is very thirsty. Oral rehydration solution is used in the initial management of the child.

 

If there is some dehydration, we administer 75 ml/kg over a 4-hour period. If the child can consume it orally, we administer it in the form of ORS; if the child is unable to drink orally parental IVF is used in such cases.

 

The following steps can be taken to treat severe diarrhea in children:

 

  1. Keep properly hydrated.
  2. Provide zinc for 10 to 14 days.
  3. Keep a healthy diet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids: IV fluids are typically reserved for severe dehydration or when the child is unable to drink. This child is drinking, so ORS is preferred.

 

Option C. Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids: This approach may be used in severe cases or when ORT is not initially successful. Since the child can drink, ORT is sufficient.

 

Option D. Plain water ad libitum: Plain water does not replace lost electrolytes and is not recommended for rehydration in diarrhea. ORS is preferred because it contains the necessary electrolytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral rehydration therapy with ORS is the optimal treatment for a child with some dehydration who is able to drink, providing necessary fluids and electrolytes to manage dehydration effectively.

choices.text: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)
Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)
Central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAD)
Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO)

questions.text: Splashed tomato appearance is seen in which of the following condition?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

Splashed tomato appearance is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

 

 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden non-progressive painless loss of vision.

On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present. Fundoscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive intraretinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The optic disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

 

Complications:

 

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100-day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

 

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of  CRVO

Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications:

 

  • Treatment for macular edema: intravitreal injection of steroids – triamcinolone acetonide, dexamethasone implant (ozurdex), and intravitreal injection of anti-vegf – ranibizumab (innovator molecule and biosimilars), aflibercept (also known as vegf-trap). Bevacizumab is also used off label.
  • Treatment for non-perfusion areas and ischemic retina: scatter laser photocoagulation.
  • Treatment for vitreous haemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment: vitrectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Branched Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO):

 

  • Description: Occlusion of one of the branches of the central retinal vein.
  • Fundoscopy: Hemorrhages and cotton wool spots are localized to the area drained by the affected branch, not the "splashed tomato appearance."

 

Option C. Central Retinal Arterial Occlusion (CRAO):

 

  • Description: Occlusion of the central retinal artery.
  • Fundoscopy: Pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the fovea, not associated with the "splashed tomato appearance."

 

Option D. Branched Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO):

 

  • Description: Occlusion of one of the branches of the central retinal artery.
  • Fundoscopy: Segmental retinal whitening along the distribution of the occluded artery, not associated with the "splashed tomato appearance."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by a "splashed tomato appearance" on fundoscopy due to massive intraretinal hemorrhages, along with engorged retinal veins, cotton wool spots, and an edematous, hyperemic optic disc. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage the underlying cause and complications.

choices.text: First hand to hand transfer appears, then palmar reflex disappears
First Palmar reflex disappears, then hand to hand transfer appears
Both Palmar reflex and hand to hand transfer appears at the same time
Both disappear at the same time

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) First Palmar reflex disappears, then hand to hand transfer appears

 

  • The palmar grip reflex is a primitive reflex observed in newborns, beginning at around 28 weeks of gestation and typically disappearing by 3 months after birth.
  • Voluntary grasping starts to develop at about 3 months of age when an object is placed in the infant's hand.
  • Bidextrous grasps, involving both hands, begin to mature around 5 months of age.
  • Unidextrous or palmar grasp starts to develop around 6 months of age.
  • Infants can transfer objects from one hand to the other, known as hand-to-hand transfer, at approximately 7 months of age.
  • Grasping and hand-eye coordination continue to develop throughout childhood and into early adulthood.
  • Fine motor skills, such as the ability to manipulate small objects with precision, develop gradually over time and are influenced by a range of factors including genetics, environment, and practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First hand to hand transfer appears, then palmar reflex disappears: This is incorrect because the palmar reflex disappears before the ability to transfer objects hand-to-hand develops.

 

Option C. Both Palmar reflex and hand to hand transfer appear at the same time: This is incorrect because the palmar reflex appears much earlier and disappears before hand-to-hand transfer ability develops.

 

Option D. Both disappear at the same time: This is incorrect because the palmar reflex disappears within the first few months, while the hand-to-hand transfer appears later, around 7 months of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palmar reflex disappears before the ability to transfer objects from one hand to the other appears in an infant's developmental timeline.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female, known case of xerophthalmia, presents with the following ocular manifestation. What is the likely clinical finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bitot's spot

 

The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia

Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot's spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that leads to corneal scaring and ultimately, blindness.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

Histologically, Bitot’s spots show kerati­nization, irregular maturation, inflam­matory infiltration, and accumulation of gram-positive bacilli.

It is a specific manifestation of Vit A deficiency

 

Causes. The major underlying causes of VAD may be summarized as follows:

 

 

Evaluation

 

History - social or medical history potentially associated with reduced intake or impaired absorption of vitamin A. Relevant factors include age, diet, weight loss, alcohol intake, gastrointestinal disorders or surgery, and night blind­ness or other ocular conditions.

 

General exam - This should include assessment of the patient’s build and weight, signs of jaundice, and abdomi­nal palpation to rule out hepatomegaly.

 

Ocular examination - The clinician should look for possible subconjunctival fibrosis and symblepharon. The status of the ocular surface may be evaluated by means of Schirmer test, rose bengal, or lissamine green staining, and conjunctival impression cytology.

 

Blood tests - Serum RBP has high specificity and sensitivity, The reference range is 30 to 75 mg/L.

Serum vitamin A/retinol. The refer­ence range is 30 to 80 μg/dL.

Serum zinc. The reference range is 75 to 120 μg/dL.

 

Treatment

High-dose vitamin A in children.

In adults, Bitot’s spots do not need to be treated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pterygium:

 

  • Description: A benign growth of the conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea.
  • Appearance: Fleshy, triangular tissue.
  • Associated Factors: UV light exposure, dry, windy conditions.

 

Option C. Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis:

 

  • Description: A hypersensitivity reaction of the conjunctiva and cornea.
  • Appearance: Small, white, nodular lesions surrounded by dilated blood vessels.

 

Option D. Membranous Conjunctivitis:

 

  • Description: Inflammation of the conjunctiva with a membrane formation.
  • Causes: Bacterial infections (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae), viral infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot's spots are a specific manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency and present as triangular, silvery-white, foamy patches on the bulbar conjunctiva. This condition is associated with xerophthalmia, which includes conjunctival dryness, corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia. The treatment focuses on addressing the underlying Vitamin A deficiency.

choices.text: Distal obstruction in the small intestine
Proximal obstruction in the large intestine

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite and abdominal pain. She has a history of Crohn’s disease, for which she is on infliximab, but she reports that this did not feel like an acute exacerbation of her disease. On physical examination, abdomen is tender. An abdominal radiograph is done as below. She is started on intravenous fluids, given anti-emetics, and put on bowel rest. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal obstruction in the small intestine

 

The above image shows dilated bowel loops with Valvulae conniventes. Valvulae conniventes are usually seen in jejunum. This means the obstruction is in the part distal to the jejunum which is the ileum. In small intestinal obstruction, bowel loops are placed centrally (in large bowel obstruction bowel lops are placed peripherally and we can see haustrations). Further, step ladder pattern is suggestive of mechanical block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proximal obstruction in the large intestine: When the large intestine is obstructed, an abdominal radiograph might show haustra, which are the semilunar folds present in the colon. Unlike the valvulae conniventes of the small intestine, these folds do not cross the entire width of the bowel. Haustral markings are spaced farther apart than the closely packed valvulae conniventes.

 

Option C. Pseudo obstruction: Also known as Ogilvie's syndrome, pseudo obstruction represents a clinical syndrome characterized by a large bowel obstruction without any mechanical etiology. It often presents with symptoms of colonic obstruction like abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. On imaging, there's typically massive dilation of the cecum and right colon.

 

Option D. Paralytic ileus: This typically follows a laparotomy and is characterized by vomiting and distension, but no tenderness. X ray abdomen shows dilated small and large bowel, without any step ladder pattern of air fluid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel vs large bowel obstruction

 

 

Rule of 3-6-9:

 

The bowel is said to be dilated if the respective diameter is more than -

 

Small Intestine: 3 cm

 

Large Intestine: 6 cm

 

Caecum: 9 cm

questions.text: Killian's dehiscence is seen between: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cricopharyngeus and Thyropharyngeus

 

Killian's dehiscence is seen between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus muscles.

 

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fires and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called as the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus and Cricopharyngeus: These are muscles involved in the function of the pharynx, but Killian's dehiscence is not located between them.

 

Option B. Thyropharyngeus and Palatopharyngeus: These muscles are part of the pharyngeal constrictor muscles, but Killian's dehiscence is not located between them.

 

Option D. Palatopharyngeus and Salpingopharyngeus: These muscles are also part of the pharyngeal constrictor muscles, but Killian's dehiscence is not located between them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Killian's dehiscence, refers to a potential weak area or gap in the pharyngeal musculature. It is located between the cricopharyngeus muscle (also called the upper esophageal sphincter) and the thyropharyngeus muscle (part of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx).

 

Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch-like herniation of the mucosal lining of the pharynx through Killian's dehiscence. It occurs in the posterior wall of the hypopharynx, just above the upper esophageal sphincter (cricopharyngeus muscle).

 

The cricopharyngeus muscle, located above Killian's dehiscence, plays a role in preventing air from entering the esophagus during breathing and preventing reflux of gastric contents into the pharynx.

choices.text: VIA – Visual inspection with 5% acetic acid

questions.text: A 38-year-old auxiliary nurse midwife, attending a community health camp, is interested in cervical cancer screening and seeks advice on the most cost-effective method. Given the setting, which screening method is recommended? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. VIA – Visual inspection with 5% acetic acid

 

Visual inspection with acetic acid is naked-eye examination of the uterine cervix, after application of 5% acetic acid and interpreting the result after one minute. This is a simple and inexpensive test for the detection of cervical precancerous lesions and early invasive cancer. The white appearing areas are the areas of pathological involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: While effective, it requires laboratory infrastructure and is more costly compared to VIA.

 

Option C. Biopsy: This is a diagnostic procedure, not a primary screening tool, and it is more invasive and expensive.

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is used for further evaluation after an abnormal screening result and is more complex and costly than VIA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For community health settings, especially where resources are limited, VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid) offers a practical and economical approach to cervical cancer screening, allowing for immediate results and facilitating early intervention if necessary.

questions.text: According to the given graphs on occupation of people and risk of developing fever, which group has highest risk of developing fever? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. White collar jobs

 

Based on the component bar graph, the highest risk of developing fever is with white collar jobs (90%) according to given component bar graph.

 

Pie graph would have been considered if question asked about the population of workers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Component bar diagram shows the various parts of a single piece of data. They are also known as sub-diagrams. A bar graph is a particular type of data visualization that uses rectangular bars with each bar’s length proportional to the value it represents. Similar data distributions are also represented by pie charts whereas component bar diagrams are rectangular, pie charts are circular.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mother was diagnosed with mild depression, she has a 3 months old child. Which among the following should be preferred? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cognitive behavioral therapy

 

For mild depression, especially in a postpartum mother, non-pharmacological treatments like cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) are often preferred as a first-line approach. CBT is effective and avoids potential medication side effects or risks that could impact breastfeeding.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Cognitive therapy + antidepressant: Cognitive therapy + antidepressant may be appropriate for more severe depression or if the depression does not respond to cognitive therapy alone.

 

Option C. Antidepressant alone: Antidepressant alone can be considered, especially if the patient doesn't have access to or isn't interested in therapy. However, the choice of medication would need to take into account the patient's breastfeeding status.

 

Option D. Electroconvulsive therapy: Electroconvulsive therapy is usually reserved for severe cases of depression that are resistant to other treatments, or where there is a need for rapid symptom reduction due to risks like suicidality.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of mild depression, especially in postpartum mothers, non-pharmacological treatments such as cognitive behavior therapy are often the preferred first-line approach. For mild depression, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and SSRIs both are often the preferred first-line treatment options.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 392.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presented with a one-year history of low-grade fever, anorexia and weight loss. A barium meal follow through is done and, following images were seen. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocecal tuberculosis

 

In image the position of caecum is sub-hepatic (almost located in the right hypochondrium). Ileocecal tuberculosis (ITB) primarily involves the ileocecal region, which is the junction between the terminal ileum and the cecum. Radiological findings often include the "goose neck deformity" due to the pulled-up cecum resulting in an obtuse ileocecal angle. There can also be ulceration, strictures, nodularity, and enlarged lymph nodes. ITB can mimic Crohn's disease or even cancer in its presentation. The sub-hepatic positioning of the cecum as mentioned is a classic radiologic sign of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a twisting of the intestine on itself, leading to an obstruction. Common sites include the sigmoid colon and the cecum. A cecal volvulus might present with a dilated loop of the bowel in the upper abdomen, but its radiological appearance is distinct and would not usually manifest as a "goose neck deformity."

 

Option C. Cancer colon: Colon cancer can lead to an obstruction, especially if it's located in the left colon, leading to symptoms of constipation, blood in stool, weight loss, etc. On a barium study, an "apple core" or "napkin ring" lesion might be seen, which is indicative of a constriction in the colon due to the tumor.

 

Option D. Diverticulosis of colon: Diverticulosis refers to the presence of multiple diverticula (small pouches) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon. The barium study would typically show outpouchings in the wall of the colon, known as saw tooth appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ileocecal tuberculosis often presents with radiological signs like the "goose neck deformity" due to a pulled-up cecum and obtuse ileocecal angle, along with clinical symptoms such as low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss.

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive tissue in our body?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bone marrow

 

Bone marrow is the most radiosensitive tissue due to rapidly dividing cells.

 

Radiosensitivity is generally associated with the rate of cell division; tissues with cells that divide more frequently are more susceptible to damage from radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Skin: Skin has a moderate level of radiosensitivity. It is composed of layers with varying sensitivities; the basal cells of the epidermis are relatively radiosensitive because they are rapidly dividing. However, skin as a whole is not as sensitive as bone marrow.

 

Option. B. Muscles: Muscle tissue is generally radioresistant compared to bone marrow. This is because muscle cells are well-differentiated and do not divide frequently. Muscle tissues mainly consist of mature muscle fibers that have a very low turnover rate, making them less vulnerable to radiation.

 

Option. D. Nervous tissue: Nervous tissue, particularly in adults, is considered highly radioresistant. Neurons in the central nervous system (CNS) are fully differentiated and do not undergo regular division. This low mitotic rate contributes significantly to their radio resistance. However, certain components of the nervous system, like the neural precursors in the brain, can be more sensitive, though still not as sensitive as bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient who was involved in a road traffic accident 6 hours ago was brought to the emergency services with altered sensorium. His Glasgow coma score was 12. CT scan of the brain was done which showed the following. He is most likely suffering from? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extradural hematoma

 

EXTRADURAL HEMATOMA

 

  • Location: lies between skull and outer endosteal layer of duramater
  • Vessels involved: Middle meningeal artery
  • Presentation: Symptoms develop soon after injury, Lucid interval is characteristic of EDH
  • CT appearance: Biconvex opacity / lenticular shaped opacity

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extradural hematoma is characterized by a biconvex (lenticular) opacity on CT scan, typically due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery following trauma.

questions.text: A patient came with the following clinical findings in ophthalmology department. The consultant asked you the diagnosis while hinting to you that it was also known as ‘the warm weather conjunctivitis’. What will be your answer?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

 

  • Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or spring catarrh is also called as warm weather conjunctivitis
  • The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or spring catarrh
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction

 

Corneal signs in VKC

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus

 

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

 

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell-Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat

 

 

Limbal VKC

Horner-Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trachoma:

 

  • Cause: Chronic conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Signs: Follicular conjunctivitis, conjunctival scarring, and trichiasis (inturned eyelashes).
  • Differences: Not primarily associated with warm weather and lacks the cobblestone papillae characteristic of VKC.

 

Option C. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis:

 

  • Cause: Hypersensitivity reaction to bacterial antigens, often Staphylococcus.
  • Signs: Small, raised, white nodules on the conjunctiva or cornea with surrounding hyperemia.
  • Differences: Not seasonal or associated with warm weather, and does not present with cobblestone papillae or ropy discharge.

 

Option D. Xerophthalmia:

 

  • Cause: Severe dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea due to vitamin A deficiency.
  • Signs: Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, and keratomalacia.
  • Differences: Not an allergic condition and does not present with the typical signs of VKC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is characterized by seasonal occurrence in warm weather, cobblestone papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Horner-Trantas spots. It primarily affects boys around the age of 5 and involves both type 1 and type 4 hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Maxillary sinus

 

This X-ray presents the occipitomental view of water's perspective, showcasing an open mouth. The highlighted area corresponds to the maxillary sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, 493

questions.text: In a discussion on the role of global agencies in advancing public health, a question arose about which international entity leads in financial support for reproductive health initiatives. Which organization is primarily recognized for its substantial contributions to population and reproductive health worldwide? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. UNFPA

 

 

UNFPA: United Nation Fund for Population Activities

 

  • Headquarters: New York, USA
  • The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) has been providing assistance to India since 1974. In addition to funding national level schemes, Area Projects for intensive development of health and family welfare infrastructure and improvement in the availability of services in the rural areas have been under implementation in eleven districts of Bihar and 4 districts of Rajasthan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UNDP: The United Nations Development Programme, while instrumental in broader development projects (SDGs, technical assistance).

 

Option B. UNICEF: Primarily concerned with children's welfare, UNICEF’s focus is more oriented towards child health and education.

 

Option D. UNESCO: Focuses on education, science, and cultural programs and initiatives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNFPA is the key global organization committed to funding initiatives that support population and reproductive health, playing a vital role in promoting sustainable health improvements for communities around the world.

choices.text: Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E markers

questions.text: A patient came with the pain in right hypochondrium. Blood investigation shows AST-22 IU/l and ALT-27 IU/ L, serum direct bilirubin levels -6mg% and ALP- 400 mg % What should be the next investigation in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG abdomen

 

The patient presents with pain in the right hypochondrium and has normal AST and ALT levels, elevated serum direct bilirubin levels, and a raised ALP level. These features are suggestive of obstructive jaundice. Ultrasound (USG) is a useful first-line investigation for jaundice of unknown cause as it can demonstrate duct dilatation and gallstones. The patient's raised bilirubin and ALP levels suggest a cholestatic or obstructive pathology, which could be due to gallstones, tumors, or bile duct obstructions. USG is the first-line imaging choice in these scenarios because it can quickly and non-invasively identify gallstones, bile duct dilatation, and other hepato-biliary abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CECT abdomen: While a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan of the abdomen provides a more detailed visualization of abdominal structures, especially with the use of contrast, it's not typically the first-line investigation for the given clinical scenario. It may be considered if USG findings are inconclusive or additional details are needed.

 

Option C. Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E markers: These markers determine if there's a viral cause to liver inflammation. However, the patient's presentation is more suggestive of an obstructive pathology rather than viral hepatitis, given the normal AST and ALT values.

 

Option D. HIDA scan: A HIDA scan helps visualize the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts, and small intestine and is particularly useful in assessing the function of the gallbladder. However, it is not the primary investigation for the given presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients presenting with pain in the right hypochondrium and biochemical evidence suggestive of obstructive jaundice, an abdominal ultrasound (USG) is the preferred initial investigation to identify the cause of obstruction.

questions.text: Supravital staining is used for? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reticulocytes

 

Reticulocytes are young, premature, non-nucleated red blood cells, contain reticular material (RNA) that stain gray Blue.

 

 

Reticulum is present in newly released blood cells for 1-2 days before the cell reach its full mature state.

 

RBCs have six stages:

 

  1. Pronormoblast
  2. Basophilic normoblast
  3. Polychromatophilic normoblast (Bone Marrow)
  4. Orthochromic normoblast
  5. Reticulocyte (2–3-day)
  6. Mature red blood cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red blood cells: Supravital staining is not typically used to identify mature red blood cells.

 

Option B. Platelets: Supravital staining is not used for platelets.

 

Option D. White blood cells: Supravital staining is not typically used for white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supravital staining is specifically used to identify reticulocytes by staining their reticular material (RNA), which appears gray-blue.

questions.text: A training seminar on biomedical waste management is held by the chief nursing officer, Ms Isha, at a District Hospital for new healthcare staff. While demonstrating with various colored bags, she questioned the attendees about the specific bag intended for incineration. What color bag is used for incineration according to the guidelines? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Yellow

 

The yellow color bag is specifically used for incineration under the biomedical waste management guidelines in India. This bag is meant for the disposal of a range of items including human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, and certain microbiological, biotechnological, and clinical laboratory wastes. These materials are designated for incineration due to their potential risk of infection or their chemical nature, which requires destruction at high temperatures to prevent environmental contamination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: When stained with Congo red and visualized under the polarizing microscope, which of the following substance would show apple green birefringence? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amyloid

 

  • Amyloid can also be identified with the Wright stain as a waxy, pink to dark purple cellular mass appearance.
  • Most commonly, amyloid can be identified with the Congo red stain as an “apple-green birefringence” when viewed Under polarized microscopic light.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipids: These do not show apple-green birefringence under polarized light with Congo red staining.

 

Option C. Collagen: Collagen does not exhibit apple-green birefringence with Congo red stain under polarized light.

 

Option D. Calcium: Calcium deposits do not show apple-green birefringence with Congo red staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid exhibits apple-green birefringence when stained with Congo red and visualized under polarized microscopic light.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred in premature neonates for closure of PDA? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ibuprofen

 

In premature newborns, Ibuprofen is currently preferred over Indomethacin as the medication of choice for the closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

  • Ibuprofen: It is effective in promoting the closure of PDA in premature neonates. It inhibits the production of prostaglandins, which are responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is also used to close PDA and works similarly by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. However, Ibuprofen is generally preferred due to a potentially better safety profile and similar efficacy.

 

Option C. Mefenamic acid: Mefenamic acid is not typically used for PDA closure in neonates. It is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) but not indicated for this specific use.

 

Option D. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen): Paracetamol can also be used for PDA closure in some cases, particularly when NSAIDs are contraindicated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ibuprofen is the preferred drug for the closure of PDA in premature neonates due to its effectiveness and safety profile. Recognizing the appropriate pharmacological treatment for PDA is crucial in neonatal care.

choices.text: Deficiency of branched chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex

questions.text: A child 5 years old was presented to a pediatrician by his parents with the history of frequent attacks of convulsions and unconsciousness. They also complained about his poor intake of food, weight loss, poor learning ability, fatigue and burnt sugar odour from urine. Plasma concentration of leucine is higher than 1000 micromol/L. What is the correct statement? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deficiency of branched chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex

 

This deficiency is characteristic of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), which the symptoms described in the question align with. MSUD is named for the distinctive sweet odor of affected infants' urine, similar to burnt sugar or maple syrup. The disease leads to high levels of branched-chain amino acids like leucine in the blood and urine, causing neurological issues, including seizures and intellectual disability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex: This deficiency disrupts the normal conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to a buildup of pyruvate and lactate in the blood, and often results in lactic acidosis. The symptoms include poor feeding, vomiting, and developmental delay.

 

Option C. Deficiency of oxoglutarate dehydrogenase complex: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, and its deficiency could lead to neurological issues and muscle weakness. However, it does not typically result in the specific symptoms described, such as the burnt sugar odor in urine and extremely high leucine levels.

 

Option D. Deficiency of oxaloacetate: This is not a typical enzymatic deficiency and does not align with the symptoms described. Oxaloacetate is a component of the Krebs cycle and is crucial for energy production. Shortage of oxaloacetate occur during the fasting/starvation condition leading to increased conversion of acetyl CoA in to ketone body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burnt sugar like odor is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acid -Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are raised in blood and also gets excreted in urine.

 

 

Diagnosis

 

  1. Ferric chloride test:  Detects Phenylpyruvate and Branched chain amino acid in urine.
  2. DNPH (Dinitro Phenyl Hydrazine) test: Detects α –Keto acids in urine (yellow color).
  3. Confirmatory test: Detection of BCAA or BCKA in urine/blood by HPLC.

 

Clinical Features of MSUD

 

  • Burnt sugar like odor (because of increased isoleucine)
  • Mental retardation (because of increased leucine)
  • Ketosis (due to increases BCKA)
  • If not treated then coma and Death can occur (high mortality rate)
  • Vomiting, feeding problems
  • Abnormal muscle tone

 

Treatment

 

  • Diet is given which is restricted in branched chain amino acids, but some amount given to allow normal growth.
  • Supplementation of Vitamin B1 can be helpful in some patients.

 

Ref: Harper 30th/e pg. 309

questions.text: All of the following are paired cartilages, except? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid

 

The thyroid cartilage is unpaired one. It is the largest cartilage of the larynx and forms the Adam's apple in the neck. It is connected to the cricoid cartilage below but does not have a left and right counterpart. Therefore, it is not a paired cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arytenoid Cartilages: Arytenoid cartilages are paired cartilages located in the larynx (voice box). There are two of them, and they sit on top of the cricoid cartilage. The arytenoid cartilages are crucial for vocal cord movement and voice production.

 

Option C. Cuneiform Cartilages: The cuneiform cartilages, also known as the cuneiform tubercles, are small paired cartilages located within the laryngeal mucosa. They provide support to the vocal folds and help maintain their shape.

 

Option D. Corniculate Cartilages: The corniculate cartilages are also paired cartilages in the larynx. They sit atop the apex of each arytenoid cartilage and contribute to the stability of the aryepiglottic folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The larynx has 3 unpaired and 3 paired cartilages:

Unpaired:

  • ﻿﻿Thyroid
  • ﻿﻿Cricoid
  • ﻿﻿Epiglottis

Paired:

  • ﻿﻿Arytenoid
  • ﻿﻿Corniculate
  • ﻿﻿Cuneiform

choices.text: Non-fusion of palatine shelves
Non fusion of medial nasal process & maxillary process
Non fusion of lateral nasal process & maxillary process
Separation of nasal septum & vomer from palatine process

questions.text: A new born presents with congenital anomaly of cleft lip. Which is the embryological development defect? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non fusion of medial nasal process & maxillary process

 

The formation of the upper lip involves the fusion of the medial nasal processes (arising from the middle portion of the developing nose) and the maxillary processes (originating from the sides of the developing face). This fusion typically occurs between the fourth and seventh weeks of embryonic development. When there is a failure in the fusion of these structures, a cleft lip can result. This defect causes an opening or gap in the upper lip, which can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-fusion of palatine shelves:

 

  • The palatine shelves arise from the maxillary processes and fuse in the midline to form the hard and soft palates. A failure of these shelves to fuse results in a cleft palate, which is distinct from a cleft lip. Cleft palate involves an opening in the roof of the mouth and does not necessarily involve the lip.

 

Option C. Non-fusion of lateral nasal process & maxillary process:

 

  • The lateral nasal processes contribute to the formation of the alae (sides) of the nose. A failure in their fusion with the maxillary process does not result in a cleft lip. Such a defect might lead to nasal deformities but not specifically to a cleft lip.

 

Option D. Separation of nasal septum & vomer from palatine process:

 

  • The nasal septum, along with the vomer, separates the nasal cavity into left and right halves. Their separation from the palatine process does not lead to a cleft lip but could result in other nasal cavity abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The embryological defect responsible for a cleft lip is the non-fusion of the medial nasal process and the maxillary process. Most common surgery for treatment of unilateral cleft lip is Millard Rotation Advancement Surgery.

 

 

Cleft Palate: it occurs due to the non-fusion of maxillary processes in the center.

 

Defect and their Repair Timeline

questions.text: Patients receiving which of the following anti-microbial drugs are least likely to develop seizures? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Macrolides

 

Macrolides, such as erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin, are known for their broad antimicrobial activity and are generally well-tolerated with a low risk of causing seizures. They are primarily used to treat respiratory and skin infections and are often chosen for patients with allergies to penicillin’s. The safety profile of macrolides regarding neurotoxic effects like seizures is significantly better compared to the other options listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta-lactam compounds: While generally safe, some beta-lactams, particularly the carbapenems (e.g., imipenem), are associated with a higher risk of seizures, especially at high doses or in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option B. Quinolones: Drugs like ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin are associated with an increased risk of seizures, particularly in patients with existing CNS disorders. Quinolones are known to have neuroexcitatory effects which can precipitate seizures.

 

Option D. Isoniazid: Commonly used in the treatment of tuberculosis, isoniazid can cause seizures in cases of overdose and is particularly concerning in patients with low levels of pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Supplementation with pyridoxine is often required to mitigate this risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When considering the risk of seizures associated with antimicrobial therapy, macrolides represent the safest option among those listed. They are particularly useful in scenarios where a low risk of neurotoxicity is a critical factor in drug selection.

questions.text: A 49-year-old COPD patient admitted in ICU is on oxygen therapy with simple Hudson mask with 2 liters of oxygen. His pCO2 on blood gas analysis was 64mmHg. What is the next step? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start BiPAP

 

  • The elevated pCO2 indicates that the patient is hypoventilating, meaning they are not exhaling enough CO2.
  • BiPAP provides two levels of pressure: higher pressure during inhalation (to help get oxygen into the lungs) and a lower pressure during exhalation (to help wash out CO2).
  • BiPAP can be especially beneficial for COPD patients experiencing acute exacerbations or those with hypercapnic respiratory failure. It assists their breathing, supports oxygenation, and aids in CO2 removal.
  • This option is suitable for patients who are conscious, cooperative, and not in immediate respiratory distress, making it an excellent non-invasive choice before considering intubation.

 

 

 

This patient is showing increased CO2 levels in blood (hypercapnia), it means patients respiratory rate is less or tidal volume is less and he is unable to washout all the CO2 from his lungs. In other words, these are signs of hypoventilation. 

Given the situation described, starting BiPAP would be the most appropriate step. The patient's increased pCO2 suggests that he is not able to exhale CO2 effectively, and BiPAP can help in augmenting his exhalation and thus improve CO2 washout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the FiO2:

 

  • FiO2 stands for Fraction of Inspired Oxygen, which represents the concentration of oxygen in the air we breathe.
  • Increasing FiO2 would m
  • ean delivering a higher concentration of oxygen to the patient.
  • While this could potentially help increase the oxygen saturation levels in the blood, it does not directly address the issue of CO2 retention (hypercapnia), which is the problem in this case.

 

Option B. Decrease the FiO2:

 

  • Decreasing FiO2 would reduce the oxygen concentration being delivered.
  • Simply decreasing the FiO2 will not address the CO2 retention issue.

 

Option D. Intubate immediately:

 

  • Intubation involves placing a tube into the patient's trachea to secure the airway and then connecting them to a mechanical ventilator.
  • It's an invasive procedure and is usually reserved for situations where non-invasive measures (like BiPAP) fail or if the patient's condition is deteriorating rapidly.
  • Immediate intubation might not be the first choice in this scenario unless the patient shows other signs of respiratory distress or failure.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2543-2544

choices.text: Invasive lobular carcinoma
Invasive ductal carcinoma

questions.text: A lady has been diagnosed with breast cancer. Her biopsy report revealing the presence of tumor cells with signet ring appearance, mucin deposition and “Indian file pattern” is most likely suggestive of? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive lobular carcinoma

 

Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is characterized by dyscohesive and infiltrating tumor cells, often arranged in single file or in loose clusters or sheets, known as the "Indian file" pattern. The histologic hallmark of ILC includes signet-ring cells containing an intracytoplasmic mucin droplet. CDH1, the gene coding for the E-cadherin adhesion protein, is of special interest as mutations are associated with invasive lobular carcinoma but not with ductal carcinoma.

 

 

Key morphological features:

 

  • Tubule formation: Absent.
  • Signet-ring cells: Containing an intracytoplasmic mucin droplet are common.
  • Desmoplasia: Minimal or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive ductal carcinoma: Characterized by the formation of duct-like structures, not typically associated with the Indian file pattern or signet-ring cells.

 

Option C. Medullary cancer: Features syncytial growth, a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and a well-circumscribed border, different from ILC.

 

Option D. Mucinous carcinoma: Characterized by extracellular mucin production, not the Indian file pattern or signet-ring cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive lobular carcinoma is identified by dyscohesive, infiltrating tumor cells arranged in an Indian file pattern, with signet-ring cells containing mucin, and is associated with CDH1 gene mutations.

choices.text: Lambert Eaton syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the medicine OPD with complaints of muscle weakness and blurring of vision following exertion more towards the evening. On examination, the patient had ptosis. The symptoms improved after edrophonium test. The person is likely suffering from? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability. The hallmark of the disease is muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The patient’s symptoms of muscle weakness and blurring of vision following exertion, along with ptosis, are typical of myasthenia gravis.

 

The improvement of symptoms after the edrophonium test (also known as the Tensilon test) is a classic diagnostic finding. Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, and its administration temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength in patients with myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton syndrome: This condition is also a neuromuscular disorder but typically presents with proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity (opposite to myasthenia gravis). It is often associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

Option C. Guillain-Barre syndrome: This is an acute polyneuropathy often characterized by ascending muscle weakness and areflexia. It does not show diurnal variation or improvement with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option D. Bronchial asthma: This is a respiratory condition characterized by airway hyperreactivity, leading to wheezing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness. It does not present with muscle weakness or improve with edrophonium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, and is characterized by ocular symptoms such as ptosis. The diagnosis is supported by improvement of symptoms with the edrophonium test.

choices.text: Manually bring testis down to the bottom of scrotum

questions.text: In a newborn baby born with an empty scrotum, testis was found to be laying close to the peritoneum. Which of the following techniques helps the testis to reach the scrotum? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GnRH Analogues

 

The clinical scenario given is a case of undescended testis (cryptorchidism). It is common for some newborns, particularly premature infants, to have undescended testicles. In most cases, spontaneous descent occurs within the first few months of life. Maternal chorionic gonadotropin plays a role in stimulating the growth and migration of the testis.

 

For newborns with undescended testis, the initial approach is typically to wait and watch for spontaneous descent, which often happens by 3 months of age. If the testis does not descend spontaneously by this time, hormonal therapy with GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) analogues or hCG (human Chorionic Gonadotropin) can be tried to induce descent.

 

If hormonal therapy is ineffective, surgical intervention (orchidopexy) is recommended. The optimal time for orchidopexy is between 6 months and 12 months of age to decrease the risks of infertility and malignancy associated with undescended testicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testosterone supplementation: While testosterone can induce secondary sexual characteristics and increase the size of the testis, it is not typically used to induce descent of undescended testis in neonates.

 

Option C. Cold compression: This is not a recognized method for promoting testicular descent and could be potentially harmful.

 

Option D. Manually bring testis down to the bottom of scrotum: This approach is not practical or safe. Manual manipulation can be part of a physical examination to assess the mobility of the testis, but persistent undescended testis requires medical or surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of undescended testis, spontaneous descent is monitored for the first few months. If it does not occur, GnRH analogues can be used to facilitate descent before considering surgical intervention (orchidopexy).

questions.text: Dr. Anita, an obstetrician in Bangalore, discusses a demographic statistic reflecting the average number of children a woman would bear during her reproductive years based on current fertility rates. What is this statistic called? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Total fertility rate

 

The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) indicates the average number of children a woman is expected to have over her reproductive lifespan, assuming current age-specific fertility rates hold. This rate is crucial for assessing population growth and planning related health services.

 

Note –

 

If Couple Protection Rate > 60%, then TFR = 2.1 and NRR = 1

 

Current TFR of India (NFHS-5, 2019-21) is 2.0

 

Other Options:  

 

Option B. GRR: Measures the no. of daughters a woman would have in her lifetime

 

Option C. NRR: No. of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality or in other words, the total number of females born who survived till the age of 15-49 years.

 

Option D. GFR: number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Total Fertility Rate is a key demographic figure that indicates the average number of children per woman, essential for understanding and addressing population dynamics.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used in the closure of PDA? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Indomethacin

 

NSAID's like Indomethacin and Ibuprofen (now drug of choice) are used in the medical management to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). NSAIDS lead to a decrease in the level of PGs by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Magnesium sulfate is a neuroprotective drug which acts as an antagonist on NMDA receptors reducing the calcium uptake. It is used in treatment and prevention of Eclampsia, Torsades de pointes and Severe Acute Asthma.

 

Option B. Alprostadil is a PGE1 analog which is used to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. It is indicated in the congenital diseases in which survival of the child requires patency of the ductus arteriosus like TGA, Hypoplastic left heart syndrome.

 

Option D. Misoprostol is a PGE1 analog which is used in cervical ripening, induction of labor, medical termination of pregnancy, management and prevention of PPH, can also be used in treatment of NSAID induced gastric ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin is effectively used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus in newborns, leveraging its ability to reduce prostaglandin levels, thereby promoting the natural closure of the ductus arteriosus that typically occurs after birth. This intervention is crucial in preventing complications associated with an open PDA.

questions.text: What is the most frequently fractured site in the orbit following trauma to the eye resulting from a punch during a physical altercation? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Floor

 

The most common site of an orbital fracture due to blunt trauma is the floor of the orbit as it is relatively weak

The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout fracture through the antrum.

Isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blowout fracture.

Clinical signs: periocular swelling (early stage), enophthalmos, ecchymosis and subconjunctival hemorrhage (later stages)

 

Investigation:

  • X ray - water view
  • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Incorrect: While the medial wall of the orbit can be fractured, it is less common compared to the orbital floor. Medial wall fractures often result from severe trauma and may involve the ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: Incorrect: The lateral wall is quite strong and less likely to fracture from blunt trauma compared to other orbital walls.

 

Option C. Roof: Incorrect: Fractures of the orbital roof are rare and usually result from severe trauma that affects the frontal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital floor fractures are common following blunt trauma to the eye. Recognizing the clinical signs and using appropriate imaging are crucial for diagnosis and management. Surgical intervention may be necessary in severe cases. Preventive measures, like protective eyewear, are important to reduce the risk of such injuries.

questions.text: Barium enema image demonstrates: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diverticulosis of colon

 

The given image is a barium enema showing saw-tooth appearing sigmoid and descending colon, suggestive of diverticulosis.

 

DIVERTICULOSIS

 

  • Saw-tooth appearance seen on barium enema
  • Description: serrated/concertina-like appearance of bowel
  • Most common site: Sigmoid colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum and is caused due to persistent omphalomesenteric duct. It appears as a diverticulum in the ileum, typically 2 feet proximal to ileocecal junction.

 

Option C. Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus and occurs when a portion of the intestine twists around its blood supply. It occurs in the patients with a history of chronic constipation. This occurs at the base of the mesentery.

 

 

Option D. Colon cancer appears as apple core appearance on barium enema. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diverticulosis of the colon presents with a characteristic saw-tooth appearance on barium enema, most commonly affecting the sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Patient presents with headache and black nasal discharge, post COVID infection. What is the condition she is suffering from? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucormycosis

 

Mucormycosis is a type of fungal infection. It’s relatively rare, but also very serious.

 

Formally known as zygomycosis (black fungus), this infection tends to occur most often if you have weakened immunity from an illness or health condition.

 

Some pathological findings commonly associated with mucormycosis:

 

  1. Invasion of Blood Vessels: The fungi can be observed infiltrating and thrombosing blood vessels, leading to tissue infarction and necrosis.
  2. Tissue Necrosis: Mucormycosis often causes extensive tissue necrosis due to angioinvasion and subsequent thrombosis. The affected tissues may appear necrotic, black, or dark in color.
  3. Presence of Fungal Hyphae: Microscopic examination of the affected tissues may reveal characteristic fungal hyphae. These hyphae are typically broad, irregularly branching, and non-septate (aseptate).
  4. Inflammatory Response: This can be observed histologically, with the presence of inflammatory cells such as neutrophils and macrophages surrounding the fungal hyphae.
  5. Tissue Destruction and Invasion: Mucormycosis fungi invade and destroy the surrounding tissues, leading to the characteristic tissue damage and necrosis seen in the infection.

 

It’s important to get treatment. If left untreated, mucormycosis can be fatal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: Caused by Aspergillus species, it primarily affects the lungs and is not typically associated with black nasal discharge.

 

Option C. Coccidiosis: This is a parasitic infection, not a fungal infection, and does not cause the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it leads to polypoid lesions in the nasal cavity but does not typically present with black nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that can occur in individuals with weakened immunity, presenting with symptoms such as headache and black nasal discharge. It requires prompt treatment to prevent fatal outcomes.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue. She had pallor on physical examination. Lab values are given below: (FMGE JUNE 2021)

 

  • Hb: 9.8 g/dL
  • MCV: 106 fL
  • Platelets: 1,80,000/mm³
  • WBC count: 7800/mm³
  • Serum methylmalonyl CoA levels: Normal

 

Which of the following should be administered as a therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folic acid

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia (MCV 106 fL) and normal methylmalonyl CoA levels. Macrocytic anemia can be caused by deficiencies in either vitamin B12 or folate. However, normal methylmalonyl CoA levels indicate that vitamin B12 deficiency is unlikely because elevated methylmalonyl CoA levels are a specific marker for vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

  • Macrocytic anemia: An MCV greater than 100 fL suggests macrocytic anemia, often due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA: Normal levels of methylmalonyl CoA point towards folate deficiency since elevated levels would suggest vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

The absence of neurological symptoms, which are typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, further supports the diagnosis of folate deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vit B12: Given that the methylmalonyl CoA levels are normal, vitamin B12 deficiency is unlikely.

 

Option B. Iron: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents as microcytic anemia (low MCV), not macrocytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency does not cause macrocytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency is indicated by macrocytic anemia with normal methylmalonyl CoA levels and the absence of neurological symptoms. The appropriate treatment is folic acid supplementation.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made. Where do you least expect the urine to get collected in this case? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Medial portion of thigh

 

Urine collection in the medial portion of the thigh is also unlikely in cases of bulbar urethral injury. The path of least resistance for urine extravasation is generally in the direction of the perineum and scrotum, not toward the thigh. The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

 

Note - In cases of bulbar urethral injury, urine leakage can occur due to damage to the urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perineum: Expected Site: One of the common sites for urine collection in cases of bulbar urethral injury is the perineum. The perineum is the area between the anus and the scrotum (in males) or the vaginal orifice (in females). Injury to the bulbar urethra can result in urine extravasation into the perineal tissues, leading to swelling and hematoma formation in this region.

 

Option B. Anterior Abdominal Wall: Unlikely Site: Urine collection in the anterior abdominal wall is unlikely in cases of bulbar urethral injury because the site of injury is closer to the perineum, and urine typically extravasates into the surrounding perineal tissues rather than tracking upward into the abdominal wall.

 

Option D. Root of Scrotum: Expected Site: Another common site for urine collection in bulbar urethral injury is the root of the scrotum. The root of the scrotum refers to the base of the scrotum where it attaches to the perineum. Injury to the bulbar urethra can result in urine extravasation into the scrotal tissues, leading to swelling and hematoma formation at the scrotal base.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.
  • The superficial perineal pouch is a compartment of the perineum enclosed by the membranous layer of the perineal fascia that surrounds the scrotum or labia and penis or clitoris.
  • The membranous layer of perineal fascia is continuous anteriorly over the pubic symphysis and pubic bones. It is later joined to the membranous layer of the anterior abdominal wall. As a result, the fluid that accumulates in the perineal pouch spreads to the lower anterior abdomen.
  • The abdominal fascia is attached to the deep fascia of the thigh in the lower lateral abdominal wall, inferior to the inguinal ligament. As a result of trauma to the penile urethra, urine does not extravasate into the anterior thigh.
  • The superficial perineal pouch is closed posteriorly by attaching the membranous layer of superficial fascia to the posterior margin of the urogenital diaphragm. As a result, there is usually no extravasation into the deep perineal pouch or the ischiorectal fossa.

questions.text: A man had just returned from Assam when he developed fever, chills and rigors and altered sensorium. The peripheral smear demonstrated the presence of Plasmodium falciparum. What is the treatment of choice for this patient? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous Artesunate

 

Intravenous Artesunate is the treatment of choice for severe malaria, including cases with cerebral involvement as indicated by symptoms such as altered sensorium. This condition, often referred to as cerebral malaria, is a severe complication of P. falciparum infection and is potentially life-threatening. Artesunate works rapidly and is effective in reducing the parasitic load quickly, thus reducing the severity of the symptoms and preventing further complications. The recommended dosing for severe malaria is 2.4 mg/kg given intravenously at 0, 12, and 24 hours initially, followed by a transition to oral antimalarial therapy to complete the treatment course.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine: Historically the treatment of choice for malaria, chloroquine is no longer effective against P. falciparum in many parts of the world due to widespread resistance, including areas like Assam.

 

Option B. Quinine: Once a mainstay for the treatment of malaria, quinine is now less commonly used due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments such as artesunate.

 

Option D. Artemether: Artemether is part of the artemisinin group and is used in the treatment of uncomplicated malaria and as a second-line option for severe cases if artesunate is not available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For severe P. falciparum malaria, especially when complicated by signs of cerebral involvement, intravenous artesunate is the recommended first-line treatment due to its rapid action, effectiveness, and better safety profile compared to alternatives like quinine and artemether. Transition to oral antimalarial therapy is necessary once the patient is stable and able to tolerate oral medications.

questions.text: Salt pepper appearance of the fundus is seen in all of the following except? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis

 

Salt and pepper fundus is not seen in tuberculosis.

 

Tuberculosis most commonly affects the lungs, but has many extrapulmonary manifestations as well, including intraocular involvement.

 

 

Posterior uveitis most often indicates choroidal involvement of tuberculosis. Choroiditis in tuberculosis can present in serpiginous-like fashion, and is hypothesized to occur due to a hypersensitivity reaction to present acid-fast bacilli.

 

Salt and Pepper Retinopathy seen in Congenital Rubella Syndrome is shown below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella:

 

Fundus Appearance: Salt and pepper retinopathy is a well-known ocular manifestation of congenital rubella syndrome. It presents as mottled pigmentation in the retina, resembling grains of salt and pepper.

 

Option B. Syphilis:

 

Fundus Appearance: In congenital syphilis, salt and pepper retinopathy can also be seen. This manifests as areas of hypo- and hyperpigmentation in the retina.

 

Option C. Refsum's Disease:

 

Fundus Appearance: Refsum's disease, a rare genetic disorder, can cause a salt and pepper appearance of the fundus due to retinal pigmentary changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pseudo-retinitis pigmentosa (salt and pepper fundus):

  • Rubella
  • Syphilis
  • Refsum's disease
  •  Carriers of albinism
  • Leber's congenital amaurosis

choices.text: It exists in trophozoite form only
The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM
The treatment of choice is metronidazole

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix appeared strawberry-like. Which of the following statements is false regarding the causative organism? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

 

The symptoms of trichomoniasis in women may include vaginal itching, burning, and discharge, while in men, it may cause urethritis and discharge from the penis. However, many people infected with T. vaginalis may not have any symptoms at all.

 

The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM: This statement is false. While culture can be used to diagnose trichomoniasis, the gold standard for diagnosis is nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), which are highly sensitive and specific. Culture on CPLM (Cysteine Peptone Liver Maltose) or PEM (Pouch Enrichment Medium) is not considered the gold standard.

 

The infection is typically diagnosed through laboratory tests that detect the presence of the parasite in genital secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It exists in trophozoite form only: This statement is true. Trichomonas vaginalis exists only in the trophozoite form and does not have a cyst form. It is a flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

Option B. It is an obligate parasite: This statement is true. Trichomonas vaginalis is an obligate parasite, meaning it relies on a host organism to complete its life cycle and cannot survive long outside a host.

 

Option D. The treatment of choice is metronidazole: This statement is true. Metronidazole or tinidazole is the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis. Both drugs are highly effective in eradicating the infection.

 

Prevention strategies for trichomoniasis include practicing safe sex by using condoms, limiting the number of sexual partners, and getting regular STI testing. It is also important for sexual partners to be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis exists only in the trophozoite form and is an obligate parasite. The gold standard for diagnosis is nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs). The treatment of choice is metronidazole.

questions.text: During the normal delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, the intern prematurely removes the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta, and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine inversion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine inversion: This uncommon cause of postpartum collapse has an abrupt onset and happens right after birth.
  • Uterine inversion causes neurogenic shock due to stretch of the uterosacral ligaments
  • Immediate replacement of the inverted uterus needs to be done
  • The most frequent third-stage management error is delivering a placenta that hasn't yet been detached (Crede's method).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid embolism: Amniotic fluid enters maternal circulation through a break in the membranes or placenta. Thromboplastin rich fluid containing debris are deposited in vessels trigger coagulation ultimately leading to DIC.

 

Option B. Postpartum hemorrhage: It may be atonic, traumatic, due to retained products or due to coagulopathy. There is presence of vaginal bleeding on examination, in atonic pph uterus is flabby whereas in traumatic PPH uterus may be contracted.

 

Option D. Uterine rupture: Characterized by shock (Hypotension and tachycardia), sudden cessation of contractions, sharp abdominal pain, fresh vaginal bleeding, fetal parts palpable easily, Fetal heart rate is usually absent, Uterus felt separately/ loss of normal uterine contour, hematuria and on P/V: loss of station

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine inversion occurs when the uterus turns inside out, often due to premature removal of the placenta, and presents with the uterus partly outside the introitus and hemorrhagic shock. Immediate replacement of the uterus is crucial.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, Williams textbook of Obstetrics Page 487

questions.text: Among the following options, which is the most common treatment for recurrent Pterygium of eye? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conjunctival autograft

 

The most commonly used technique for recurrent pterygium among the following is conjunctival autograft

Beta-irradiation: Beta irradiation is adjunctive procedure doing during conjunctival autografting. In this, after excision of the pterygium, beta irradiation is given to the sclera bed.

Other adjunctive procedures to reduce rate of recurrence of pterygium: 5FU, MMC, Amniotic membrane grafting.
