A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. Histologically. It is made up of elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beta-radiation:

 

  • Usage: This is used as an adjunctive treatment to prevent recurrence after surgical removal of pterygium. It involves applying beta radiation to the scleral bed after pterygium excision.
  • Advantages: Reduces the recurrence rate of pterygium.
  • Disadvantages: Can have potential side effects, including delayed healing and scleral thinning.

 

Option C. Observation:

 

  • Usage: This approach is generally not recommended for recurrent pterygium, especially if it affects vision or causes significant discomfort.
  • Advantages: Non-invasive and avoids surgical risks.
  • Disadvantages: Does not address the underlying problem, allowing it to potentially worsen over time.

 

Option D. Bare sclera technique:

 

  • Usage: Involves excising the pterygium and leaving the sclera exposed.
  • Advantages: Simple and quick surgical procedure.
  • Disadvantages: Higher recurrence rate compared to conjunctival autografting and adjunctive treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent pterygium is best treated with conjunctival autograft due to its lower recurrence rates and effectiveness. Adjunctive treatments can further enhance outcomes. Observation and bare sclera technique are less effective in preventing recurrence. Understanding the nature of pterygium is crucial for selecting the appropriate treatment approach.

choices.text: Autoclaving at 121 degrees Celsius for 30 - 60 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes or less
Flash autoclaving at 134 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30 - 60 minutes

questions.text: Which among the following methods is used to sterilize a glass petri dish? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes or less

 

Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware like petri dish. The dry heat effectively kills all microorganisms, including spores, without using moisture, which is suitable for glassware.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glass petri dishes are best sterilized using a hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes or less to ensure complete sterilization without causing any damage to the glassware.

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased prolactin secretion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Increased prolactin release is the cause of lactational amenorrhea.
  • Prolactin is secreted in pulsatile bursts during lactation in response to sucking, and this suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH, which results in lactational amenorrhea.
  • If the woman remains amenorrheic, regular lactation with one feed at night can delay ovulation and conception for up to six months. (Lactational amenorrhoea method)
  • After six months, nursing has little effect on ovulation, and conception is still possible despite amenorrhea and the potential need for additional contraceptives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased progesterone: Progesterone in pregnancy is initially secreted by the corpus luteum up to 6 weeks, the placenta starts gradually taking over the function and completely takes over by 12 weeks.

 

Option B. Increased GnRH secretion: It is untrue as prolactin suppresses GnRH

 

Option C. Decreased prolactin secretion: It is untrue as prolactin levels increase in pregnancy and are responsible for secretion of milk. Increased secretion is the cause of lactational amenorrhoea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lactational amenorrhea is caused by increased prolactin secretion, which suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH, thereby preventing ovulation.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page172

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation:

 

Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.

 

Bainbridge reflex: Correct. The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for controlling heart rate in response to blood volume. Increased blood volume is detected by stretch receptors located in both sides of the atria at the venoatrial junctions, leading to tachycardia during right atrial distension.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Bezold-Jarisch reflex: Incorrect. The Bezold-Jarisch reflex responds to noxious ventricular stimuli sensed by chemoreceptors and mechanoreceptors within the left ventricular wall by inducing hypotension, bradycardia, and coronary artery dilatation.


Option C. Cushing reflex: Incorrect. The Cushing reflex is a response to acute elevations of intracranial pressure, causing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration due to compromised blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons.


Option D. J reflex: Incorrect. The J reflex is related to pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary edema and pneumonia. Stimulation of J-receptors causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension, which is always pathological.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex controls heart rate in response to increased blood volume and leads to tachycardia during right atrial distension.

questions.text: Given mosquito causes which disease? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. JE

 

The mosquito shown in the image is identified as a Culex species, which is known for transmitting diseases such as Bancroftian filariasis and Japanese Encephalitis, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Amoebic liver abscess

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic male presented with pain in epigastrium radiating to the back 4 weeks ago. He now presents with an epigastric lump. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pancreatic pseudocyst

 

History of an alcoholic male with epigastric pain is suggestive of Pancreatitis. The given duration of 4 weeks with epigastric lump is pointing towards its complication which is most likely be Pancreatic Pseudocyst. Pancreatic pseudocysts are collections of leaked pancreatic fluids. They may form next to the pancreas during pancreatitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amoebic liver abscess:

 

  • This is an extraintestinal infection caused by the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. Symptoms might include pain in the upper right part of the abdomen and fever. However, this condition would typically not cause pain radiating to the back, and there is no direct correlation with alcohol intake.

 

Option C. Acute cholecystitis:

 

  • This is the inflammation of the gallbladder, typically caused by a gallstone blocking the cystic duct. While it does present with abdominal pain, it is usually localized to the right upper quadrant and doesn't usually radiate to the back. Alcohol is not a direct risk factor for cholecystitis.

 

Option D. Hydatid cyst:

 

  • This is a parasitic infection caused by the Echinococcus tapeworm. The cyst can cause abdominal pain, but the presentation and the patient's history of alcoholism do not make it the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic pseudocysts are a common complication of pancreatitis, often presenting as an epigastric lump in patients with a history of alcohol abuse and abdominal pain.

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management? (FMGE JUNE 2021)

 

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

 

  • Warfarin is teratogenic, especially in doses >5 mg, with an 8% risk of warfarin embryopathy.
  • During pregnancy, warfarin should be changed to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, particularly if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day.
  • After 13 weeks, warfarin can be resumed until 36 weeks, at which point it should again be replaced by LMWH.
  • Aspirin may be added for women at very high risk of thrombosis.
  • Heparin is discontinued just before delivery and resumed 6-12 hours after delivery.
  • Warfarin can be restarted postnatally as it is not excreted in breast milk.

 

LMWH has a longer half-life, similar efficacy and safety, and a lower risk of thrombocytopenia and osteoporosis compared to unfractionated heparin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: Although this could be a potential approach, LMWH is preferred due to its longer half-life and lower risk profile.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin is not recommended at 36 weeks of gestation due to the risks associated with warfarin use in late pregnancy, especially around the time of delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: Adding aspirin is only recommended for women at very high risk of thrombosis, which is not specified in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation with a prosthetic valve, warfarin should be replaced with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) due to the risks associated with warfarin use near delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page:321, Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26th edition pg 2405

choices.text: A condensing lens is not required
It is used very close to the patient's eye as possible
A real, inverted image is seen
Magnification is about 15 times

questions.text: Among the statements provided, which one is incorrect regarding the procedure performed using the instrument shown in the image?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A real, inverted image is seen

 

The instrument shown in the above image is a direct ophthalmoscope, and it produces a virtual erect image.

 

Parts of direct Ophthalmoscope

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A condensing lens is not required: This is correct as direct ophthalmoscopy does not require a condensing lens.

 

Option B. It is used very close to the patient's eye as possible: This is correct as direct ophthalmoscopy is performed close to the patient’s eye.

 

Option D. Magnification is about 15 times: This is correct as direct ophthalmoscopy typically provides magnification of around 15 times.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direct ophthalmoscope produces a virtual erect image, not a real inverted image, with about 15 times magnification.

 

Difference between Direct and Indirect Ophthalmoscope

questions.text: A young female has history of a spontaneous abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asherman Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most likely reason for amenorrhoea is Asherman Syndrome
  • In this scenario, normal FSH levels (4–25 IU/L) are found.

 

(FSH levels are high in ovarian dysfunction and low in Sheehan's syndrome and PCOS)

 

  • The endometrium's basal layer can get damaged after a spontaneous abortion. Scarring, fibrous deposition, and uterine synechiae are the results of this.
  • These synechiae can cause hypomenorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility, or recurrent abortions, amongst other symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Sheehan's syndrome: It is a type of pituitary necrosis which occurs as a result of post-partum haemorrhage and is associated with low levels of pituitary hormones. It may be accompanied by amenorrhoea, failure of lactation ,hypothyroidism.

 

Option B. Premature Ovarian failure: Ovarian failure occurring before 40 years of age, characterized by FSH more than 40 mIU/ml

 

Option C. PCOS: Characterized by the presence of 2 of the 3 criteria i.e. oligo/or anovulation, hyperandrogenism and polycystic ovaries on USG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asherman Syndrome is characterized by the formation of intrauterine adhesions following a procedure or spontaneous abortion, leading to normal FSH levels but symptoms such as hypomenorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility, or recurrent miscarriages.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page459

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not pierced during epidural anesthesia? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dura

 

 

For epidural anesthesia, the needle is inserted through several layers before reaching the epidural space, which is just outside the dura mater. The arachnoid mater is a delicate membrane that encloses the cerebrospinal fluid and runs just under the dura mater. In epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured, as this would mean the needle has gone too deep, entering the subarachnoid (intrathecal) space.

 

Layers pierced for Epidural anesthesia (from outside to inside):

 

  1. Skin, subcutaneous tissue
  2. Supraspinous ligament
  3. Interspinous ligament
  4. Ligamentum flavum
  5. Epidural space

 

  • Structures pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture (outside to inside): Skin, subcutaneous fat, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, duramater, arachnoid mater.
  • Last structure to be pierced during epidural anesthesia : Ligamentum flavum
  • Last structure to be pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture: Arachnoid mater

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligamentum Flavum: This is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is the last ligamentous layer that the needle passes through before entering the epidural space.

 

Option C. Supraspinous Ligament: This is a strong, fibrous cord that connects the tips of the spinous processes from the seventh cervical vertebra to the sacrum. This ligament is pierced as the needle progresses towards the epidural space.

 

Option D. Interspinous Ligament: This ligament lies immediately below the supraspinous ligament and connects the adjoining spinous processes to each other. The needle also traverses this ligament as it moves toward the epidural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The arachnoid mater is not punctured during epidural anesthesia; penetration of this layer indicates a breach into the subarachnoid space, which is not the target for an epidural block.

questions.text: A woman has a breast malignancy as shown in image, it is not associated with lymph node metastasis, it is not mobile or attached to the rib, what is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inflammatory breast cancer

 

The image shows Peau d'orange, which involves skin changes including swelling and an orange peel-like texture. This is a classic sign of inflammatory breast cancer (IBC). IBC is an aggressive form of breast cancer that often presents with redness, swelling, and skin thickening, affecting more than one-third of the breast. It is characterized by rapid onset and poor prognosis. The description mentions that the tumor is not mobile and is not attached to the rib, which is consistent with inflammatory breast cancer, as these tumors tend to invade the skin and cause marked changes in the breast appearance and texture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are fibroepithelial tumors of the breast that can be benign or malignant. They typically present as large, fast-growing masses but do not cause the skin changes (like Peau d'orange) seen in inflammatory breast cancer. They usually do not involve the nipple or skin and are often mobile.

 

Option B. Breast abscess: A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, typically due to bacterial infection. It often presents with pain, swelling, redness, and sometimes fever, but it does not typically cause Peau d'orange or the extensive skin changes associated with inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Option D. Leiomyosarcoma: Leiomyosarcoma is a rare malignant tumor of smooth muscle origin. It can occur in the breast but is extremely uncommon. Leiomyosarcoma typically presents as a firm, well-circumscribed mass without the inflammatory changes seen in inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange is a classic sign of inflammatory breast cancer, characterized by rapid onset and poor prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is an abductor of the vocal cord? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only abductor of the vocal cords.

 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is one of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx. It is paired, with one muscle on each side of the larynx.

 

The primary function of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is to abduct (open) the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they pull the arytenoid cartilages (to which the vocal cords are attached) apart, allowing air to flow freely through the glottis (the opening between the vocal cords). This action is crucial for breathing, as it opens the airway and allows for inhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Cricoarytenoid Muscle: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is another intrinsic muscle of the larynx, but its primary function is to adduct (close) the vocal cords. It opposes the action of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. When the lateral cricoarytenoid muscles contract, they bring the arytenoid cartilages closer together, closing the glottis for phonation (voice production).

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoid Muscle (Vocalis): The thyroarytenoid muscle, often referred to as the vocalis muscle, is also an intrinsic laryngeal muscle. It plays a crucial role in phonation (voice production). The thyroarytenoid muscle is involved in controlling the tension of the vocal cords but is not primarily responsible for their abduction or adduction.

 

Option D. Vocalis Muscle: The vocalis muscle is a part of the thyroarytenoid muscle complex and plays a role in adjusting the tension and thickness of the vocal cords during phonation. It is not a primary abductor of the vocal cords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Dr. Mukherjee is evaluating a 40-year-old worker at a healthcare camp for a groundnut processing factory in Hyderabad. The worker reports symptoms of food poisoning after eating stored groundnuts from the factory. Considering the work environment and his symptoms, which contaminant is most likely responsible for his illness? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aflatoxins

 

Aflatoxins are a group of toxins produced by certain fungi, notably Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, which are often found in improperly stored food products like groundnuts. Consumption of groundnuts contaminated with aflatoxins can lead to aflatoxicosis, which presents with symptoms consistent with food poisoning. The setting of a groundnut processing factory and the storage of these nuts increase the likelihood of exposure to aflatoxins, making it the most probable cause of the worker’s condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sanguinarine: This toxin is found in Argemone mexicana and is associated with Epidemic Dropsy, not typically linked with groundnut consumption.

 

Option B. Factory smoke: While smoke might contribute to respiratory issues, it is unlikely to cause symptoms resembling food poisoning.

 

Option C. Beta oxalyl amino alanine: Known as BMAA, this neurotoxin is associated with certain neurological diseases and not with the ingestion of groundnuts.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿In the lumbar region it is in 4 layers
﻿﻿﻿In the thoracic region it is attached medially to the vertebrae
The anterior, posterior and middle layer join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thoracolumbar fascia?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In the lumbar region it is in 4 layers

 

The thoracolumbar fascia is not typically divided into four layers in the lumbar region. It is usually described as having three layers in the lumbar region (Anterior, Posterior, and middle layers).

 

The anterior and posterior layers are thicker and stronger, while the middle layer is thinner.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They contain nociceptive nerve endings: True. The thoracolumbar fascia does contain nociceptive (pain-sensing) nerve endings. These nerve endings contribute to the sensation of pain and discomfort in the lumbar and thoracic regions.

 

Option C. In the thoracic region, it is attached medially to the vertebrae: True. In the thoracic region, the thoracolumbar fascia is attached medially to the vertebral column. It plays a role in providing stability and support to the thoracic spine.

 

Option D. The anterior, posterior, and middle layer join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis: True. The anterior, posterior, and middle layers of the thoracolumbar fascia converge and blend together to form an aponeurotic sheet. This aponeurosis is a broad, flat tendon-like structure that serves as the origin for the transversus abdominis muscle, among other muscles. It contributes to the abdominal wall's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the lumbar region, the fascia consists of 3 layers-anterior, middle and posterior. The thoracolumbar fascia is a complex arrangement of multiple fascial layers in the thoracolumbar region. This fascia encloses the paraspinal muscles, quadratus lumborum muscle, and the latissimus dorsi muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following defects is associated with the use of Lithium during pregnancy?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ebstein’s anomaly

 

Lithium use during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart defects, particularly Ebstein’s anomaly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cleft palate: While many teratogens can contribute to cleft palate, lithium is not typically associated with it.

 

Option B. Neural tube defect: Some antiepileptic drugs (like valproic acid) increase the risk of neural tube defects, not lithium.

 

Option D. Phocomelia: This limb abnormality is classically associated with thalidomide use during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mood stabilizers, such as lithium, valproic acid, and carbamazepine, have potentially teratogenic effects. Lithium is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart defects, notably Ebstein's anomaly. Valproic acid can lead to neural tube defects, and carbamazepine has been linked to neural tube defects and craniofacial abnormalities. Valproate is the most teratogenic of all the mood stabilizers.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 653

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly labelled here?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C-Subscapular artery

 

The option marked C is wrongly labelled as it is the brachial artery and not subscapular artery.

 

The brachial artery is a continuation of the axillary artery in the arm and is responsible for supplying blood to the muscles of the upper arm and forearm

 

The axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by the pectoralis minor muscle.

 

In the above given diagram, the numbers represent the following structures:

 

  1. First part of axillary artery
  2. Second part of axillary artery
  3. Third part of axillary artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A- Superior Thoracic Artery: The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the axillary artery. It travels superiorly and medially, supplying the first and second intercostal spaces, along with some branches to the serratus anterior muscle. Functionally, the superior thoracic artery provides blood to the upper part of the chest wall and the serratus anterior muscle.

 

Option B. B- Thoracoacromial Artery: The thoracoacromial artery is another branch of the axillary artery. It is a short artery that quickly divides into several branches, including the clavicular, acromial, deltoid, and pectoral branches. The thoracoacromial artery supplies blood to various muscles and structures in the shoulder region and the upper chest wall.

 

Option D. D- Posterior Circumflex Artery, Brachial Artery: The posterior circumflex artery is a branch of the axillary artery that travels around the surgical neck of the humerus. It participates in the blood supply of the shoulder joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subscapular artery is one of the larger branches of the axillary artery. It runs along the posterior wall of the axilla and supplies the subscapularis muscle and other structures in the axillary region. This artery also gives rise to the circumflex scapular artery, which provides blood to the scapula and surrounding muscles.

choices.text: Pleural fluid protein 4.5 gm% and LDH 200
Pleural fluid protein 4.5 gm% and glucose 30mg%
Pleural fluid LDH 90IU and glucose 60mg%
Pleural fluid protein 3.5gm% and glucose 90 mg%

questions.text:
Which of the following findings from a pleural fluid aspirate will suggest an exudative pleural effusion? (FMGE JUNE 2021)

 

Normal values obtained from lab:

 

Total S. Protein: 6-8 g/dL,

 

S. LDH: 140-280 IU/L,

 

S. glucose: 140-200 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pleural fluid protein 4.5 gm% and LDH 200

 

To determine if a pleural effusion is exudative, we use Light's criteria, which compares the pleural fluid and serum levels of protein and LDH. According to Light's criteria, a pleural effusion is classified as exudative if at least one of the following conditions is met:

 

  1. The ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5/ 50%.
  2. The ratio of pleural fluid LDH to serum LDH is greater than 0.6/ 60%.
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.

 

Let's apply Light's criteria to option A:

 

  • Pleural fluid protein 4.5 gm% compared to the serum protein range (6-8 g/dL) results in a ratio of approximately 0.75, which is greater than 0.5.
  • Pleural fluid LDH 200 compared to the serum LDH range (140-280 IU/L) results in a ratio that fits within the criteria as well. If the upper limit is 280, two-thirds of 280 is approximately 186.7. Therefore, an LDH level of 200 exceeds this threshold.

 

Thus, option A meets Light's criteria for an exudative pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pleural fluid protein 4.5 gm% and glucose 30mg%: While the protein level meets Light's criteria, glucose is not part of Light's criteria for determining exudative effusion.

 

Option C. Pleural fluid LDH 90IU and glucose 60mg%: The LDH level does not meet the criteria as it is less than two-thirds of the upper limit of serum LDH.

 

Option D. Pleural fluid protein 3.5gm% and glucose 90 mg%: While glucose is low, the protein ratio might not meet the criteria as it is less clearly exudative compared to option A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exudative pleural effusions are identified using Light's criteria, focusing on the ratios of pleural fluid to serum protein and LDH levels.

choices.text: Maturity onset Diabetes of the young
Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL and thus she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146mg/dL and HbA1c was 7.6%. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overt diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

  • The following are the lab results that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother:
    • Fasting blood sugar at least 126 mg/dL
    • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
    • HbA1c of at least 6.5%
  • Pregnant women with overt diabetes are more likely to have fetuses with congenital abnormalities.
  • Gestational diabetes mellitus is usually diagnosed between 24-28 weeks and is diagnosed by an oral glucose tolerance test.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Maturity onset Diabetes of the young (MODY): MODY is a rare form of diabetes that is different from overt diabetes. It usually presents before the age of 25 and is due to a genetic mutation. The patient's age and lab results are more consistent with overt diabetes.

 

Option C. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM): GDM is usually diagnosed between 24-28 weeks of gestation using an oral glucose tolerance test. The patient’s high fasting and random blood glucose levels and HbA1c indicate overt diabetes, not GDM.

 

Option D. Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA): LADA is a form of type 1 diabetes that occurs in adults. It is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies and slower progression to insulin dependence. The patient's lab results are more indicative of overt diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar of at least 126 mg/dL, a random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL, or an HbA1c of at least 6.5%.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 327

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a traditional principle of Primary Health Care? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Universal health coverage

 

Universal Health Coverage (UHC) is not considered a traditional principle of Primary Health Care as defined by the initial concepts laid out in the Alma-Ata Declaration of 1978. While UHC is a broader goal that encompasses access to necessary health services without financial hardship, it encompasses more than just the primary care level and aims at a wider system-level integration which includes secondary and tertiary care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appropriate technologies: This is a traditional principle of PHC, emphasizing the use of scientifically sound, yet socially acceptable and affordable technology in health care.

 

Option B. Community participation: Fundamental to PHC, this principle stresses the involvement of community members in planning and implementing health care strategies.

 

Option C. Intersectoral coordination: Also a core principle, it highlights the importance of collaboration among various sectors to promote health beyond traditional health care settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principles of Primary Health care are:

 

  • Equitable Distribution
  • Community Participation
  • Intersectoral Coordination
  • Appropriate Technology

 

Additional Information

 

Primary health care concept
 

  • Background: One year after the World Health Assembly stated its “Health for All” goal, WHO came up with the concept of primary health care at Alma-Ata Conference, USSR, in 1978
  • Broad principles: Social equity, National coverage, Selfreliance and Inter-sectoral coordination
  • Aim: To put the people’s health in the people’s hand
  • Definition: Essential health care based on practical, scientifically sound and socially acceptable methods and technology made universally accessible to individuals and families in the community through their full participation and at a cost that the community and the country can afford to maintain at every stage of their development in the spirit of self-reliance and self-determination
  • Hallmarks of Primary health care: 4 A’s
    • Affordability
    • Acceptability
    • Accessibility   
    • Availability
  • 8 essential ELEMENTS/components of Primary Health Care (as outlined by the ‘Alma-Ata Declaration, 1978’):
    • E: Essential drugs
    • L: Locally endemic diseases prevention and control
    • E: Education concerning health problems and their control 
    • M: Maternal and child health care including family planning
    • E: EPI (Immunization) against Vaccine Preventable Diseases
    • N: Nutrition and promoting proper food supply
    • T: Treatment of common diseases and injuries
    • S: Safe water supply and sanitation

questions.text: A patient presents with spoon shaped nails. What is the underlying cause of this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

  • Iron deficiency anemia is most common type of anemia — a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Red blood cells carry oxygen to the body’s tissues.
  • As the name suggests, iron deficiency anemia is due to insufficient iron. Without enough iron, your body can’t produce enough of a substance in red blood cells that enables them to carry oxygen (hemoglobin). As a result, iron deficiency anemia may leave you tired and short of breath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia is due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, leading to large red blood cells. It does not typically cause spoon-shaped nails.

 

Option B. Chronic renal disease: This condition can lead to anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production but is not directly associated with spoon-shaped nails.

 

Option C. Chronic liver disease: Liver disease can cause various systemic symptoms and nail changes, but spoon-shaped nails are specifically linked to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spoon-shaped nails (koilonychia) are indicative of iron deficiency anemia, the most common type of anemia due to insufficient iron for hemoglobin production.

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency in a comatose state. On examination, his serum glucose levels were found to be 500 mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.33, and increased plasma ketones levels. His serum potassium levels are normal. What should be added to saline for this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insulin

 

The patient's presentation is indicative of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), characterized by hyperglycemia (serum glucose of 500 mg/dL), metabolic acidosis (arterial pH of 7.33), and elevated ketone levels. The treatment of DKA involves several critical steps (FLIP therapy):

 

  1. Fluid Replacement: Initially, isotonic saline (0.9% NaCl) is used to correct dehydration.
  2. Insulin Therapy: Insulin is the most crucial component of DKA treatment as it helps to reduce blood glucose levels and stops further ketone production. Regular insulin is typically administered via continuous intravenous infusion.
  3. Potassium Management: Despite normal serum potassium levels at presentation, insulin therapy can cause hypokalemia as potassium shifts into cells. Thus, potassium levels must be monitored closely and supplemented as needed.
  4. Bicarbonate Therapy: Bicarbonate is only indicated in severe acidosis (pH < 6.9).
  5. Phosphorus: Phosphorus replacement is considered if there is severe hypophosphatemia, which is not indicated in this patient.

 

Given the information, the most critical immediate treatment to add to saline is insulin to manage hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bicarbonate: Not indicated unless there is severe acidosis with pH < 6.9.

 

Option C. Phosphorus: Not routinely needed unless severe hypophosphatemia is present.

 

Option D. 10% dextrose: Used later in the treatment when blood glucose levels fall below 250 mg/dL to prevent hypoglycemia while continuing insulin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis, insulin is essential to resolve hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. Fluids are crucial for rehydration, and potassium levels must be monitored and managed during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions leads to wing beating tremors? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson's disease

 

Wing beating tremors, also known as asterixis, are a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease. This condition is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that leads to the accumulation of copper in various tissues, including the liver and brain. The neurological manifestations of Wilson's disease include movement disorders such as tremors, dystonia, and dysarthria.

 

Wing beating tremors: These are best seen when the patient holds their arms outstretched and attempts to keep their wrists extended. The tremors resemble a bird flapping its wings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington's chorea: This genetic disorder leads to progressive neurodegeneration, primarily affecting movement (chorea), cognitive function, and psychiatric symptoms. It does not typically present with wing beating tremors.

 

Option C. Parkinsonism: This group of disorders, including Parkinson's disease, is characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability. The tremors in Parkinsonism are usually resting tremors, not wing beating tremors.

 

Option D. Sydenham's chorea: This condition is a complication of rheumatic fever and is characterized by rapid, involuntary movements affecting all parts of the body (chorea). It does not present with wing beating tremors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wing beating tremors are a hallmark of Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism. Recognizing this unique clinical sign is essential for diagnosing and managing the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest symptom of alcohol withdrawal? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tremors

 

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms follow a predictable pattern after abrupt cessation or significant reduction in alcohol consumption in someone with alcohol dependence.

 

Tremors: These are the earliest and most common symptoms, starting as early as 6 hours to 8 hours after the last drink. They are characterized by "shaky hands" and can progress to involve other body parts.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Hallucinations: These can occur within 12-24 hours after the last drink. They are usually visual but can also be auditory or tactile.

 

Option C. Seizure: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures can occur within 24-48 hours after the last drink.

 

Option D. Delirium: Delirium tremens (DT) is the most severe form of withdrawal and begins 48-72 hours after the last drink. It's characterized by altered mental status, agitation, fever, and autonomic instability.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tremors are the earliest symptom of alcohol withdrawal, typically appearing 6-8 hours after the cessation of drinking, followed in sequence by hallucinations (12-24 hours), seizures (24-48 hours), and delirium tremens (48-72 hours).

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, type B tympanogram is seen? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Serous otitis media

 

Type B tympanogram is seen with serous otitis media.

 

Type B tympanogram is characterized by a flat response, indicating no change in compliance as air pressure is varied in the external ear canal. This pattern typically suggests the presence of fluid in the middle ear without any significant air pocket, which is commonly associated with serous otitis media. This condition leads to the accumulation of non-infected fluid in the middle ear, which impedes the normal movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ossicular dislocation: Typically leads to a type Ad tympanogram, which shows very high compliance due to the disconnection between the ossicles.

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: More often associated with a type As tympanogram, where there is reduced mobility of the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to lower compliance at ambient air pressure.

 

Option D. Normal ear: Should display a type A tympanogram, where compliance peaks at or near ambient pressure, indicating normal mobility of the middle ear system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 27

questions.text: Which among the following is the longest acting PDE-inhibitor? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tadalafil

 

Tadalafil is recognized as the longest-acting phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor, used primarily in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (ED), benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Tadalafil can remain active for up to 36 hours, allowing for greater spontaneity and less planning for doses compared to its counterparts. Its mechanism involves the inhibition of PDE5, which enhances the effects of nitric oxide (NO) released during sexual stimulation. NO activates guanylate cyclase to increase levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), leading to smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow to the penis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sildenafil: This was the first PDE5 inhibitor approved for the treatment of ED. It has a shorter duration of action compared to tadalafil, typically lasting about 4 to 6 hours. Sildenafil can also inhibit PDE6, which is found in the retina, occasionally causing side effects such as changes in color vision (blue-tinted vision).

 

Option B. Vardenafil: Similar to sildenafil in duration, vardenafil acts for about 4 to 5 hours. It is somewhat more selective than sildenafil but can also cause visual disturbances as a side effect.

 

Option D. Avanafil: The newest of the listed PDE5 inhibitors, avanafil has a rapid onset of action and lasts approximately 6 hours. It is designed to have fewer side effects but still acts similarly by enhancing the effects of NO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tadalafil is the longest-acting PDE5 inhibitor available, making it a preferred option for patients seeking longer duration of efficacy for managing erectile dysfunction, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Its longer action allows for less frequent dosing and can contribute to a better overall quality of life in patients requiring PDE5 inhibitors.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given X-ray? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perforation peritonitis

 

The correct answer is B. Perforation peritonitis. The above image shows free gas under diaphragm which indicates pneumoperitoneum. It is caused by perforation peritonitis.

 

When this happens, contents from the intestines can spill into the abdominal cavity, leading to infection and inflammation. On an X-ray, this can present as free air or gas under the diaphragm, indicating pneumoperitoneum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pleural effusion:

 

 

On an X-ray, it may appear as a white area (because fluid is denser than air) at the base of the lung and can obliterate the costophrenic angles.

 

Option C. Sigmoid volvulus:

 

 

This condition occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on itself (volvulus). On an X-ray, it often shows a distinctive "coffee bean" sign due to the shape of the twisted colon. There won't typically be free gas under the diaphragm unless there's a complication like bowel perforation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction:

 

 

On an X-ray, multiple air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern may be observed in upright films. Again, free gas under the diaphragm would only be seen if there was a complication such as bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray indicates pneumoperitoneum, which is a hallmark sign of perforation peritonitis and necessitates urgent medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (choriocarcinoma): This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history and presenting symptoms. Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic disease that can arise following a molar pregnancy. The persistent elevation of beta-hCG levels, abdominal pain, distention, and the presence of cannonball foci on the chest X-ray (indicative of lung metastases) are characteristic findings of choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, leading to pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. It does not typically cause elevated beta-hCG levels or cannonball lesions in the lungs, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Ovarian cyst: Ovarian cysts can cause abdominal pain and distention, but they do not typically cause persistent elevation of beta-hCG levels or lung metastases. This diagnosis does not fit the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Asherman's syndrome: Asherman's syndrome, characterized by intrauterine adhesions, usually results from trauma to the endometrial lining, such as after dilatation and curettage. It can lead to amenorrhea or menstrual irregularities but is not associated with elevated beta-hCG levels or lung metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (choriocarcinoma) should be suspected in patients with a history of molar pregnancy who present with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels, abdominal symptoms, and lung metastases (cannonball lesions on chest X-ray).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 363

questions.text: Which of the following is specifically found in gram-negative bacteria? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lipopolysaccharides

 

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are unique to the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria. They are not found in gram-positive bacteria. LPS is a crucial component of the gram-negative bacterial cell wall, contributing to the structural integrity of the bacteria and protecting the membrane from certain kinds of chemical attacks. It is also an endotoxin and can trigger strong immune responses in animals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capsule:

 

  • Capsules can be found in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. They are a polysaccharide layer that lies outside the cell envelope and provides protection to the bacteria.

 

Option B. Peptidoglycan:

 

  • Peptidoglycan is present in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, though it is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria. It provides structural strength to the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option D. Flagella:

 

  • Flagella are found in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria and are used for locomotion. They are not specific to either type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are specific to gram-negative bacteria and form a significant part of their outer membrane, playing a critical role in the bacteria's structural integrity and immune system interactions.

questions.text: Dr. Raghav, the Chief Medical Officer at Apex Urban Hospital, is addressing issues related to patient wait times and the duration of consultations in the outpatient department. He wants to gather accurate data on how much time doctors spend with each patient to determine if adjustments in staffing or training are needed. Which management technique is most suitable for measuring the actual time doctors spend on patient consultations? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Work Sampling

 

Work Sampling: Systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals, carried out at pre-determined or random intervals. It provides quantitative measurement of various activities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Model: While models can represent systems or situations, they might not give the real-time, actionable data needed to address the specific concern of doctor-patient interaction time.

 

Option B. Systems Analysis: Is a management technique of finding out the cost-effectiveness of the available alternatives

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Is the graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Implementing Work Sampling will enable the hospital to precisely evaluate and adjust the time allocated for each patient consultation, enhancing efficiency and patient satisfaction.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of seizure and its medication is incorrect? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Typical absence seizures: Topiramate

 

Typical absence seizures are primarily treated with ethosuximide, which is the drug of choice. Valproate is also an option but is more commonly used for atypical absence seizures.

 

Topiramate is not typically used for treating absence seizures, making the combination of "Typical absence seizures: Topiramate" incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized-Onset Tonic-Clonic: Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is an appropriate and commonly used medication for generalized-onset tonic-clonic seizures. It is effective in managing this type of seizure.

 

Option B. Focal seizures: Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is a suitable medication for focal seizures. It is often used as a first-line or adjunctive therapy for this type of seizure.

 

Option D. Myoclonic: Valproic acid: Valproic acid is an appropriate treatment for myoclonic seizures. It is one of the first-line treatments for this type of generalized seizure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typical absence seizures should be treated with ethosuximide as the drug of choice.

questions.text: The first primary tooth to erupt is: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lower central incisor

 

The first primary tooth to erupt in infants is the lower central incisor, typically appearing around 6 months of age (5-7 months). The eruption of primary teeth follows a specific sequence, which is essential for pediatric healthcare providers to monitor for any deviations that could indicate underlying health issues.

 

  • Sequence of Primary Teeth Eruption:
    1. Lower central incisors: 6 to 10 months
    2. Upper central incisors: 8 to 12 months
    3. Upper lateral incisors: 9 to 13 months
    4. Lower lateral incisors: 10 to 16 months
    5. First molars: 13 to 19 months
    6. Canines or cuspids: 16 to 23 months
    7. Second molars: 23 to 33 months

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper central incisor: These teeth typically erupt after the lower central incisors, around 8 to 12 months of age.

 

Option C. Upper canine: Upper canines usually erupt between 16 to 23 months of age, much later than the lower central incisors.

 

Option D. Lower canine: Lower canines also erupt later, between 16 to 23 months of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first primary tooth to erupt in infants is the lower central incisor, typically appearing around 6 months of age. The sequence of primary teeth eruption is an essential part of pediatric growth and development monitoring.

questions.text: A worker in the wheat section of a food facility eats peanuts regularly and develops hepatic carcinoma after many years. Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of his condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aflatoxin

 

Aflatoxins are a family of toxins produced by certain fungi that are found on agricultural crops such as maize (corn), peanuts, cottonseed, and tree nuts.

 

Aflatoxins are one of the most potent and dangerous groups of mycotoxins worldwide.

 

Over four billion people in developing countries are repeatedly exposed to aflatoxins, contributing to greater than 40 percent of the disease burden in these countries. Aflatoxins are produced primarily by the fungi Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus. There are four main types of aflatoxins: B1, B2, G1, and G2. Aflatoxin B1 is the major toxin produced. The clinical effects of aflatoxins may include death, liver cancer, reproductive problems, anemia, immune system suppression, and jaundice. Nursing animals may be severely affected by a toxic derivative of aflatoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Industrial toxins: Can cause various health problems but not specifically associated with hepatic carcinoma due to aflatoxin exposure.

 

Option C. Phytotoxins: Plant-derived toxins, not specifically linked to hepatic carcinoma.

 

Option D. Aniline: A chemical compound used in industrial applications, not linked to hepatic carcinoma due to aflatoxin exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aflatoxins, produced by Aspergillus species on crops like peanuts, are potent mycotoxins that can lead to hepatic carcinoma after prolonged exposure.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has flexible fingers and can even touch the back of his hand with his wrist extended. The child also demonstrates the sign shown in the image below. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

 

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, and a tendency to bruise easily. The presence of flexible fingers, the ability to touch the back of the hand with the wrist extended, and the demonstration of the Gorlin sign (touching the tip of the nose with the tongue) are indicative of EDS. Additionally, the auscultation findings of a click after S1 followed by a late systolic murmur are consistent with mitral valve prolapse with MR, which is commonly associated with EDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marfan’s Syndrome: Marfan syndrome also involves connective tissue abnormalities, but it is characterized by tall stature, arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers), scoliosis, and pectus deformities. Aortic root dilation is also common in Marfan syndrome. The absence of these skeletal features and the presence of the Gorlin sign make Marfan syndrome less likely.

 

Option C. Loeys-Dietz Syndrome: This syndrome is associated with vascular aneurysms, hypertelorism, and bifid uvula or cleft palate. The typical triad of Loeys-Dietz syndrome is not present in this case.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: This condition is known for brittle bones and recurrent fractures, often referred to as "brittle bone disease." Patients typically have blue sclerae. These features are not mentioned in the case, making osteogenesis imperfecta an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome presents with hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, and other features such as mitral valve prolapse and the ability to perform the Gorlin sign. Recognizing these clinical signs can aid in the diagnosis of this connective tissue disorder.

questions.text: During a discussion on demographic transitions and economic impacts, a scholar inquired about the term for a change in age composition that leads to an increase in the number of working-age individuals relative to dependents. What is this phenomenon called? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decrease in dependency ratio

 

When we have a higher number of economically productive population, it is called as a demographic bonus. It is achieved when we can see a decline in the dependency ratio.

 

Demographic bonus is a condition in which the productive age population is more than the non-productive population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in the dependency ratio indicates a demographic shift towards a greater proportion of working-age individuals, which can significantly benefit the economy by increasing the labor force and reducing the relative number of dependents.

questions.text: What is the site of maximum pain in acute appendicitis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McBurney’s point

 

In acute appendicitis, the site of maximum tenderness is at McBurney’s point. This point is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the umbilicus. McBurney’s point corresponds to the base of the appendix. Initially, the pain of acute appendicitis typically begins in the periumbilical region due to visceral innervation and then migrates to McBurney’s point as inflammation progresses and the parietal peritoneum becomes involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flank: Pain in the flank is more commonly associated with conditions affecting the kidneys, such as renal colic or pyelonephritis. It is not the typical site of maximum pain in acute appendicitis.

 

Option C. Right upper abdomen: Pain in the right upper abdomen is typically associated with conditions affecting the liver or gallbladder, such as cholecystitis or hepatitis. It is not the usual location of pain for acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Umbilicus: While pain in acute appendicitis initially occurs in the periumbilical region due to visceral pain, it later localizes to McBurney’s point as the inflammation progresses. The umbilicus is not the site of maximum tenderness in acute appendicitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The site of maximum tenderness in acute appendicitis is at McBurney’s point, which corresponds to the base of the appendix.

 

MCBURNEY’S POINT CORRESPONDS TO THE BASE OF THE APPENDIX

questions.text: A worker with a 30-year tenure in the sugarcane industry presents with symptoms of breathlessness and cough. Chest X-rays reveal mottling in the lungs. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bagasossis

 

Bagassosis is an airborne disease caused by inhalation of the fibrous cane-sugar residue, bagasse.

 

H/O working in sugarcane industry supports the diagnosis.

 

Bagasse dust blocks bronchioles thus leading to bronchitis and bronchopneumonia. It has been shown to be due to Thermoactinomyces sacchari. 

 

Prevention and Bagasse control measures are Keeping the moisture content > 20% and Spraying bagasse with 2% propionic acid (fungicide). 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs due to: Exposure to asbestos dust.  Asbestosis does not usually appear until after 5-10 years of exposure. Sputum shows ‘asbestos bodies’, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin. Lung show “Ground glass appearance” on chest X-ray. 

 

Asbestos may lead to pulmonary fibrosis, carcinoma of bronchus, mesothelioma of peritoneum/pleura and cancer of GIT. Asbestos type most dangerous is ‘amphibole’.

 

Option C. Byssinosis: Caused by inhalation of cotton dust, leading to chest tightness and breathlessness. Monday fever/ Monday sickness is associated with Byssinosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconioses:

 

 

Antigens involved in Pneumoconioses:

questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the following X-ray of a newborn with respiratory distress: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia

 

The X ray showing the features of Bowel gas shadows in the thorax on this X-ray due to bowel herniation caused by a diaphragm defect and is seen in case of Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia.

 

The most common type of it is Bochdalek hernia.

 

It is due to the pleuroperitoneal membrane defect in the Posterolateral aspect.

 

Whereas Morgagni hernia is due to the Anterior pleuroperitoneal membrane defect.

 

Pathophysiology and cause

 

  • Cause is unknown
  • Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing embryo Abdominal contents herniate and compress the ipsilateral developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension.

 

Types of congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Mild to severe respiratory distress
  • Tachypnea, cyanosis, dyspnea
  • Absent breath sound.
  • Shock.

 

Three general presentations: Severe respiratory distress Severe respiratory distress at the time of birth. (Severe hypoplasia) Respiratory deterioration hours after delivery (honeymoon period).

 

Benefit from correction of hypoxemia and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Diagnosis: Therapeutic Symptoms Radiographic study.

 

Prenatally as early as 25 weeks of gestation.

 

Therapeutic: The first stages in treatment are the insertion of an orogastric tube and the preservation of the airway (intubation).

 

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used as part of the treatment strategy on occasion; normally, the newborn would be placed on a ventilator right away.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Tracheoesophageal fistula involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus. It usually presents with choking, coughing, and cyanosis with feeding. The X-ray may show air in the stomach and intestines but not bowel gas shadows in the thorax.

 

Option C. Hiatal Hernia: Hiatal hernia involves the herniation of the stomach into the thorax through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm. It usually presents with gastroesophageal reflux symptoms and not with the bowel gas shadows seen in CDH.

 

Option D. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): CCAM is a developmental lung abnormality characterized by the formation of cysts or masses of abnormal lung tissue. It presents with respiratory distress but appears as cystic or solid masses on imaging, not bowel gas shadows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is identified on X-ray by bowel gas shadows in the thorax, which indicates herniation of abdominal contents through a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition – Page No- 3855-3856

questions.text: A stain is found on the clothes of a kidnapper. It is treated with picric acid and studied under a microscope which shows yellow color needle shaped crystals. What could the stain be? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Semen

 

The above scenario explains the process of Barberio test that is done to identify seminal stain.

 

Barberio's test: A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to dried stain extract on a glass slide covered with a coverslip, produces yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate. The reaction depends on the presence of spermine from prostatic secretions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sputum: Does not produce yellow needle-shaped crystals with picric acid.

 

Option C. Blood: Hemin (Teichmann’s) test or Hemochromogen (Takayama) test are used for blood stains, producing different crystals.

 

Option D. CSF (Cerebrospinal Fluid): Does not produce yellow needle-shaped crystals with picric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals when a stain is treated with picric acid and examined under a microscope indicates a seminal stain, identified using the Barberio test.

 

Additional Information

 

Tests for seminal stains

 

1) Presumptive test for semina stains:

 

a) Fluorescence under UV light

b) Microchemical tests: ﻿﻿Florence test and ﻿Barberio's test

 

Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals) 

 

 

 

2) Confirmatory Tests for Semen

 

  • Detection of complete sperm under the microscope (Best test)﻿﻿
  • Acid phosphatase test (second best test): It is produced by prostate gland. Acid phosphatase enzyme is present in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids
  • ﻿﻿Creatine phosphokinase test: It is a component of Spermatozoa.
  • Prostate specific antigen

questions.text: A radiological assessment of a pregnant woman reveals an anteroposterior oval-shaped pelvic inlet. According to Caldwell and Molloy’s classification, this shape of pelvic inlet is commonly associated with: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthropoid pelvis

 

  • According to Caldwell and Molloy’s classification, an anteroposterior oval-shaped pelvic inlet is associated with the anthropoid pelvis. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipito-posterior positions during labor.
  • Anthropoid pelvis: This type is characterized by an anteroposterior oval shape and is often associated with posterior fetal positions.
  • Gynecoid pelvis: The typical female pelvis, which is round and associated with uncomplicated labor progression.
  • Android pelvis: A male-shaped pelvis that is heart-shaped and associated with obstructed labor.
  • Platypelloid pelvis: A flat pelvis with a transverse oval shape, associated with delayed engagement and asynclitism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Android pelvis: The android pelvis has a heart-shaped or triangular inlet. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor due to its narrow shape and is not characterized by an anteroposterior oval shape.

 

Option C. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the most common type of female pelvis, with a rounded inlet and is typically associated with uncomplicated labor. It does not have an anteroposterior oval shape.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a flat, transverse oval inlet. This type is associated with delayed engagement and asynclitism during labor, but not with an anteroposterior oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anteroposterior oval-shaped pelvic inlet is associated with the anthropoid pelvis, which is commonly linked with occipito-posterior fetal positions during labor.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, Williams textbook of Obstetrics page 34

questions.text: Mr. Sharma, a farmer in Bihar, inquires about the Ayushman Bharat scheme at a local health center, interested particularly in the insurance benefits it provides. Dr. Verma, leading the center, outlines the yearly financial support available per family under the scheme. What is the annual insurance limit per family provided by Ayushman Bharat? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rs. 5 Lac/Family/Year

 

The Ayushman Bharat program, also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana, offers an insurance package limit of up to Rs. 5 lakh per family per year. This coverage is designed to ensure that there is no financial burden on families when accessing necessary medical services, including hospitalization. The scheme covers a wide array of medical conditions without any restrictions on family size, age of members, or type of illness, making it highly inclusive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayushman Bharat

 

  • Main Aim: To provide a service to create a healthy, capable and content new India 
  • Goals:
    • Create a network of health, wellness infrastructure delivering comprehensive primary healthcare services
    • Provide insurance cover to > 40% population deprived of secondary & tertiary care services
  • Beneficiaries Criteria:
    • Rural areas: Based on the deprivation categories (D1, D2, D3, D4, D5, D7) under the SECC database
    • Urban areas: 11 occupational criteria
    • RSBY beneficiaries in states where it is active
  • Hospitalization Process:
    • No charges/premium for hospitalisation expenses
    • Include Pre- and Post-hospitalisation expenses
    • ‘Ayushman Mitra’ in each hospital to assist patients
  • Hospital Eligibility:
    • All public hospitals
    • Empanelled private health care facilities
    • Empanelment criteria: Hospital with > 10 beds

questions.text: All of the following are seen in panic attacks except? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicide attempt

 

Panic attacks are acute, intense episodes of fear and discomfort that peak within minutes. Common symptoms include palpitations, sweating, trembling, sensations of shortness of breath, and feelings of impending doom (Option D). They can be described as episodic (Option C), occurring suddenly and without warning, often without a clear trigger (Option B).

 

Suicide attempts (Option A) are not a characteristic feature of panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Panic attack is an acute attack of intense anxiety accompanied by “feeling of impending doom”. The symptoms during panic attack involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and derealization or depersonalization with fear of dying, losing control or going mad. Treatment includes both SSRIs and benzodiazepines with CBT.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402

choices.text: Mallory Weiss tear
Duodenal ulcer perforation

questions.text: A young male passed his exam and went for a party where he had 10 beers. After this binge drinking episode, he presented with vomiting and upper Gl bleed. Most Likely cause is?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mallory Weiss tear

 

In Mallory Weiss syndrome, repeated vomiting produces a vertical split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia in 90% of the cases. In only 10% of the cases the tear is in the esophagus. Mallory Weiss tear occurs just below GE junction, partial tear involving mucosa and submucosa, with rupture of submucosal veins. Patient presents with painless hematemesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Boerhaave Syndrome is the rupture of the posterior wall of the lower esophagus. It occurs due to continuous retching and emesis with incomplete cricopharyngeal relaxation. The abdominal contents go into the mediastinum and give rise to constellation of symptoms like Vomiting, Retrosternal Chest Pain and subcutaneous emphysema. This is called as Mackler’s triad.

 

Option C. Most commonly, duodenal ulcer perforates on the anterior wall causing pneumoperitoneum; The patient has symptoms of peritonitis (severe abdominal pain with guarding and rigidity). If it perforates on the posterior wall, it involves erosion of the gastroduodenal artery leading to hematemesis.

 

Option D. Tension Pneumothorax doesn’t present with Upper GI bleed. It presents with respiratory distress. On clinical examination, there is hyper-resonance on the affected side on percussion and reduced air entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mallory-Weiss tear is associated with painless hematemesis following forceful vomiting, commonly linked to alcohol binge drinking. It involves a mucosal tear near the gastroesophageal junction.

choices.text: Chronic myeloid leukemia
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Acute myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: A child presented with history of pallor with fatigue, petechial bleeding and fever since last 7 days. On examination he was having enlargement of liver and spleen with sternal tenderness. Which of the following is the likely explanation for the symptoms in the child? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow — the spongy tissue inside Bones where blood cells are made. The word “acute” in acute lymphocytic leukemia comes from the fact that the Disease progresses rapidly and creates immature blood cells, rather than mature ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Characterized by pancytopenia (deficiency of all types of blood cells) and does not typically cause hepatosplenomegaly or sternal tenderness.

 

Option B. Chronic myeloid leukemia: More common in adults and presents with marked leukocytosis and splenomegaly but is not common in children.

 

Option D. Acute myelogenous leukemia: While it can present similarly, ALL is more common in children and better fits the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is characterized by rapid progression and the creation of immature blood cells, leading to symptoms such as pallor, fatigue, petechial bleeding, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and sternal tenderness in children.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the emergency management of asthma does not act by bronchodilation? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hydrocortisone

 

Hydrocortisone acts in an acute attack of bronchial asthma by producing anti-inflammatory effect, by decreasing the mucous secretion and by increasing the responsiveness of the β2 receptors to their agonists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salbutamol: It acts as an agonist at beta-2 receptors which causes bronchodilation.

 

Option B. Ipratropium: It acts as a muscarinic agonist at M3 receptors which antagonize smooth muscle contraction, thereby leading to bronchodilation.

 

Option C. Deriphylline: Is a non-specific phosphodiesterase inhibitor like Theophylline. It increases the effects of steroids by activating histone deacetylase. Increased cAMP levels cause bronchodilation, improved airflow and reduced airway resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the emergency management of asthma, while most treatments focus on bronchodilation to relieve symptoms, Hydrocortisone is used primarily for its anti-inflammatory properties. Understanding the different mechanisms of these drugs is crucial for optimizing acute asthma management and ensuring effective relief from an asthma attack.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for ear pain after a tonsillectomy surgery?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as cranial nerve IX, plays a significant role in causing referred otalgia following a tonsillectomy. It innervates both the tonsils and the tonsillar fossa. Consequently, any irritation or discomfort in this area can be perceived in the ear through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also referred to as Jacobson's nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve: Mainly responsible for motor functions of the facial muscles, taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and does not typically cause ear pain related to tonsillectomy.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve: While it does innervate parts of the face and has branches that reach to the ear, it is not primarily involved in pain associated with tonsil conditions.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve: It has extensive functions related to autonomic control of the viscera but is not directly involved in causing ear pain following tonsillectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is primarily responsible for ear pain following a tonsillectomy, a phenomenon known as referred otalgia. This nerve has a complex sensory innervation that includes the mucosa of the tonsils, part of the pharynx, and the middle ear through the tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 143

questions.text: In a discussion on cancer trends in India, the topic of the most common type of cancer among Indian males is brought up. Based on recent data, which type of cancer is most frequently diagnosed in this demographic? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lip and oral cavity

 

Lip and oral cavity cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer among Indian males, primarily due to high rates of tobacco consumption (both smoked and smokeless), alcohol use, and specific dietary habits unique to the region. This type of cancer's prevalence is notably higher in India compared to many other parts of the world, highlighting the need for specific public health interventions aimed at these risk factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to reports by Globocon 2020, leading causes of cancer in males in India are:

 

  1. Lip, Oral cavity
  2. Lung
  3. Stomach
  4. Colorectal
  5. Esophagus

 

According to reports by Globocon 2020, leading causes of cancer in females in India are:

 

  1. Breast
  2. Cervix and uterus
  3. Ovary
  4. Lip, oral cavity
  5. Colorectal

choices.text: Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis
Rheumatic heart disease

questions.text: A female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetations on either side of the heart valves. What can be the diagnosis of the patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Libman-Sacks endocarditis

 

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a form of non-infective endocarditis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is characterized by the presence of sterile vegetations on either side of the heart valves. The key points supporting this diagnosis in the given case are:

 

  • Fever and malar rash: These are common symptoms of SLE.
  • Vegetations on either side of the heart valves: This is a characteristic feature of Libman-Sacks endocarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infective endocarditis: This typically presents with fever, positive blood cultures, and vegetations on one side of the heart valves. The vegetations are infective and not sterile.

 

Option C. Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis: This condition involves sterile vegetations usually found on the valve leaflets but is not specifically associated with SLE. It can occur in hypercoagulable states and malignancies.

 

Option D. Rheumatic heart disease: This condition is typically a sequela of rheumatic fever and involves inflammation of the heart valves. It is usually associated with a history of streptococcal infection and does not present with sterile vegetations on both sides of the valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is characterized by sterile vegetations on either side of the heart valves and is commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Recognizing the association with SLE is crucial for diagnosis.

choices.text: Transitional cell cancer
Squamous cell cancer
Small cell cancer

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has been working in the dye industry for 40 years. He develops some frequency and urgency with painless hematuria. What is the likely subtype of the condition present in him? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transitional cell cancer

 

Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is the most common type of bladder cancer. It originates in the urothelial cells that line the inside of the bladder. The patient's history of working in the dye industry for 40 years is significant, as occupational exposure to certain chemicals, such as naphthylamine, is a known risk factor for developing TCC.

 

Confirmed or suspected risk factors for transitional cell carcinoma.

 

  1. Smoking Increases risk up to five times.
  2. Analgesics Mainly associated with renal pelvis transitional cell carcinoma, but also bladder tumors
  3. Occupation Workers in alanine dye, rubber and chemical industries due to exposure to Naphthylamine (which in the liver is converted to carcinogen that must be activated in the Bladder). These workers need regular bladder checks.
  4. Cyclophosphamide can cause bladder cancer in the long term (although used for cancer treatment)
  5. Schistosomiasis cause chronic inflammation and metaplasia (squamous) of the bladder mucosa (leading to squamous cell carcinoma)
  6. Chronic infections/inflammation: Some authorities believe that any chronic inflammatory may predispose to cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: A less common type of bladder cancer that originates from glandular cells.

 

Option C. Squamous cell cancer: Usually associated with chronic inflammation and infections, such as those caused by Schistosomiasis.

 

Option D. Small cell cancer: A rare type of bladder cancer that originates from neuroendocrine cells.

 

Educational Objective:
