Transitional cell carcinoma is the most common type of bladder cancer, with risk factors including occupational exposure to chemicals, smoking, and certain medications. This type of cancer is characterized by painless hematuria and urinary frequency and urgency.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound compressing the swelling. Xray of the neck is seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Laryngocele

 

The given image along with the examination finding of Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngeal Pouch: Also known as a Zenker's diverticulum, is a pouch that protrudes from the pharyngeal mucosa and would not typically cause a gurgling sound when compressed.

 

Option C. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: This involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and the esophagus, not associated with external neck swellings or gurgling sounds upon compression.

 

Option D. Tonsillar cyst: Would generally be located near the tonsils inside the throat and would not exhibit characteristics like a gurgling sound or be affected by Valsalva maneuvers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a history of activities involving high intra-laryngeal pressure, presenting with neck swelling and characteristic gurgling sounds upon compression, a laryngocele should be considered as a likely diagnosis, requiring appropriate imaging and potential surgical intervention for confirmation and treatment.

choices.text: Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 40-year-old P2L2 presents to your office with foul smelling bloody discharge per vaginum. She has been diagnosed with Carcinoma of the cervix Stage III B as per FIGO classification. What is the primary treatment option for this case? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Treatment of cervical cancer is either surgical or chemoradiation
  • Chemoradiation can be given for all stages
  • Surgery can be given till stage 2A
  • From Stage 2B onwards, treatment of cervical cancer is only by chemoradiation

 

 

Type 1: Simple extra fascial hysterectomy

 

Type 2: Modified radical hysterectomy

 

Type3: Radical Hysterectomy

 

Type4: Extended Radical hysterectomy

 

Type 5: Partial Exenteration

 

Educational Objective:

 

From Stage 2B onwards, the primary treatment of cervical cancer is chemoradiation.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 367

questions.text: The following image is of the most common cause of stridor in children. Identify it? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in children and the most common congenital laryngeal abnormality. It typically presents soon after birth and generally resolves by the age of two. The condition is characterized by the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration, which leads to airway obstruction.

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Stridor is present, which worsens when the child is in a prone position or while feeding.
    • Sobbing can be a typical accompanying symptom.
       
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Laryngomalacia results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration, causing an obstruction of the airway.
       
  • Management:
    • In most cases, laryngomalacia resolves spontaneously without the need for treatment or correction.
    • In severe cases where there is significant airway obstruction, a tracheostomy may be necessary.
    • Supraglottoplasty is recommended for severe laryngomalacia to alleviate symptoms and improve airway patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal papilloma: Laryngeal papilloma is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and presents with wart-like growths in the larynx, leading to hoarseness and potential airway obstruction, but it is not the most common cause of stridor in children.

 

Option C. Chronic epiglottitis: Chronic epiglottitis, also known as recurrent acute epiglottitis, is a rare condition that involves inflammation of the epiglottis. It presents with severe throat pain, fever, and difficulty swallowing but is not the most common cause of stridor.

 

Option D. Laryngocele: A laryngocele is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal saccule that can present with a neck mass, hoarseness, and airway obstruction, but it is not as common as laryngomalacia in causing stridor in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in children and typically resolves on its own by the age of two. It is important to recognize the characteristic symptoms and management strategies for severe cases.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sedation and wait

 

Explanation:

 

  • The described clinical situation points to either a prolonged latent phase or false labor pain.
  • The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.
  • By using therapeutic rest, in which the patient is sedated with morphine, one can also distinguish false labor from true labor.
  • Augmentation by amniotomy or oxytocin is not recommended for prolonged latent phase unless there is an indication for quick delivery.
  • A cesarean section is not indicated as prolonged latent phase is not known to have any significant effect on maternal or fetal outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Augmentation with oxytocin: Augmentation is not recommended for a prolonged latent phase unless there is an indication for quick delivery.

 

Option C. Cesarean section: Cesarean section is not indicated as a prolonged latent phase does not significantly affect maternal or fetal outcomes.

 

Option D. Amniotomy: Amniotomy is not recommended for prolonged latent phase unless there is an indication for quick delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A latent phase of more than 20 hours in a primigravida and more than 14 hours in a multigravida is abnormal, but it does not significantly affect maternal-fetal outcomes. Proper management involves sedation and waiting.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 24th edition pg 446, D C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition pg 463

choices.text: Amoebic liver abscess

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented to the hospital with history of recurrent pain in the right Hypochondrium for 1 week. She is a known case of hereditary spherocytosis. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute cholecystitis

 

Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder. It usually happens when a gallstone blocks the cystic duct.

 

Gallstones are small stones, usually made of cholesterol, that form in the gallbladder. The cystic duct is the main opening of the gallbladder. In patients with hemolytic disorders, black pigment stones are seen, which are likely to block cystic duct and cause biliary colic or cholecystitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydatid Cyst is a parasitic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus. It most commonly involves Liver and Lung. The patient is usually asymptomatic or may have right upper quadrant pain

 

Option B. Acute Pancreatitis: Patient with Acute Pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Lab investigations reveal increase serum amylase and lipase levels. Its management is mainly supportive care with adequate analgesia, IV Fluid therapy and oxygen administration.

 

Option D. Amoebic liver abscess: Patients with amoebic liver abscess are mostly asymptomatic. There is usually a history of dysentery with mucus in stools. It is caused by E. histolytica and on aspiration, pus with Anchovy-sauce appearance is obtained.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis often occurs in patients with hemolytic disorders, like hereditary spherocytosis, due to the formation of black pigment stones that block the cystic duct.

choices.text: Gray matter around aqueduct of Sylvius

questions.text: A patient after a head injury following a road traffic accident. Present with following symptom - He is extremely curious. He forgets everything, hyperorality and increased sex drive. Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged in this patient?  (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Amygdala

 

Explanation

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which results from damage to the amygdala. This syndrome is characterized by hyperorality, hypersexuality, bulimia, visual agnosia, and amnesia. Hyperorality refers to a compulsive tendency to put objects in one's mouth or to explore objects with one's mouth. Hypersexuality refers to an increased interest in sexual behavior, and disinhibition refers to a loss of normal inhibitions or social boundaries. Visual agnosia is the inability to recognize objects, and docility refers to a lack of normal emotional responses.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Gray matter around the aqueduct of Sylvius: Incorrect. The gray matter around the aqueduct of Sylvius is known as the punishment center and is not related to the symptoms described.


Option C. Lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus: Incorrect. The lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus are associated with the reward center and do not explain the symptoms of hyperorality, hypersexuality, and amnesia.


Option D. Anterior Cingulate gyri: Incorrect. The anterior cingulate gyri are involved in functions related to emotion and cognition but are not specifically associated with the symptoms described in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the amygdala can result in Kluver-Bucy syndrome, characterized by hyperorality, hypersexuality, amnesia, and other behavioral changes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy drink full bottle of iron syrup. What is the antidote of acute iron poisoning? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Desferrioxamine

 

Desferrioxamine is the specific antidote for acute iron poisoning and is administered via the intravenous route. It acts by chelating free iron, forming a complex that is then excreted primarily through the kidneys. This action effectively reduces the toxic effects of excess iron in the body, which can include severe damage to the gastrointestinal tract, liver, and heart if not promptly treated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dimercaprol or BAL (British anti-lewisite) is the antidote for bismuth, arsenic and lead poisoning

 

Option B. EDTA is the antidote for lead poisoning

 

Option D. Penicillamine is primarily used in management of copper poisoning

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desferrioxamine is the antidote of acute iron poisoning, given via IV route.

  • Deferipirone is drug of choice for chronic iron poisoning.

choices.text: Water's view
Towne's view
Law's view

questions.text: What is this view called in which maxillary sinus is seen best? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Water’s view

 

Water’s view (occipitomental view) is a radiographic projection used primarily to evaluate the paranasal sinuses, especially the maxillary sinuses. It is the most effective X-ray view for visualizing the maxillary sinus because it projects the sinus clearly by positioning the X-ray beam at an angle that minimizes overlap with other anatomical structures.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B. Towne's View: This view is typically used to visualize the foramen magnum and occipital bone at the base of the skull, not the sinuses.
  • Option C. Law’s View: While not as commonly referenced as the others, it is not standard for evaluating the maxillary sinuses.
  • Option D. Stenver's View: Used primarily for detailed evaluation of the inner ear structures, including the auditory ossicles and mastoid process, not for sinus imaging.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: While using endotracheal tube what determines the resistance to airflow? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diameter

 

  • Resistance to airflow is given by the Poiseuille’s Law formula –

R = 8nL/ Π r4

 

Where,

 

(L- length, r – radius, n- number, R- resistance to airflow)

 

As per the formula, resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius. A small reduction in radius (or diameter) can result in a significant increase in resistance. This is why patients with narrowed airways (like in asthma) have much higher resistance to airflow.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option A. Material: While the material of the tube can influence factors such as flexibility, it doesn't directly determine the resistance to airflow as described by Poiseuille’s Law.

 

 

Option C. Price: The cost of the endotracheal tube has no direct bearing on the resistance to airflow.

 

Option D. Length: Length does play a role as seen in the formula, but in clinical settings, variations in tube length have a comparatively lesser effect than the diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While using endotracheal tube the diameter determines the resistance to airflow.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 358-359 (Doubtful)

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female who was treated with steroids and remdesivir for COVID now presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

 

MUCORMYCOSIS

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis presents with black or greyish membrane is seen in the nasal mucosa. Exploration of maxillary sinus reveals a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

 

Option C. Foreign body presents with unilateral nasal discharge which is often foul smelling and occasionally bloodstained.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patient presents as a leafy, polypoid mass, pink to purple in color and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with diabetes or other forms of immunocompromise, especially those recently treated with steroids or other immunosuppressive agents, the presence of black necrotic tissue in the nasal cavity should prompt immediate consideration of mucormycosis. This is a medical emergency that requires prompt antifungal treatment and often surgical debridement to prevent fatal outcomes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. Examination findings are given below. Swarm of bees appearance is seen on histopathology. The most likely diagnosis in this man is? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Alopecia areata

 

  • It is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss. It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. It is Associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3
  • Alopecia areata has Exclamation mark hair, which refers to short extractable broken hairs which are thinner towards the base as shown in the image below

 

  • Alopecia totalis means loss of all scalp hair & alopecia universalis means loss of all body hair.
  • Spontaneous remission is seen in 80% of the patients, in case of limited Alopecia areata.
  • Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata. Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair.
  • Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair.
  • This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.
  • The following image shows sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

On histological examination perifollicular lymphocytic infiltration is seen giving a swarm of bee’s appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kerion

 

  • It presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Option C. Trichotillomania

 

  • It is a behavioural disorder characterised by compulsive hair pulling which causes patchy hair loss.
  • Varying lengths of hair & absence of complete hair loss in the patch are its characteristic features which can be seen in the below image.

 

Trichotillomania

 

Option D. Androgenetic alopecia

 

  • It is characterized by the miniaturization & reduction of hair follicle production. Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true. Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are effects of male pattern hair loss.
  • A stronger version of testosterone is called DiHydroTestosterone (DHT). It causes follicular regression, which results in androgenetic alopecia.
  • Female pattern hair loss (FPHL) manifests as diffuse mid-frontal scalp hair thinning with little to no bitemporal recession. Typically, the frontal hairline is preserved, and there is no vertex baldness.
  • Vertex baldness and frontal hairline recession are symptoms of male pattern hair loss (MPHL).

 

The most popular classification systems currently used to describe patterns of hair loss are the Ludwig system for FPHL and the Hamilton Norwood classification system for MPHL.

 

Ludwig system for FPHL:

 

 

 

As the pattern of hair loss differs between men & women the terms male pattern hair loss & female pattern hair loss are also used. However male pattern may occur in women & vice versa.

 

Drugs used to treat male pattern baldness:

 

  • Minoxidil lotion
  • 5-alpha reductase antagonist - Finasteride

 

Drugs used to treat female pattern baldness:

 

  • Minoxidil lotion
  • Anti androgens – Spironolattone flutamide cyproterone acetate

 

Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator:

 

  • It is used orally to treat severe hypertension. when used as a hair lotion, it prolongs the anagen phase & slows down or prevents hair loss.

 

Finasteride

 

  • Type 2,5 alpha reductase is essential for controlling androgen-dependent hair growth. Within the hair follicle, finasteride specifically inhibits type 2,5 alpha reductase. As a result, it is used to treat male pattern baldness.
  • Testosterone is converted to the more potent form of dihydrotestosterone by the enzyme 5-alpha reductase (DHT).
  • Three isoforms of the enzyme 5-alpha reductase exist. Widespread in the skin and unrelated to hair growth are types 1 and 3.
  • The prostate, epididymis, and seminal vesicles are just a few examples of tissues that respond to androgens and contain type 2 5 alpha reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alopecia areata is a cause of non-scarring hair loss with round or oval patches and a characteristic "swarm of bees" appearance on histopathology, distinguishing it from other types of alopecia and scalp conditions.

 

Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.9-17, 89.28-33

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.39

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea, but she gets abdominal pain every month. On examination, she has normal development of other secondary sexual characteristics, there is an abdominal lump present and on parting the labia a bluish bulge is noted. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the appropriate management? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cruciate incision on the hymen

 

  • The diagnosis of imperforate hymen is supported by a history of primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, the presence of a palpable abdominal lump, and the observation of a tense, bulging, blue membrane on the separation of the labia.
  • The treatment of choice for an imperforate hymen is a cruciate incision over the hymen, which allows the retained menstrual blood to be evacuated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excision of the septum: This is appropriate for a transverse vaginal septum, which is a different congenital anomaly causing cryptomenorrhea.

 

Option B. Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty: This treatment is used for atresia of the upper third of the vagina, which also can cause cryptomenorrhea but is a more complex condition.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: This is generally reserved for cases where surgical correction is not possible, such as in cervical agenesis or rudimentary uterine horns with functional endometrium.

 

Other causes of cryptomenorrhea that may present with similar symptoms include:

 

  • Transverse vaginal septum (treated with excision of the transverse septum)
  • Imperforate hymen (treated by a cruciate incision)
  • Atresia of the upper third of the vagina (may be treated with extensive dissection and vaginoplasty)
  • Hysterectomy (may be needed where surgical correction is not possible, such as cervical agenesis or rudimentary horns with functional endometrium)

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cruciate incision over an imperforate hymen is the appropriate management for a 17-year-old female presenting with primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, and a bulging bluish hymen.

 

Ref: D.C. Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology Pg 450

choices.text: Cervical vertebral fracture

questions.text: The main cause of death in Judicial hanging is? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical vertebral fracture

 

The cause of death in judicial hanging is controversial and often attributed to 'hangman's fracture' of the second cervical vertebra.

 

 

Cervical Vertebral Fracture (Hangman's Fracture):

 

  • Mechanism: The sudden drop and the force applied to the neck result in hyperextension and fracture of the C2 vertebra. This fracture can lead to instant death due to spinal cord injury.
  • Consequences: Disruption of the cervical spinal cord can cause immediate cessation of neurological function, including respiratory and cardiovascular control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoxia: While hypoxia is a contributing factor in many asphyxial deaths, in judicial hanging, the primary mechanism is cervical spinal cord injury.

 

Option B. Brain hypoxia: Similar to general hypoxia, brain hypoxia can occur but is not the primary cause of death in judicial hanging.

 

Option D. Vagal inhibition: This refers to reflex cardiac arrest due to vagus nerve stimulation, but it is not the primary cause of death in judicial hanging.

 

Educational objective

 

The main cause of death in judicial hanging is the fracture of the cervical vertebra (specifically the second cervical vertebra or C2), leading to spinal cord injury and immediate cessation of vital functions.

choices.text: Indirect inguinal hernia
Direct inguinal hernia

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented with a mass in the inguinal region which produces gurgling sound on reduction. The mass is reduced completely on pressing it through the deep inguinal ring. What could be the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

An indirect inguinal hernia originates at the internal inguinal ring and follows the path of the spermatic cord within the inguinal canal.

 

The given mass is reduced completely on pressing the deep inguinal ring is pointing towards indirect inguinal hernia. Its likely to contain small bowel (enterocele) as suggested  by gurgling sound on reduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Direct inguinal hernia: A direct inguinal hernia protrudes through a weakened area in the fascia of the abdominal wall, known as the Hesselbach's triangle. It does not travel through the inguinal canal as indirect hernias do. Because of its location, you cannot reduce it by applying pressure to the deep inguinal ring.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: A femoral hernia emerges through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament, closer to the thigh. It's more common in women than in men due to the wider shape of the female pelvis. Its location is distinctly different from that of an inguinal hernia, and it's usually not reducible through the deep inguinal ring.

 

Option D. Pantaloon hernia: A pantaloon hernia (also called a saddlebag hernia) is when there's both a direct and an indirect inguinal hernia on the same side. The name comes from the hernias' appearance resembling a pair of pants. If the described mass could be reduced by pressing at two distinct sites (one corresponding to the indirect hernia and the other to the direct hernia), then a pantaloon hernia might be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An indirect inguinal hernia can be reduced completely by pressing the deep inguinal ring and often produces a gurgling sound if it contains small bowel.

questions.text: 65-year-old man presents with complaints of low back pain. On further evaluation, he is found to have anemia and serum electrophoresis demonstrates an increased level of IgG kappa monoclonal protein. He has elevated serum calcium and creatinine levels. The x-ray of skull shows multiple punched out lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple myeloma

 

Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells. Normal plasma cells are found in the bone marrow and are an important part of the immune system. The immune system is made up of several types of cells that work together to fight infections and other diseases.

 

Lymphocytes (lymph cells) are one of the main types of white blood cells in the immune system and include T cells and B cells. Lymphocytes are in many areas of the body, such as lymph nodes, the bone marrow, the intestines, and the bloodstream.

 

When B cells respond to an infection, they mature and change into plasma cells. Plasma cells make the antibodies (also called immunoglobulins) that help the body attack and kill germs. Plasma cells, are found mainly in the bone marrow. Bone marrow is the soft tissue inside bones. In addition to plasma cells, normal bone marrow is also the home for other blood cells such as red cells, white cells, and platelets.

 

CRAB CRITERIA for MM

 

Hypercalcemia – serum calcium >11 mg/dL

 

Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dL or creatinine clearance <40 mL/min

 

Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dL

 

Lytic bone lesions

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Follicular lymphoma: A type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that originates from follicle center B cells, not characterized by the findings described.

 

Option C. Burkitt’s lymphoma: A highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, often involving the jaw or abdomen, not typically associated with increased IgG kappa monoclonal protein.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: A type of leukemia characterized by an accumulation of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes in the blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues, not typically associated with the findings described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by the presence of IgG kappa monoclonal protein, hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and lytic bone lesions.

questions.text: A farmer comes to skin OPD with the painful, swollen foot which has discharging sinuses and dark grains coming out of sinuses. Gram stain was negative. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eumycetoma

 

The diagnosis with the given case scenario would be Eumycetoma (Madura foot)

 

 

Clinical features: (GST)

  1. Grains
  2. Sinuses
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The above image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge

 

Treatment:

 

1. Eumycetoma:

 

  • Antifungals (Itraconazole)

 

2. Actinomycetoma:

 

  • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
  • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

 

  • SCC is a type of skin cancer arising from the squamous cells.
  • It can present as a firm, red nodule, or a flat sore with a scaly crust.
  • While SCC can ulcerate and sometimes form a chronic non-healing sore, it doesn't typically present with discharging sinuses and grains.
  • Therefore, the presentation doesn't fit with SCC.

 

Option C. Actinomycetoma:

 

  • Actinomycetoma is similar to eumycetoma in presentation, but it's caused by bacteria (actinomycetes) rather than fungi.
  • Like eumycetoma, it can cause swelling and sinuses. However, the grains in actinomycetoma are typically pale or yellowish in colour.
  • The "dark grains" description is more consistent with eumycetoma than actinomycetoma.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by the Sporothrix schenckii complex.
  • It's commonly associated with gardening or outdoor activities involving thorn pricks.
  • The disease typically presents as a chain of nodules or ulcers along the lymphatic draining the site of inoculation as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While sporotrichosis can cause nodules and ulcers, it doesn't produce sinuses with dark grains like eumycetoma does.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eumycetoma is identified by the clinical presentation of a swollen extremity with draining sinuses and visible grains, typically occurring in individuals with a history of walking barefoot or in farmers, and distinguish it from Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Actinomycetoma, and Sporotrichosis.

 

Reference

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no 604

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration, low T3, low T4. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

The patient's presentation of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain, along with low TSH, T3, and T4 levels, is indicative of central hypothyroidism. The fact that TSH levels increased after the administration of TRH suggests a central cause for hypothyroidism, specifically originating from the hypothalamus.

 

  • Low TSH, T3, and T4: These findings suggest central hypothyroidism, which can be due to either pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction.
  • TRH administration: The increase in TSH levels following TRH administration indicates that the pituitary is TRH sensitivity. This implies that the problem lies with the hypothalamus, which is not producing sufficient TRH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary: This is inconsistent with the clinical findings of low TSH, T3, and T4.

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary: If the problem were in the pituitary, the TSH levels would not increase after TRH administration, indicating TRH resistance.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus: This is inconsistent with the clinical findings of low TSH, T3, and T4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism with low TSH, T3, and T4, and an increase in TSH levels after TRH administration, indicates hypothalamic dysfunction. This is due to a deficiency in TRH production from the hypothalamus, leading to secondary hypothyroidism.

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

 

The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery: While this artery does contribute to the overall vascular network in the area, it is not the primary supply to the palatine tonsils.

 

Option C. Buccal branch of maxillary artery: Primarily supplies regions in the buccal mucosa and is not directly involved in supplying the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D. Ascending palatine branch of facial artery: Although it supplies the tonsils, it is not the main artery compared to the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the vascular anatomy of the palatine tonsils is crucial, especially in surgical settings where tonsillectomy might be performed. Recognizing the primary and secondary blood supplies can aid in effective management of potential complications such as bleeding. The tonsillar branch of the facial artery remains the most significant contributor to this vascular supply.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 291, 292

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to emergency in a delirious state. He is found to have tachycardia and arrythmia. There were scratch marks on the skin. Which of the following substance can cause these symptoms?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

The patient's symptoms (delirium, tachycardia, arrhythmias, and scratch marks) are characteristic of cocaine intoxication. Cocaine is a stimulant that can lead to these manifestations, especially the sensation of "formication" causing scratching.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heroin: Opioid intoxication usually presents with miosis, respiratory depression, and sedation.

 

Option C. Cannabis: Typically causes euphoria, anxiety, and perceptual alterations but not the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Chronic intake leading to withdrawal can cause delirium tremens, but this presents with tremors, agitation, and possible seizures, and doesn't typically involve scratch marks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can present with cardiovascular abnormalities like tachycardia, hypertension and arrhythmias, neuropsychiatric symptoms like delirium, and the sensation of "formication" (also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon) which leads to scratching. It can also present with paranoid ideations, auditory hallucinations and visual illusions.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry by Niraj Ahuja, 7th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: Dr. Anjali, an epidemiologist in a small district of Jharkhand, is concerned about a sudden surge in the number of malaria cases, especially in children. To establish if there's a recent increase in the transmission of the malarial parasite in the community, she intends to use a specific metric. Which of the following indices would Dr. Anjali most likely employ to determine the recent transmission of malaria in her community? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infant parasite rate

 

The Infant Parasite Rate (IPR) is a crucial metric used to assess recent malaria transmission, especially among young children. It measures the percentage of infants who test positive for malaria parasites in their blood. This index is highly sensitive for detecting recent changes in malaria transmission levels in a community. If the IPR remains zero for three consecutive years, it typically indicates that malaria transmission has been absent during that period, even if the mosquito vectors are still present.

 

 

Most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria. If IPR is zero for 3 consecutive years, it is regarded as absence of malaria transmission (even though anopheline may remain)

 

Parasite rate: Percentage children 2–10 years age showing parasites in blood films

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual Parasite Incidence: Incorrect because this measures the number of new cases per year per 1,000 population and is not specifically sensitive to recent transmission among infants.

 

Option C. Spleen Rate: Incorrect as it measures the percentage of children with enlarged spleens due to malaria over time, which is more of a long-term indicator.

 

Option D. Slide Positivity Rate: Incorrect for this specific need, as it indicates the proportion of all tested slides that are positive, not specifically focusing on recent transmission in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Infant Parasite Rate (IPR) is the most sensitive index for detecting recent malaria transmission in young children, making it an essential tool for epidemiologists monitoring malaria outbreaks in areas with fluctuating transmission levels.

choices.text: Right lower lobe consolidation
Right middle lobe consolidation
Right loculated effusion

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fever and cough for 6 days. The CXR is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Explanation

 

  • Silhouette sign is to be applied here. Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.
  • The outline of a specific structure that is created at the boundary between two tissues with varying tissue densities is called a silhouette in a chest radiograph, for example, the cardiac silhouette between the heart and the lung.
  • The silhouette sign is the blurring or obliteration of these typical silhouettes brought on by disease pathologies.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Right Lower Lobe Consolidation: Would more typically obscure the right diaphragm or show a basal shadowing in the posterior-anterior view.

 

Option B. Mitral Stenosis: Would not directly affect lung parenchyma; might lead to pulmonary congestion seen as diffuse bilateral shadowing.

 

Option D. Right Loculated Effusion: Typically appears as a denser, more fluid-like shadowing at the lung bases or along the pleural lining, often with a meniscus.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Barium swallow image demonstrated below indicates: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

ACHALASIA CARDIA

 

 

Rat-tail appearance/bird-beak tapering appearance

 

Achalasia cardia is one of the common motility disorder of esophagus. Pathophysiologically, achalasia cardia is caused by loss of inhibitory ganglion in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zenker’s diverticulum is a pharyngeal outpouching which occurs due incoordination between the Cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus. It is a false or pulsion diverticulum. Barium swallow image is shown below -

 

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm which is a hypermotility disorder.

 

 

Option D. Cancer Esophagus appears as irregular narrowing of the lower esophagus with shouldering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia presents with a characteristic "bird-beak" or "rat-tail" appearance on barium swallow due to the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, caused by the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mumps

 

Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands, particularly the parotid glands located near the ears. The key symptoms in this case include fever, a painful lump over the cheek (indicating parotitis), and difficulty in swallowing or talking. Additionally, the patient's complaint of mild testicular pain suggests orchitis, which is a common complication of mumps in post-pubertal males.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical tuberculosis: This condition typically presents with lymphadenopathy in the neck, chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. It does not usually cause acute painful lumps below the ear or testicular pain.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Diphtheria presents with sore throat, low-grade fever, and an adherent membrane on the tonsils, pharynx, or nasal cavity. It does not typically cause parotitis or orchitis.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can present with painless lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. However, it does not commonly present with acute symptoms such as painful parotid swelling or testicular pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mumps is characterized by parotitis and orchitis, especially in post-pubertal males. Recognizing these key symptoms can aid in the diagnosis of mumps.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever for the past 4 days and new onset of breathlessness was admitted to ICU as he was deteriorating. He was unresponsive to the incremental flow rate of oxygen and his oxygen saturation was progressively decreasing. He was intubated and a Chest X-ray was ordered, and the findings are shown in the image below. His PaO2/FiO2 was 204 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ARDS

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by the following criteria, updated in the New Berlin criteria:

 

  1. Acute onset: The patient's condition should worsen within a week of a known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms.
  2. Bilateral opacities on imaging: The chest X-ray shows bilateral extensive infiltrates, which are not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules.
  3. Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema: The respiratory failure should not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.
  4. PaO2/FiO2 ratio:
    • Mild ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300 mmHg
    • Moderate ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 ratio <200 mmHg
    • Severe ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 ratio <100 mmHg

 

In this case, the patient has an acute onset of symptoms, bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray, and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 204 mmHg, indicating moderate ARDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atelectasis: This condition involves the collapse of part or all of a lung and typically does not present with the extensive bilateral infiltrates seen in ARDS.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is usually associated with elevated left atrial pressure, and imaging might show cardiomegaly and pleural effusions, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Fibrosis: This is a chronic condition that leads to progressive scarring of the lung tissue. It usually presents with a more gradual onset and not the acute, severe respiratory failure seen in ARDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARDS is diagnosed based on acute onset, bilateral infiltrates on chest imaging, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio indicative of the severity of hypoxemia. Recognizing these criteria is crucial for timely and appropriate management.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks’ gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm.There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)

 

Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3

 

Platelet count: 62000/mm3

 

Hematocrit: 26%

 

AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

  • HELLP syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.
  • The hallmark symptoms of HELLP (Hemolysis, High Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome are right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear findings of hemolysis.
  • Although associated with preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome may not have any or very little hypertension and proteinuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Transmission by parenteral route, sexual contact, or vertical transmission. Acute illness may cause malaise, nausea, vomiting. In many cases, it is asymptomatic. Jaundice is rare, fever uncommon

 

Option C. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy: (yellow atrophy of liver)

 

Option D. Obstetric cholestasis: Intrahepatic cholestasis associated with pruritis, nausea, vomiting, jaundice. Levels of liver enzymes are raised, conjugated bilirubin are also raised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets, and can present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and elevated AST levels.

 

  Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page258,336

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old man who experienced eye pain, photophobia, and redness for the past 2 days after injuring his eye by brushing it against leaves and thorns while gardening?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal keratitis

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a case of fungal keratitis as it caused by trauma with vegetative matter like leaves and thorns

 

Salient features of a fungal corneal ulcer:

 

  • It is caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter.
  • Signs are more pronounced than symptoms.
  • The corneal ulcer appears dry. Delicate feathery finger-like extensions are present.
  • A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation) may be present
  • Multiple, small satellite lesions may be present around the ulcer.
  • Hypopyon is present.
  • Pigmented ulcer (brownish) may be caused by some dematiaceous species of fungi.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion and few other findings.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simplex keratitis:

 

  • Cause: Typically caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).
  • Symptoms: Presents with eye pain, redness, and photophobia, but usually follows a history of HSV infection or recurrence.
  • Signs: Dendritic ulcers are characteristic, which are not described in this case.

 

Option B. Bacterial keratitis:

 

  • Cause: Usually associated with contact lens wear or trauma but often presents with more acute and severe symptoms.
  • Signs: The ulcer tends to be more purulent with intense redness and discharge, not specifically linked to trauma with vegetative matter.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba keratitis:

 

  • Cause: Often associated with contact lens use, especially with exposure to contaminated water.
  • Symptoms: Severe pain out of proportion to clinical signs, photophobia, and redness.
  • Signs: Ring infiltrates and perineural infiltrates are characteristic but are not typically linked to trauma with vegetative matter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal keratitis is commonly associated with trauma from vegetative matter. Key clinical features include a dry corneal ulcer with feathery edges, satellite lesions, and a possible immune ring. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker's oral examination. Identify the lesion given? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Leukoplakia

 

Leukoplakia is a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. Etiological factors include smoking, tobacco chewing, alcohol abuse particularly, if combined with smoking, ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites. Pathologically, there is epithelial hyperplasia with excess keratin deposition. It is a pre-cancerous condition.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythroplakia is a red patch in oral cavity. Occurs due to poor oral hygiene.

 

Option C. Fordyce's granules are enlarged, slightly raised sebaceous glands that appear in hairless areas of skin.

 

 

Option D. Koplik spots are seen with measles. They are small, white spots (often on a reddened background) that occur on the inside of the cheeks early in the course of measles.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When conducting an oral examination, especially in patients with risk factors like smoking or alcohol consumption, it is crucial to differentiate between various types of lesions. Leukoplakia, due to its potential to transform into a malignancy, requires careful monitoring and possibly biopsy to assess the degree of dysplasia or early signs of cancerous changes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: A 6-year-old child comes to casualty with history of unknown poisoning by some seed/drug. On examination patient has dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium and decreased secretions with hallucination. What poisoning should the doctor suspect? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Datura

 

Dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium and decreased secretions are anticholinergic symptoms, and Datura is an anticholinergic poison

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura):
    • Dry hot skin
    • Dilatation of pupils
    • Diplopia
    • Dry mouth
    • Decreased Body Secretions
    • Dysphagia
    • Dysarthria
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Poppy seeds: These are non-poisonous. All the parts of poppy plant are poisonous except seeds, which are used as an ingredient in food (Khas Khas seeds)

 

Option C. Mushroom: Mushroom poisoning usually have GI symptoms (vomiting and diarrhea) or cholinergic symptoms (SLUDGE: Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Diarrhoea, Gastrointestinal Upset, Emesis). Whereas the patient in question have anticholinergic symptoms.

 

  • Mushroom poisoning is the result of ingestion of wild mushrooms after misidentification of a toxic mushroom as an edible species.
  • There are about 100 different species of mushrooms which can be toxic and have different kinds of toxins which can produce very different symptoms.
  • The most common consequence of mushroom poisoning is simply mild gastrointestinal upset due to gastrointestinal irritants that cause vomiting and diarrhea, but usually no long-term damage.
  • However, sometimes mushroom poisoning can be dangerous and even lead to death. Other features of mushroom poisoning are:
    • Hallucination by mushrooms of the Psilocybe genus, containing psilocybin
    • Muscarinic symptoms by certain mushrooms containing muscarine toxins that stimulate muscarinic cholinergic receptors (but not the nicotinic cholinergic receptors).
    • Liver toxicity: It is caused by Amanita phalloides, the mushroom which causes 95% of mushroom poisoning deaths. Initially there is Severe gastroenteritis, then after few days liver failure and sometimes renal failure and death

 

Option D. Cannabis: The features of cannabis are generally mild, and usually mild psychoactive (euphoria, relaxation) and mild cognitive impairment. The question has predominantly anticholinergic features which are seen in Datura. Also, Hallucination, Delirium etc are rare in cannabis, and occur only in very few severe cases, but they are common in Datura.

 

Educational Objective

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium, decreased secretions, and hallucination, which match the symptoms described in the question.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for downwards and outwards displacement of pupil as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oculomotor nerve

 

The image of the right eye being "down and out" along with ptosis, double vision and pupillary dilation is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Causes: Vascular ischemia, Trauma, Intracranial neoplasm, Haemorrhage, Congenital, Idiopathic

 

Clinical Manifestations of III CN Palsy: Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), Ophthalmoplegia (impaired eye movements), Diplopia (double vision), Mydriasis (dilation of the pupil)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve:

 

  • Function: The optic nerve transmits visual information from the retina to the brain.
  • Associated Conditions: Conditions affecting the optic nerve, such as optic neuritis or optic neuropathy, typically result in visual loss, not abnormalities in eye movement or pupil position.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve (CN IV):

 

  • Function: Innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • Action of Superior Oblique: Moves the eye downward and outward.
  • Clinical Manifestation of CN IV Palsy: Results in vertical diplopia (double vision), difficulty looking downward, and a compensatory head tilt to the opposite side of the lesion.
  • Key Point: The action of the superior oblique muscle is to turn the eye “down and out”. However, a "down and out" position of the eye in the context of trochlear nerve involvement implies the unopposed action of the superior oblique muscle due to paresis of the ocular muscles supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).

 

Option D. Abducens nerve (CN VI):

 

  • Function: Innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
  • Action of Lateral Rectus: Moves the eye outward (abduction).
  • Clinical Manifestation of CN VI Palsy: Leads to horizontal diplopia, inability to abduct the eye, and esotropia (inward turning of the eye).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the eye, along with ptosis and pupillary dilation. This occurs due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are innervated by CN VI and CN IV, respectively. Understanding the clinical presentation and causes of oculomotor nerve palsy is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhea not responding to antibiotics. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in EAC, facial nerve palsy was present. The likely diagnosis is? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

 

An elderly individual with diabetes is experiencing intense ear pain (otalgia), drainage from the ear (otorrhea), and the presence of granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC). Additionally, there is a facial nerve palsy, which collectively suggests the possibility of malignant otitis externa.

 

MALIGNANT OTITIS EXTERNA

 

ETIOLOGY – More common in elderly, diabetic and immunocompromised patients.

 

CAUSATIVE ORGANISM - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus species, and fungi.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Excruciating ear pain
  • Granulations in the ear canal
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple lower cranial nerve palsies
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to temporomandibular fossa
  • Posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

 

DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells, and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.           
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Control of diabetes
  • Aural toilet
  • Antibiotic treatment against causative organism, which in most commonly P. aeruginosa (or any other causative organism) for 6-8 weeks.
  • Antibiotics commonly used are antipseudomonal antibiotics ; Third-generation cephalosporins ; Ciprofloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger, A. fumigatus or Candida albicans. It is common in hot and humid climate of tropical and subtropical countries. Patient presents with intense itching,

discomfort or pain in the ear, watery discharge with a musty odour and ear blockage.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media presents with hearing loss, mild earache. Tympanic membrane is dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.

 

Option D. Eczematous otitis externa - It is the result of hypersensitivity to infective organisms or topical ear drops such as chloromycetin or neomycin, etc. Patient presents with intense irritation, vesicle formation, oozing and crusting in the canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa should be suspected in diabetic or immunocompromised patients presenting with severe ear pain, resistant otorrhea, and cranial nerve palsies. Immediate and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent potentially fatal outcomes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: A patient presented with vomiting to medicine OPD. He has a history of eating fried rice. What is the most likely organism causing this? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacillus cereus

 

Bacillus cereus is a common cause of food poisoning associated with the consumption of fried rice. This bacterium can produce spores that survive cooking. If the rice is not properly refrigerated, these spores can germinate, leading to the production of an enterotoxin that causes vomiting. Bacillus cereus food poisoning typically presents with two syndromes: the emetic form (vomiting) and the diarrheal form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium perfringens: 

Clostridium perfringens can cause food poisoning, but it is more commonly associated with meat dishes and presents with symptoms primarily involving diarrhea and abdominal cramps rather than vomiting.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: 

Staphylococcus aureus can cause food poisoning characterized by vomiting and diarrhea. It is typically associated with improperly stored dairy products, meats, and salads but is less commonly linked to fried rice.

 

Option D. Bacillus anthracis: Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax and is not associated with food poisoning or fried rice consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus cereus is the most likely organism responsible for food poisoning characterized by vomiting after consuming fried rice. This organism produces toxins that can survive cooking and cause illness if the food is not properly stored.

questions.text: Identify the type of graphical representation shown. What is this specific type of graph called? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Component bar diagram

 

Component bar diagram shows the various parts of a single piece of data. They are also known as sub-diagrams. A bar graph is a particular type of data visualization that uses rectangular bars with each bar’s length proportional to the value it represents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’. Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option B. Multiple Bar Diagram: Is for visual comparison of magnitude of different frequencies in discrete data Is the most versatile of all statistical diagrams. This involves several bars grouped together to compare different categories, not components of a single category.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Component bar diagrams excel in displaying complex data in a clear, comparative format, ideal for analyzing detailed breakdowns such as nutritional intake across different demographics.

questions.text: A pediatrician in a rural clinic is evaluating a 7-year-old boy who presents with several episodes of diarrhea. Although the diarrhea does not show the classic rice-water appearance typical of cholera, another symptom leads the doctor to suspect a Shigella infection instead. What symptom more likely indicates Shigella infection rather than cholera? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fever

 

Fever is a distinguishing symptom in cases of Shigella infection and is generally uncommon in cholera, making it a key indicator for diagnosis. Cholera typically presents with watery diarrhea and dehydration without significant fever. Shigella, on the other hand, often causes fever alongside bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, pointing to its invasive nature affecting the intestinal walls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal cramps: These are common in many types of gastrointestinal infections, including both cholera and shigella.

 

Option C. Vomiting: Vomiting can occur in cholera but is not as distinctive for differentiating between these two infections.

 

Option D. Tenesmus: While tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete emptying after a bowel movement) is also seen in Shigella, it's not as universally present as fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fever is unusual in Cholera but usually is a symptom in Shigella infection.

 

All other given options are found in Cholera except abdominal pain, which is seen in both.

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • Points in favor of abruption
    • Abdominal pain
    • Pallor
    • High BP 
    • Uterine height > POG

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: In placenta previa, the bleeding is painless

 

Option C. Hydramnios: In hydramnios, there won’t be vaginal bleeding

 

Option D. Preterm labor: In preterm labor also there won’t be vaginal bleeding

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abruptio placenta is characterized by abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal movements, often associated with hypertensive disorders in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 295-297

questions.text: What is the name of the pathological classification used for CA stomach? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Borrmann classification

 

The name of the classification used for CA stomach is Bormann classification.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duke classification is used for colorectal cancer

 

Option C. Johnson’s classification is used for location of peptic ulcer

 

Option D. Sievart’s classification is used for GE junction tumours

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Borrmann classification is used to categorize gastric carcinomas based on their macroscopic appearance observed during endoscopy, which is crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning in stomach cancer.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was born at term with no congenital abnormalities. He is now 70% normal body weight. On examination, dependent edema on lower extermities and large distended abdomen is found. Which of the following nutritional problems is most likely present in the child? (FMGE  JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor with protein malnutrition

 

Kwashiorkor is primarily a protein deficiency disorder, even though the overall calorie intake may be adequate. The key symptoms include edema (as seen in the lower extremities of the child), a distended abdomen, and often a change in hair color, skin peeling or rash, and an enlarged liver. The child's normal birth and subsequent development of these symptoms are consistent with kwashiorkor, which typically occurs when a child is weaned onto a high-carbohydrate but low-protein diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus with energy deficiency: Marasmus is caused by a severe deficiency in calories, leading to significant weight loss and muscle wasting. Children with marasmus typically appear very thin and frail, without edema. The presence of edema and a distended abdomen in the described child is not characteristic of marasmus.

 

Option C. Kwashiorkor with energy deficiency: This option is a bit contradictory as kwashiorkor typically involves adequate or near-adequate caloric intake but insufficient protein intake. It is the protein deficiency that is the more critical aspect of kwashiorkor, not energy deficiency.

 

Option D. Marasmus with protein malnutrition: Marasmus is characterized more by energy deficiency than by protein deficiency. Although protein deficiency can be a component, the primary issue in marasmus is a lack of overall caloric intake. The presence of edema in the child is more indicative of kwashiorkor than marasmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two types of malnutrition disorders

 

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed pg. 587

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was found to have hypogonadism. On investigation, this child was found to have high levels of LH, FSH & testosterone. Which of the following enzymes could be deficient in this child? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5 alpha reductase

 

  • The boy presents with hypogonadism, and his laboratory findings reveal high levels of LH, FSH, and testosterone. This condition is indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • 5 alpha reductase deficiency leads to impaired conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is crucial for the development of male external genitalia. This deficiency manifests as hypogonadism, despite normal or elevated testosterone levels.
  • DHT is the active form of testosterone responsible for the development of male genitalia during intrauterine life. A deficiency in 5 alpha reductase results in undervirilization in males, leading to ambiguous genitalia or female-like external genitalia despite male chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21 alpha hydroxylase: Deficiency in this enzyme typically presents with congenital adrenal hyperplasia, characterized by ambiguous genitalia in females and precocious puberty in males due to excessive androgen production.

 

Option B. 11 beta hydroxylase: Deficiency leads to congenital adrenal hyperplasia with hypertension and ambiguous genitalia in females, due to excess androgen production, and similar to 21 alpha hydroxylase deficiency, males typically show signs of early virilization.

 

Option D. 17 hydroxylase: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to decreased production of sex steroids (androgens and estrogens), causing undervirilization in males and lack of secondary sexual development in both sexes, with hypertension and hypokalemia due to mineralocorticoid excess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency leads to impaired conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), resulting in undervirilization and ambiguous genitalia in males despite normal or elevated levels of testosterone.

questions.text: What is the name of procedure, whose image is given below? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Whipple’s procedure

 

The image depicts a Whipple procedure, also known as a pancreaticoduodenectomy. This complex surgical operation involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, the gallbladder, and the bile duct. The procedure is typically performed to treat tumors and other disorders located in the head of the pancreas, as well as in the bile duct, duodenum, and surrounding areas. The Whipple procedure aims to remove the diseased tissue while maintaining as much normal pancreatic function as possible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticojejunostomy: This procedure involves creating an anastomosis (connection) between the pancreas and the jejunum to facilitate drainage of pancreatic secretions. It is not depicted in the image provided.

 

Option C. Radical pancreatectomy: A radical pancreatectomy is a more extensive surgical procedure where the entire pancreas, part of the stomach, part of the small intestine, the common bile duct, the spleen, and nearby lymph nodes are removed. This is not the procedure depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Duodenojejunostomy: This procedure involves creating a connection between the duodenum and the jejunum. It is commonly performed to bypass an obstructed segment of the duodenum, but it does not involve the extensive tissue removal seen in the Whipple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy) involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct, and is used to treat tumors and other disorders of these organs.

choices.text: Superficial perineal pouch
Deep perineal pouch

questions.text: A patient with history of trauma has a ruptured bulbar urethra. What is the location for accumulation of urine? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superficial perineal pouch

 

In bulbar urethral injury, there is extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The superficial perineal pouch is a potential space located in the perineum, inferior to the urogenital diaphragm and above the Colles' fascia of the perineum. When the bulbar urethra ruptures, urine can dissect into this space, leading to swelling and hematoma in the perineal region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch:

 

  • The deep perineal pouch is superior to the superficial pouch and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous part of the urethra, the deep transverse perineal muscles, and other structures. A rupture here would not typically lead to extravasation of urine into this pouch as a result of bulbar urethral trauma.

 

Option C. Recto-uterine pouch (or Pouch of Douglas):

 

  • This is the space between the rectum and the uterus and is the lowest point in the peritoneal cavity in females. It is of importance when there is the accumulation of fluid (such as pus or blood) in the peritoneal cavity. It does not have relevance in the context of a ruptured male urethra.

 

Option D. Perivesical space:

 

  • The perivesical space is located around the bladder. Urinary extravasation is seen here in cases of extraperitoneal bladder rupture or posterior urethral rupture, not typically in bulbar urethral injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a bulbar urethral rupture, urine typically accumulates in the superficial perineal pouch.

questions.text: A demographer is examining the population trends in various industrialized nations. He notes that in these countries, both birth and death rates are uniformly low, leading to very modest population growth. This scenario contrasts with earlier stages where these rates exhibited more pronounced shifts. What term is used to describe this stable demographic stage? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Phase 4

 

The term "low stationary phase" refers to the fourth stage of the demographic cycle, characterized by low birth rates (BR) and low death rates (DR), resulting in minimal net population growth. This stage reflects a matured demographic state often seen in developed countries where both birth and death rates have stabilized at a low level after transitioning through phases of higher variability.

 

Demographic Cycle

 

Stage 1: (High stationary): High birth rate & high death rate

 

Stage 2: (Early expanding): Birth rate unchanged & death rate decreases

 

Stage 3: (Late expanding): Birth rate: decreases & death rate: decreases

 

Stage 4: (Late stationary): BR: low & DR: low

 

Stage 5: (Declining): BR < DR / population decreases - populations are reproducing well < replacement levels (Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece, United Kingdom and Japan)

 

 

Minimum demographic gap: Stage 1 & stage 4

 

Maximum demographic gap: Late part of stage 2

 

India is in: Stage 3 (Late expanding stage)

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Demographic transition: is a model used to explain the process of transition from high BR and high DR (Stage 1 demographic cycle – High stationary) to low BR and low DR (Stage 4 )
  • Demographic trap: Applies to a country whose population is growing rapidly due to a high BR and low DR 
  • Demographic Window: Period of time in a nation’s demographic evolution when ‘proportion of population of working age group is particularly prominent’. Typically, demographic window of opportunity lasts 30–40 years
  • Demographic dividend: A rise in the rate of economic growth due to a rising share of working age people in a population. It usually occurs late in the demographic transition when the fertility rate falls and the youth DR declines. In this demographic window opportunity, output per capita rises.
  • Demographic gift: The initially favorable effect of falling fertility rates on the ratio of the working population to the dependent population

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demographic cycle

choices.text: Optic nerve glioma

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute vision loss and painful eye movements in one eye. Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the affected eye, while the optic disk appears normal. Visual field testing reveals a central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Optic neuritis

 

Clinical examination reveals a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as the Marcus Gunn pupil due to asymmetric involvement. This is an important finding in optic nerve disorders, including optic neuritis.

The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma

 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis.

The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease)

 

 

 

Causes of RAPD:

 

  • Severe retinal disease (eg, central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Asymmetric Maculopathy (macular degeneration)
  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis multiple sclerosis)
  • Optic tract lesions (eg, infarction)
  • Asymmetric Glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve glioma: Typically presents with progressive vision loss, optic disc swelling, and later atrophy. Painful eye movements are less common.

 

Option C. Eale's disease: Idiopathic retinal vasculitis, typically presenting with peripheral retinal ischemia and neovascularization. Does not present with RAPD or central scotoma.

 

Option D. Neuroretinitis: Presents with optic disc swelling and macular star formation. The optic disc would not appear normal as described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic neuritis is characterized by acute vision loss, painful eye movements, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and central scotoma with a normal-appearing optic disc. It is strongly associated with demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis.

 

Causes of Central/ Centrocaecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion e.g., Pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
  1. Poor nutrition
  2. Tobacco Alcohol
  3. Drug-induced optic neuropathy
  4. Toxin-induced optic neuropathy
  5. Hereditary optic atrophy
  6. Sarcoidosis
  7. Leukemia

questions.text: A child with b/I sensorineural hearing loss was given hearing aids which have not been beneficial. Which of the following is the next treatment option for this child? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cochlear implant

 

The next treatment option for this child is a cochlear implant.

 

Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone anchored hearing aid is indicated when air conduction can’t be used, conductive hearing loss in which surgery is contraindicated, single sided hearing loss.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure used to eradicate disease in middle ear and to reconstruct hearing mechanism.

 

Option C. Normal hearing aid is a device used to amplify sounds. In the given case, it is mentioned that hearing aids were not beneficial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children with significant sensorineural hearing loss who do not benefit from hearing aids, cochlear implants offer a viable alternative for auditory rehabilitation. They provide the ability to perceive sound by directly stimulating the auditory nerve, thereby bypassing the dysfunctional cochlear hair cells.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 138-140

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis in this child with bull neck, nasal twang, nasal regurgitation with change in voice? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Diphtheria, which is characterized by bull neck, cervical adenopathy, sore throats, and difficulty swallowing in unvaccinated children.

 

 

In case of measles there is a presence of bilateral parotitis.

 

Ludwig angina presents as a submandibular swelling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torticollis: Ruling out: Torticollis is a condition characterized by a twisted neck and head tilt. It does not present with bull neck or nasal regurgitation.

 

Option C. Mumps: Ruling out: Mumps typically presents with bilateral parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) and does not involve the symptoms described such as bull neck or nasal twang.
