Option D. Ludwig’s angina: Ruling out: Ludwig's angina is an infection of the floor of the mouth, under the tongue. It presents with submandibular swelling and can cause airway obstruction but does not typically present with nasal twang or regurgitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria is characterized by bull neck, sore throat, grey or white patches in the throat or nose, and can cause airway obstruction and heart failure if untreated. Vaccination with DTaP is crucial for prevention.

choices.text: Streptococcus sanguis
Enterococcus faecium
Coxiella burnetti

questions.text: A 38-year-old IV drug abuser presents with a 1-week history of malaise, fatigue, and rigors. His temperature on admission was 38.5°C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Which organism is most likely to be found in his blood culture? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers.

 

Staphylococcus aureus infective endocarditis (IE) is a serious and potentially life-threatening infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers or valves, caused by the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus. IE can occur in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions, such as congenital heart disease or heart valve abnormalities, or in those with a history of intravenous drug use or healthcare-associated infections.

 

The symptoms of IE may include fever, fatigue, chills, night sweats, weight loss, and new or changing heart murmurs. In some cases, the infection may also cause septicemia, which can lead to septic shock and multiple organ failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus sanguis: 

Streptococcus sanguis, a member of the viridans group streptococci, is a common cause of subacute infective endocarditis, particularly in individuals with pre-existing valvular heart disease. However, it is less common in IV drug users compared to Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option B. Enterococcus faecium: 

Enterococcus faecium can cause infective endocarditis, especially in individuals with genitourinary or gastrointestinal tract infections. It is less common in IV drug users.

 

Option C. Coxiella burnetii: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q fever endocarditis, which typically occurs in patients with pre-existing valvular disease or prosthetic valves. It is not commonly associated with IV drug use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely causative organism of infective endocarditis in IV drug users, characterized by a rapid onset of symptoms and the presence of a pan-systolic murmur, as well as positive blood cultures.

questions.text: Identify the antibody shown in the image: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgM

 

IgM antibodies may appear earlier and decline more rapidly than IgG antibodies. IgM antibody tests have been widely used for the diagnosis of acute infection and to determine whether a pregnant woman has been infected during gestation or before conception. There has been a heightened awareness of the fact that titers in tests for IgM antibodies may persist for years after the acute infection and that the reliability of commercially available assays varies considerably.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgD: Usually monomeric and involved in the initiation of immune responses.

 

Option C. IgA: Typically found as a dimer, especially in mucosal areas and secretions.

 

Option D. IgG: Monomeric and the most abundant antibody in the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgM is the largest antibody and appears early in the immune response, often forming a pentameric structure.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with hepatic jaundice, deranged liver function tests, and the clinical findings as shown in the given image, which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilson’s disease

 

Wilson’s Disease

 

Copper accumulates in the liver, kidneys, brain, and eyes Autosomal recessive disease of copper metabolism

 

Young patients: Symptoms of liver disease

 

Older Patients: Neuropsychological symptoms

 

LABS

 

  • LOW ceruloplasmin
  • LOW serum copper (most of the copper deposited in tissue)
  • INCREASED urine copper

 

Management

 

  • Chelation with penicillamine
  • Low copper diet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Huntington chorea: A neurodegenerative genetic disorder characterized by chorea and psychiatric symptoms, not associated with hepatic jaundice and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option C. Leigh syndrome: A severe neurological disorder that typically arises in the first year of life, not associated with hepatic jaundice and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option D. Hemochromatosis: A genetic disorder leading to iron overload, not copper, and does not present with Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson’s disease is characterized by copper accumulation in the body, leading to hepatic jaundice, neuropsychological symptoms, and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes.

questions.text: Hormones that regulate serum calcium levels:(FMGE  2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcitonin, vitamin D, PTH

 

These are the three primary hormones involved in the regulation of serum calcium levels. PTH increases calcium levels in the blood by stimulating the release of calcium from bones, increasing calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and promoting the conversion of vitamin D to its active form, which increases calcium absorption in the gut. Vitamin D (specifically, its active form, calcitriol) enhances intestinal absorption of calcium. Calcitonin, produced by the thyroid gland, helps to lower blood calcium levels by inhibiting bone resorption and increasing calcium excretion in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Thyroid, Vitamin D, PTH: The thyroid gland itself does not directly regulate serum calcium levels. While it produces calcitonin, it's more accurate to specify calcitonin rather than the thyroid gland as a whole.

 

Option C. Calcitonin, Vitamin D: This option excludes PTH, which is a critical hormone in calcium regulation. PTH works in tandem with calcitonin and vitamin D to maintain calcium balance.

 

Option D. Vitamin D, PTH: While both are crucial, this option omits calcitonin, which plays a role in reducing calcium levels in the blood, particularly in response to hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ca Homeostasis = Involves Calcitriol (vitamin D), PTH and calcitonin

 

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed pg. 639

questions.text: A patient has macrocytic anaemia and high homocysteine levels. His methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal. What is the diagnosis:(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B9 Deficiency

 

Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency is known to cause macrocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine levels. Folate is essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell formation. When folate levels are low, it leads to the production of larger than normal red blood cells (macrocytes), resulting in macrocytic anemia. Folate deficiency also leads to elevated homocysteine levels due to impaired remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B6 Deficiency: While vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency can lead to elevated homocysteine levels, it generally does not cause macrocytic anemia. Instead, vitamin B6 deficiency is more commonly associated with microcytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 Deficiency: Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes macrocytic anemia and high homocysteine levels, it is additionally associated with elevated methylmalonic acid (methylmalonyl CoA) levels. Since the patient's methylmalonyl CoA levels are normal, this makes vitamin B12 deficiency less likely.

 

Option D. Anemia of Chronic Disease: This type of anemia typically presents as normocytic (normal cell size) or microcytic (small cell size) and is associated with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies. It does not typically present with macrocytosis or high homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30th ed; pg- 558

choices.text: It is a large molecule bounded with another protein
﻿﻿﻿It gets attracted to the positive charge of the glomerular filtration barrier

questions.text: Why hemoglobin cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is a large molecule bounded with another protein

 

It is a large and negatively charged protein cannot cross the glomerulus in normal physiological state. It is not Present in free form physiologically; present within the RBCs.

 

Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells that is responsible for oxygen transport in the body i.e., from the lungs towards the tissues via the circulatory system. It is a complex molecule made up of four protein subunits, each containing a heme group that binds to an oxygen molecule.

 

In the tissues, the oxygen is released from Hb and used by cells for energy production through cellular respiration.

 

The production of Hb is regulated by a hormone called erythropoietin, which is produced by the kidneys in response to low levels of oxygen in the body.

 

Other Options:


Option B. It gets attracted to the positive charge of the glomerular filtration barrier: Incorrect. Hemoglobin is negatively charged, and the glomerular filtration barrier is also negatively charged, which repels the passage of negatively charged proteins like hemoglobin.


Option C. Both A and B: Incorrect. While hemoglobin is a large molecule, it is not attracted to the positive charge of the glomerular filtration barrier, making this option incorrect.


Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Option A is correct, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemoglobin cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state because it is a large molecule contained within red blood cells and is negatively charged, which is repelled by the similarly charged glomerular filtration barrier.

questions.text: A person is working with 30-year history of working in cardboard manufacturing and develops breathlessness and mottling in lungs. It is likely to be associated with: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bagassosis

 

Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. It was first reported in India in a cardboard manufacturing firm near Kolkata. The disease is associated with exposure to bagasse dust in industries like cardboard, paper, and sugar manufacturing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Byssinosis: Associated with the inhalation of cotton, hemp, or flax dust in the textile industry, not bagasse dust.

 

Option C. Asbestosis: Caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly seen in industries like cement and roof tiling.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: A type of cancer that is not related to inhalation of occupational dust and does not present with lung mottling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occupational exposures and related diseases:

questions.text: A tall male teenager presented with gynecomastia. On examination, he has average cognition and absence of secondary male characteristics as deep voice, beard, and male distribution of pubic hair. His genetic analysis was performed and he had the presence of a barr body. What is the likely diagnosis of this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klinefelter syndrome

 

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects males. It is caused by the presence of one or more extra copies of the X chromosome, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. This extra genetic material can lead to a variety of physical, hormonal, and developmental differences.

 

Physical features: People with Klinefelter syndrome may have a tall and thin body type, with long legs, arms, and fingers. They may also have a small penis, undescended testicles, and enlarged breast tissue (gynecomastia).

 

Hormonal features: Klinefelter syndrome can cause low levels of testosterone and increased levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). This can lead to infertility, decreased muscle mass, and reduced facial and body hair growth.

 

Developmental features: Klinefelter syndrome can affect cognitive and behavioral development. Boys with Klinefelter syndrome may have difficulty with language, reading, and social skills. They may also be at higher risk for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and other learning disorders.

 

Diagnosis: Klinefelter syndrome can be diagnosed through genetic testing, typically performed after puberty when physical and hormonal differences become more apparent.

 

Treatment: Treatment for Klinefelter syndrome may include hormone replacement therapy to address low testosterone levels, speech therapy or educational interventions to address developmental differences, and surgery to address gynecomastia or undescended testicles.

 

KLINEFELTER- XXY AND TURNER-XO SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Affects females and is characterized by a single X chromosome (XO).

 

Option C. Swyer syndrome: A type of gonadal dysgenesis where individuals have an XY karyotype but develop as females.

 

Option D. Down syndrome: Caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), not associated with gynecomastia and absence of male secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by an extra X chromosome (47, XXY), leading to physical, hormonal, and developmental differences, including gynecomastia and absence of secondary male characteristics.

questions.text: Which treatment option is typically recommended for a 3-year-old child diagnosed with amblyopia in the right eye?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patching of the left eye

 

The treatment of amblyopia in this child is by occlusion of the normal eye. Amblyopia or "lazy eye' is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye

 

Treatment should be based on various factors such as pt. age, VA, compliance with previous treatment, psychological status and various other causes.

The choices of treatment of amblyopia are used alone or in combination to achieve goal of treatment

 

Passive Therapy - The patient experiences a change in visual stimulation without any conscious effort

 

  1. Proper refractive correction
  2. Occlusion
  3. Penalization

 

1. Proper Refractive Correction

  • To provide sharp images and providing optimal environment for amblyopia therapy
  • Give patient proper optical correction alone
  • Short period of time (6-8 weeks) before initiation of other therapy - In case of refractive amblyopia, a progressive improvement in acuity for up to 16-22 weeks has been shown in some pts after refractive Correction.

 

2. Occlusion Therapy

  • The most powerful and effective means of treating amblyopia
  • Highly effective until 8 years of age
  • New studies have shown improvements upto 24 yrs of age
  • Cover good eye to stimulate amblyopic eye
  • Success rate 30-92%
  • When fixation is central: simple & effective
  • When fixation is eccentric: <7 years central fixation recovers
  • Older the child harder to regain central fixation

 

Mode of Action

Prevent fixating eye taking part in act of vision and removes inhibitory stimulus that arises from stimulation from fixating eye (non-amblyopic eye)

 

3. Penalization

  • Therapeutic technique performed by optically defocusing the eye with better vision by using cycloplegia or altering the eye glass lens

 

Classification and types

 

 

Amblyopic eyes have a characteristic vision which has:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescription glasses:

 

  • Role: Important for correcting refractive errors but not sufficient alone for treating amblyopia.
  • Use: Provides sharp images to both eyes, but additional therapy is needed to treat amblyopia.

 

Option B. Patching of the right eye:

 

  • Incorrect: Patching the amblyopic eye (right eye) would worsen the condition by further reducing its use.

 

Option D. Vision therapy:

 

  • Role: Used as an adjunct to other treatments, involving exercises to improve eye coordination and visual processing.
  • Use: Less effective alone for treating amblyopia compared to occlusion therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-year-old child with amblyopia, the recommended treatment is patching the left (normal) eye to stimulate the right (amblyopic) eye. This method is highly effective in improving the function of the amblyopic eye by forcing it to be used more actively in visual tasks.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of undescended testis? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pulsatile GnRH

 

The treatment of undescended testis (cryptorchidism) can sometimes involve hormonal therapy, although the most common treatment is surgical. The hormonal treatments that have been used include human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).

 

Pulsatile GnRH therapy can be used to treat cryptorchidism. Pulsatile GnRH administration mimics the natural release pattern of GnRH from the hypothalamus, which can stimulate the testes to descend. However, the effectiveness of this treatment is variable and not as consistent as surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-pulsatile GnRH: The non-pulsatile administration of GnRH is not typically used for the treatment of undescended testis. The pulsatile nature of GnRH administration is important to mimic the physiological pattern of GnRH release.

 

Option C. Testosterone: Testosterone therapy has been used in the past for treating cryptorchidism. However, its effectiveness is limited and not generally recommended as a primary treatment. There are also concerns about potential adverse effects on the future fertility of the child.

 

Option D. Anti-MIH therapy: MIH (Müllerian Inhibiting Hormone) is not directly related to the descent of the testes. It is involved in the regression of the Müllerian ducts during male fetal development. Thus, an "anti-MIH therapy" would not be relevant or effective in treating undescended testis. Based on these considerations, the most appropriate answer from the given options for the treatment of undescended testis is A. Pulsatile GnRH, keeping in mind that its effectiveness can be variable and surgical treatment (orchidopexy) is often preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing undescended testis, pulsatile GnRH offers a hormonal treatment option that leverages the body’s natural hormonal mechanisms for testicular descent, although its variable effectiveness means that surgical intervention remains the most reliable treatment method. Each case should be evaluated individually, considering both the potential benefits and limitations of hormonal therapy compared to surgical options.

questions.text: A patient on treatment of myasthenia gravis present with increasing muscle weakness. Which of the following drugs is used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Edrophonium

 

Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, it works only for 10 min. Initially, 2 mg is administered. If improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered.

 

If the condition improves the diagnosis is Myasthenia gravis and if it worsens, the condition is Cholinergic crisis.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine: Used primarily in the treatment of glaucoma and not relevant for assessing neuromuscular function or differentiating myasthenic from cholinergic crises.

 

Option C. Atropine: An anticholinergic used to treat cholinergic crisis by reducing the effects of excessive acetylcholine but not used for differentiating between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis.

 

Option D. Pyridostigmine: A treatment for myasthenia gravis as it enhances communication at the neuromuscular junction by preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine. Not used in the differential diagnosis of the conditions mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Edrophonium test is crucial in differentiating between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis, especially when patients present with increased muscle weakness. Improvement in symptoms after administration indicates inadequate acetylcholine effect typical of myasthenia gravis, while worsening suggests toxic effects from excessive medication typical of cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: Ms. Lakshmi, a school principal in Rajasthan, seeks to integrate health services into her school's activities and consults with the local health official about oversight. Which level of rural health infrastructure is primarily responsible for managing school health programs? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PHC

 

The Primary Health Center (PHC) is typically responsible for overseeing school health programs in rural areas. The Medical Officer in charge of the PHC manages and coordinates health services for schools within the catchment area, which usually serves a population of 20,000 to 30,000. This includes routine health check-ups, vaccinations, and health education, ensuring that the healthcare needs of students are met as part of broader public health efforts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) play a pivotal role in the rural healthcare infrastructure by directly overseeing and managing school health programs, ensuring that health services are effectively integrated into the educational environment for the well-being of students.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman came to the hospital with a breast condition as shown in the picture below. What is the T- staging of the cancer? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

The image shows Peau d'orange appearance of the breast, which is characteristic of skin edema due to lymphatic obstruction. This presentation corresponds to T4b in the TNM staging system for breast cancer.

 

T4b:

 

  • This stage involves ulceration, ipsilateral satellite skin nodules, or skin edema, including Peau d'orange. Peau d'orange refers to the orange peel-like appearance of the skin, indicative of underlying malignancy involving the skin's lymphatic drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4a: T4a involves direct extension to the chest wall, which does not include the pectoralis muscle. The provided image does not indicate involvement of the chest wall.

 

Option C. T4c: T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b. Since the image only shows Peau d'orange without chest wall extension, it does not fulfill the criteria for T4c.

 

Option D. T4d: T4d refers to inflammatory breast cancer, characterized by diffuse erythema and edema (inflammatory changes) of the breast, often without an underlying mass. The image provided does not suggest diffuse inflammatory changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Peau d'orange appearance in breast cancer is indicative of T4b stage, which involves skin changes such as ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or edema including Peau d'orange.

choices.text: Strangulated inguinal hernia

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy presented in agony with sudden onset of severe pain in the groin region, associated with redness and swelling of the scrotum. On examination the right testis looks higher than the left. Possible diagnosis in this boy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Testicular torsion

 

The clinical scenario described is highly suggestive of testicular torsion, which is a surgical emergency. Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord twists, cutting off the testicle's blood supply. This condition presents with sudden, severe pain in the groin or scrotum, often accompanied by swelling, redness, and an elevated testis on the affected side. The critical timeframe for intervention is within six hours to prevent testicular necrosis. The procedure performed is an orchidopexy, where the testis is surgically fixed to prevent recurrence. The investigation of choice is a Doppler ultrasound, which assesses blood flow to the testis. Deming's sign, where the affected testis is higher than normal, is a key clinical feature of testicular torsion.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hydrocele: Hydrocele, which is the accumulation of fluid around the testicle, typically does not present with sudden onset of severe pain or an elevated testis. It generally presents as a painless swelling in the scrotum.

 

Option C. Strangulated inguinal hernia: A strangulated inguinal hernia may present with colicky abdominal pain and a tender, irreducible mass in the groin, but it does not cause the testis to be higher than normal.

 

Option D. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Acute epididymo-orchitis involves inflammation of the epididymis and/or testis, often presenting with gradual onset of pain and swelling in the scrotum. The affected testis is not typically higher than the contralateral testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion presents with sudden, severe groin or scrotal pain, swelling, redness, and an elevated testis, requiring urgent surgical intervention within six hours to prevent necrosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented to ophthalmology department with increased tearing and a mucopurulent discharge from the right puncta. The mother seeks appropriate treatment for the condition. Which of the following management options would be most suitable? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sac massage with topical antibiotics

 

The above history of epiphora (increased watering) and mucopurulent discharge from the punctum is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis

Congenital dacrocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It occurs due to the stasis of secretions which in turn due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct.

Regurgitation test (applying pressure over the lacrimal sac causes regurgitation of mucopurulent discharge from the lower punctum is usually positive.

More than 90% of patients with congenital nasolacrimal obstruction undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syringing:

 

  • Usage: Syringing involves flushing the tear drainage system with a saline solution to clear any blockage.
  • Suitability: This method is not typically used as the initial treatment for congenital dacryocystitis in infants because it can be traumatic and is usually reserved for older children or if conservative methods fail.

 

Option B. Probing with syringing:

 

  • Usage: This involves inserting a probe into the nasolacrimal duct to open any blockage and then flushing it with saline.
  • Suitability: Probing is generally considered if the condition does not resolve with conservative measures like sac massage and antibiotics. It is usually performed between 9 months to 1 year of age if the condition persists.

 

Option D. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR):

 

  • Usage: DCR is a surgical procedure where a new drainage pathway is created between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity.
  • Suitability: This is typically reserved for older children (over 4 years of age) or adults, especially when other treatments have failed. It is not the first-line treatment for a 3-month-old child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment depends on the age of the child:

questions.text: Corticospinal tract which is one of the descending motor tracts which carries signal to the muscle crosses at? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lower medulla

 

Explanation

 

Descending motor tracts crosses over in lower medulla.

 

Descending motor tracts are of 2 types Pyramidal and extrapyramidal tract cross at lower medulla.

 

The corticospinal tract also known as pyramidal tract, is the major neuronal pathway providing voluntary motor function, which is important for the fine, skilled motor activity.

 

Pathway - corticospinal tract starts at precentral gyrus i.e., motor cortex → Corona radiata → internal capsule→ pons → medulla oblongata

 

 

80% fibers decussate at medulla and descend towards spinal cord as lateral corticospinal tract. 

 

20% remain uncrossed and they reach to the spinal cord and then they cross opposite side

 

Other Options:


Option A. Midbrain: Incorrect. The midbrain is not the location where the corticospinal tract crosses.


Option B. Pons: Incorrect. The pons is not the location where the corticospinal tract crosses.


Option C. Upper medulla: Incorrect. The upper medulla is not the location where the corticospinal tract crosses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, crosses at the lower medulla, providing voluntary motor function important for fine, skilled motor activity

questions.text: What structural abnormality of the cornea is commonly observed in keratoconus? (FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corneal thinning and steepening

 

Keratoconus is a condition characterized by the progressive thinning and steepening of the cornea. This leads to a cone-like shape of the cornea, resulting in visual distortions and irregular astigmatism.

 

 

Symptoms of keratoconus may change as the disease progresses. They include:

 

  • Blurred or distorted vision.
  • Increased sensitivity to bright light and glare, which can cause problems with night driving.
  • A need for frequent changes in eyeglass prescriptions.
  • Sudden worsening or clouding of vision.

 

 

Keratoconus is also associated with:

  • Eye allergies
  • Excessive eye rubbing, and
  • Connective tissue disorders like marfan syndrome and ehlers-danlos syndrome

 

In the early stage, keratoconus symptoms can include:

  • Mild blurring of vision
  • Slightly distorted vision, where straight lines look bent or wavy
  • Increased sensitivity to light and glare
  • Eye redness or swelling

 

In later stages, keratoconus symptoms often include:

  • More blurry and distorted vision
  • Increased nearsightedness or astigmatism (when your eye cannot focus as well as it should). As a result, you may need new eyeglass prescriptions often.
  • Not being able to wear contact lenses. They may no longer fit properly and they are uncomfortable.

 

Treatment of keratoconus:

  • Intacs:  Intacs are intrastromal implants that help flatten the curvature of cornea to improve vision.
  • Collagen cross-linking. Riboflavin drops are activated by UV light and improve the mechanical strength and stability of corneal collagen by inducing crosslinking.
  • Corneal transplant

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corneal thickening and flattening: Incorrect: This description does not align with keratoconus. Corneal thickening and flattening could be seen in conditions like corneal edema or other specific corneal dystrophies but not in keratoconus.

 

Option C. Corneal scarring and opacity: Incorrect: While corneal scarring and opacity can occur as a complication of advanced keratoconus, they are not the primary structural abnormalities. These features are more commonly associated with infections, trauma, or advanced stages of corneal diseases.

 

Option D. Corneal vascularization and neovascularization: Incorrect: Corneal vascularization and neovascularization are usually indicative of chronic inflammation, corneal ulcers, or prolonged contact lens wear. They are not typical features of keratoconus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratoconus is a progressive eye disease characterized by corneal thinning and steepening, leading to a cone-shaped deformation. This results in distorted vision and irregular astigmatism, often presenting with symptoms like blurred vision, increased light sensitivity, and frequent changes in prescription glasses. Early detection and appropriate management, including options like corneal cross-linking, Intacs, and in severe cases, corneal transplant, are crucial to slow disease progression and preserve vision.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with a history of bee allergy came to the emergency room with complaints of swelling of face and dyspnea after a bee sting. Which of the following inflammatory mediators plays a major role? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histamine

 

Inflammatory mediators, including cytokines, histamine, bradykinin, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes, impact the Immune system, usually as proinflammatory factors. Other mediators act as regulatory components to establish Homeostasis after injury or prevent the inflammatory process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serotonin: Also involved in the inflammatory response but not the primary mediator in allergic reactions like histamine.

 

Option B. Bradykinin: is a product of kallikrein induced breakdown of high-molecular-weight kininogen (HMWK) in the kinin cascade.

 

Option D. Prostaglandins: are a group of lipids with hormone-like actions that your body makes primarily at sites of tissue damage or infection.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Histamine is the primary inflammatory mediator involved in the allergic response to a bee sting, leading to symptoms such as swelling and dyspnea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and JVP showed rapid x and y descent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by the thickening and rigidity of the pericardium, which restricts the heart's normal movement and function. This condition leads to specific changes in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, including rapid x and y descents. These findings are indicative of constrictive pericarditis and are often referred to as "Friedreich's sign"

 

  • Rapid x and y descents: The rapid x descent is due to atrial relaxation, and the rapid y descent is due to rapid ventricular filling. Both are prominent in constrictive pericarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: In cardiac tamponade, there is usually attenuation or blunting of the y descent due to the restriction of ventricular filling by the pericardial fluid. This condition often shows absent y descent in severe cases.

 

Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy: This condition is characterized by dilation of the heart chambers and is often associated with heart failure symptoms and additional heart sounds such as a third heart sound (S3). The JVP findings are different from those seen in constrictive pericarditis.

 

Option D. Restricted cardiomyopathy: This condition can also present with similar JVP findings, including rapid x and y descents, making it a close differential diagnosis. However, the classic teaching and the context provided in the question lean towards constrictive pericarditis as the more straightforward diagnosis for exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Constrictive pericarditis presents with prominent rapid x and y descents in the JVP waveform. Recognizing these features is crucial for diagnosis and differentiating it from other conditions like cardiac tamponade and dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of chronic diarrhea, fatigue, and tiredness. On examination, his nail findings are shown below. Lab investigations show Hb as 8 g/dL. Which of the following is the best treatment? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron supplements

 

The nail finding shown in the image is called koilonychia, which is characterized by spoon-shaped nails. This is a classic sign of iron deficiency anemia. The patient's symptoms of chronic diarrhea, fatigue, and tiredness, along with a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, further support the diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia.

 

  • Iron supplements: The best treatment for iron deficiency anemia is iron supplementation. This helps replenish the body's iron stores and resolve the symptoms associated with anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Incorrect because folic acid is used to treat folate deficiency anemia, not iron deficiency anemia. The patient's symptoms and nail findings specifically indicate iron deficiency.

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Incorrect because metronidazole is an antibiotic used to treat infections caused by anaerobic bacteria and certain parasites. It is not relevant to the treatment of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Incorrect because vitamin B12 is used to treat pernicious anemia or vitamin B12 deficiency anemia, which presents differently from iron deficiency anemia. The nail findings and symptoms do not indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) is a classic sign of iron deficiency anemia. The appropriate treatment for iron deficiency anemia is iron supplementation.

choices.text: Only people who order online food
Online food eaters and homemade food eaters

questions.text: Dr. Verma, an epidemiologist, is investigating the correlation between online food ordering and obesity through a case-control study. He is determining the appropriate groups for sampling to effectively study the potential link. Which groups should be included in the sample? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Obese and non-obese people

 

Case Control study is a retrospective study where we move from the effect to the cause. In this example, to find the relationship between Obesity (that is the effect) and ordering food (probably the cause), we have to take obese persons as the cases and non-obese persons as the controls. And in these two groups we have to assess for the presence of the risk factor – that is whether they were ordering food or not.

 

  • In a case control study, selection of controls is a prerequisite
  • If the study group is small, choose up to 4 controls per case (In larger studies with equal cost to collect cases and controls 1: 1 is sufficient)
  • Cases are diseased individuals; Controls are those free from the disease under study
  • Controls must be similar to cases, as much as possible except for the absence of disease under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

Including both obese and non-obese individuals in the study is crucial to effectively explore the relationship between online food ordering habits and obesity, ensuring a balanced perspective between affected and control groups.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycetoma

 

The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

 

Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive, and debilitating infectious disease that affects the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, caused by fungi or bacteria. It is also known as "Madura foot" or "Maduromycosis". The disease is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and South America.

 

Mycetoma typically begins with a painless swelling of the affected area, which slowly increases in size over time. The swelling is often accompanied by drainage of pus or other fluid, and the affected tissue may become hard and fibrous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat lesion with a scaly, crusted surface, which does not fit the presentation of multiple sinuses and swelling as seen in the image.

 

 

Option C. Nocardia: Nocardia can cause cutaneous infections but typically presents with abscesses and nodules rather than the large, sinuous, swollen mass seen in Mycetoma.

 

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, usually presents as nodular lesions along lymphatic channels, which can ulcerate. It does not typically present with the large, deforming swelling seen in Mycetoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma, also known as "Madura foot," is a chronic infectious disease causing progressive swelling, multiple sinuses, and deformity, predominantly affecting tropical and subtropical regions.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins increases the absorption of iron from the stomach? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C increases the absorption of iron from the stomach whereas phytates, tannates and oxalates inhibit the absorption of iron from the stomach. Vitamin C is particularly effective in increasing the bioavailability of non-heme iron, the type of iron predominantly found in plant-based foods. This characteristic makes Vitamin C essential for improving overall iron status, especially in individuals at risk for or suffering from iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While Vitamin A is crucial for vision, immune function, and skin health, and is a fat-soluble vitamin requiring dietary fats for absorption, it does not facilitate iron absorption. However, it's important to note that the overall nutritional status, including adequate vitamin A levels, can influence general health and may indirectly impact nutrient absorption processes.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12's absorption is uniquely dependent on the presence of Castle’s intrinsic factor, a glycoprotein secreted by the stomach's parietal cells, which binds to Vitamin B12 and allows its absorption in the terminal ileum. Although Vitamin B12 is essential for red blood cell production and neurological function, it does not play a role in enhancing iron absorption.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Known for its role in calcium absorption and bone health, Vitamin D increases the absorption of calcium from the gastrointestinal tract. Like Vitamin A, Vitamin D is also fat-soluble and requires dietary fats for its absorption. However, it does not increase iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin D increases the absorption of Calcium.

  • Vitamin B12 absorption is affected by presence of Castle’s intrinsic factor in the stomach.

  • Vitamin A absorption is dependent on fat.

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat-soluble vitamins and requires fat for their absorption.

  • Vitamin C is vital for increasing iron absorption from the diet by reducing iron to its more absorbable form and overcoming the inhibitory effects of certain dietary compounds.

questions.text: Collagen derived from cartilage can be classified into? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 collagen

 

Type 2 collagen is a specific type of collagen protein that is primarily found in cartilage, which is a specialized connective tissue & resistant to pressure.

 

This type of collagen is a crucial component of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in cartilage, providing structural support and maintaining the tissue's integrity.

 

Type 2 collagen is responsible for conferring tensile strength to cartilage, making it resistant to compression and deformation. It is a major component of articular cartilage, which covers the ends of bones at synovial joints, as well as other types of cartilage in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 Collagen: Type 1 collagen is the most abundant type of collagen in the human body. It is primarily found in skin, tendons, ligaments, bones, and other connective tissues. It is responsible for providing tensile strength to these tissues.

 

Option C. Type 10 Collagen: Type 10 collagen is mainly found in hypertrophic cartilage, which is a stage of cartilage development during endochondral ossification. It plays a role in the mineralization of cartilage and bone growth.

 

Option D. Type 7 Collagen: Type 7 collagen is a component of anchoring fibrils in the skin and mucous membranes. It is crucial for attaching the basement membrane of the epidermis (outer skin layer) to the underlying dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common types of collagens and their locations in the human body:

questions.text: Which of the following volatile anesthetic agents is cardio selective / most preferred in cardiac surgeries? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sevoflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Sevoflurane is the most cardiovascular stable inhalational anesthetic agent, making it the preferred choice for cardiac surgeries. It has a rapid onset and offset, and it does not irritate the airways, which is beneficial for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Sevoflurane has a favorable cardiovascular profile, causing minimal myocardial depression and maintaining hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enflurane:

  • Enflurane is a halogenated ether used as a volatile inhalation anesthetic.
  • It can decrease blood pressure but also has the potential to cause seizures and increase cerebral blood flow, which might not be suitable for some patients, especially with raised intracranial pressure.
  • Enflurane is not the first choice for cardiac surgeries due to its potential for myocardial depression and arrhythmogenic properties.

 

Option C. Nitrous oxide:

  • Commonly known as "laughing gas", nitrous oxide is an inhaled anesthetic with analgesic properties and is often used in combination with other agents.
  • Nitrous oxide is not a primary anesthetic for major surgeries and is contraindicated in some situations, such as pneumothorax, due to its expansive properties.
  • It is not specifically cardio selective.

 

Option D. Desflurane:

  • Desflurane is a volatile inhalation anesthetic similar to sevoflurane but with a much lower blood/gas solubility, resulting in rapid onset and offset of action.
  • Desflurane can cause an increase in heart rate and blood pressure upon induction and thus might not be the first choice for patients with cardiac diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sevoflurane is the most cardiovascular stable inhalational anesthetic agent and is preferred for cardiac surgeries due to its rapid onset and offset, minimal airway irritation, and favorable cardiovascular profile.

questions.text: At a national public health forum focused on enhancing immunization surveys, an epidemiologist emphasizes the foundational steps for conducting effective research. He queries the group on the initial action to take for ensuring a systematic approach that captures a representative sample. What is this preliminary step? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Identify cluster

 

Among the given options, identifying clusters is the earliest step to be done while conducting an immunization survey.

 

Steps in Immunization survey are as follows:

 

  • Planning based on national immunization schedule
  • Select the age group of children to be evaluated
  • Decide which sources of information to use
  • Decide how many interviewers are needed and the length of the survey
  • Identify clusters
  • Select the starting household
  • Select subsequent houses
  • Complete the cluster forms
  • Complete the summary forms
  • Analyse data

 

Educational Objective:

 

In planning an immunization survey, the identification of clusters is a critical early step that sets the foundation for effective sampling and data collection, ultimately ensuring the survey’s success and the reliability of its findings.

choices.text: Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake
Kwashiorkor due to less calorie intake
Marasmus due to low protein and calorie intake
Marasmus with low calorie intake

questions.text: The condition seen in this child could be due to which of the following? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

The clinical case and the image of malnourished toddler with an enlarged abdomen suggests the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor, it is due to less protein intake.

 

  • Kwashiorkor is a acute severe malnutrition (SAM) that is characterized by edema and apathy.
  • Infants and young children are typically affected, most frequently between the time of weaning and age 5.
  • Children with kwashiorkor have faces that resemble the moon.
  • Edema is most likely to start in the feet and lower legs before spreading to the entire body. Hepatomegaly, fatty infiltration, and dilated bowel loops can all cause abdominal distension.
  • the skin changes include flaky paint dermatosis, often known as crazy paving, which is characterized by dark, peeling, cracked patches with pale skin beneath.
  • The hair is fine, thin, brittle, and readily pulled out. It might stop curling. Children with dark hair may experience a reddish or light hair change. The "flag sign" is made up of bands of hair that alternate between being light and being normal in colour.
  • Children frequently refuse to eat and are unhappy and apathetic.
  • Both growth retardation and muscular atrophy are clearly seen.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kwashiorkor due to less calorie intake: Incorrect. Kwashiorkor is specifically due to a deficiency in protein intake rather than calories alone.

 

Option C. Marasmus due to low protein and calorie intake: Incorrect. Marasmus is a condition caused by severe malnutrition due to both protein and calorie deficiency. It presents with severe wasting and loss of muscle mass, without edema.

 

Option D. Marasmus with low calorie intake: Incorrect. While Marasmus is indeed due to low calorie intake, it is characterized by severe wasting and emaciation, not the edema and hepatomegaly seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, an enlarged abdomen, and apathy due to severe protein deficiency, whereas Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting due to deficiencies in both protein and calories.

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown below in the X-ray radiograph of a neonate? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

The image in the scenario depicts the Morgagni hernia, which is a retrosternal hernia which is a anterior diaphragm abnormality.

 

The most common type of it is bochdalek hernia.

 

It is due to the pleuroperitoneal membrane defect in the Posterolateral aspect.

 

Whereas Morgagni hernia is due to the Anterior pleuroperitoneal membrane defect.

 

Pathophysiology and cause

 

  • Cause is unknown
  • Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing embryo Abdominal contents herniate and compress the ipsilateral developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension.

 

Types of congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Mild to severe respiratory distress
  • Tachypnea, cyanosis, dyspnea
  • Absent breath sound.
  • Shock.

 

Three general presentations:

 

Severe respiratory distress Severe respiratory distress at the time of birth. (Severe hypoplasia) Respiratory deterioration hours after delivery (honeymoon period). Benefit from correction of hypoxemia and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Diagnosis: Therapeutic Symptoms Radiographic study.

 

Prenatally as early as 25 weeks of gestation.

 

Therapeutic:

 

The first stages in treatment are the insertion of an orogastric tube and the preservation of the airway (intubation).

 

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used as part of the treatment strategy on occasion; normally, the newborn would be placed on a ventilator right away.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumomediastinum: Pneumomediastinum is a condition characterized by the presence of air or gas in the mediastinum, Pneumomediastinum can be caused by various factors, including trauma to the chest, medical procedures, certain lung diseases such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis will have history of recurrent URTI, LRTI with pneumonia. Diagnostic test is elevated sweat chloride levels > 60 mEq/L

 

Option D. Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis will have a happy child with fast breathing. Chest x ray will show a hyperinflated chest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a condition where abdominal organs herniate into the chest cavity through a defect in the diaphragm, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition – Page No- 3855-3856

questions.text: Painless lesions over the vulval area as shown below are suggestive of?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Condyloma acuminata

 

The probable diagnosis is Condyloma acuminata.

 

  • Genital warts are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV-6 > HPV-11).
  • It is also called venereal warts or condyloma acuminata and has high infectivity. It is acquired most commonly after sexual contact but may also occur non-sexually.

 

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.
  • The treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts with imiquimod cream via topical immunomodulation is approved.
  • An FDA-approved medication called imiquimod induces apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells by stimulating their toll-like receptors 7 and 8

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genital herpes:

 

  • Caused by the herpes simplex virus.
  • Typically presents as painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitals or surrounding areas as depicted in the image below.

 

  • The lesions are not verrucous (wart-like).

 

Option C. Condyloma lata:

 

  • Secondary syphilis manifestation.
  • These lesions are flat, broad, whitish, and wart-like, but they differ from the more verrucous nature of condyloma acuminata. They are moist and may be found in skin folds as depicted in the image below.

 

  • While they can be painless and somewhat wart-like, they don't have the typical appearance of condylomata acuminata.

 

Option D. Gonococcal vulvovaginitis:

 

  • Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Presents with purulent vaginal discharge and can be associated with dysuria or pelvic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata is diagnosed by the characteristic appearance of painless, warty lesions on the genital area, distinguishing them from other causes of genital lesions such as Genital herpes, Condyloma lata, and Gonococcal vulvovaginitis.

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.56, 25.58

Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition Page no70

questions.text: During a community medicine rotation in a rural village in Uttar Pradesh, MBBS students participated in a health camp where a woman with complicated obstetric issues was identified. She needed specialized care not available at the primary care level of the camp. The students inquired about the first referral unit in the primary health care system where this woman should be taken for specialized care. What is the appropriate referral unit for such cases? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Community Health Centre

 

Community Health Centres (CHC) are the designated first referral units in India's primary healthcare system for handling specialized care requirements that exceed the capabilities of Primary Health Centres (PHC).

 

Levels of Primary Health Care System in India

 

• Primary Level of Health Care:

  • Is ‘first level of contact between population and health care system’ in India
  • Health services are delivered through:
  • Sub-centre
  • Primary Health Centre

• Secondary Level of Health Care:

  • Is ‘First referral level of health care’ in India
  • Health services are delivered through: Community Health Centre

• Tertiary Level of Health Care:

  • Is ‘Second referral level of health care’ in India
  • Health services are delivered through: Medical Colleges and Hospitals

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

First referral units in primary health care in India are community health centres

questions.text: What is the complication associated with IV bolus oxytocin? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotension

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hypotension: The effects of oxytocin IV bolus include hypotension. Bolus IV injections of oxytocin cause hypotension especially when the patient is hypovolemic or has heart disease. Occasionally, oxytocin may produce anginal pain. Oxytocin is therefore given as diluted solutions at a set rate to avoid these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Oxytocin does not typically cause hypertension; instead, it can lead to hypotension due to its vasodilatory effects when administered as an IV bolus.

 

Option C. Hyperglycemia: Hyperglycemia is not a known side effect of oxytocin administration. Oxytocin primarily affects uterine contractility and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is not associated with oxytocin administration. Oxytocin's side effects are more related to its effects on the uterus and cardiovascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IV bolus administration of oxytocin can cause hypotension, particularly in hypovolemic patients or those with heart disease, and should be given as diluted solutions at a controlled rate.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 574

questions.text: A patient with intellectual disability was found to have hyperuricemia. Self-mutilation behavior was also noticed. Which of the following enzyme is deficient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HGPRT

 

HGPRT: The child is exhibiting the symptoms of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, which is due to deficiency of HGPRT (hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) activity. Patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome often have intellectual disability, behavioral disturbances including self-mutilation, and hyperuricemia due to the overproduction of uric acid. Partial deficiency of HGPRT causes Kelly Seegmiller syndrome with only increased uric acid levels but no self-mutilation behavior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha galactosidase-A: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Fabry disease, a genetic disorder that affects lipid metabolism. It's characterized by symptoms like pain, kidney failure, heart issues, and skin lesions, but not typically by intellectual disability, hyperuricemia, or self-mutilation.

 

Option B. Glucocerebrosidase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes Gaucher's disease, which is another lysosomal storage disease. It leads to the accumulation of glucocerebrosides in cells, causing symptoms like enlarged liver and spleen, bone pain and fractures, and neurological complications. However, it is not typically associated with hyperuricemia or self-mutilation.

 

Option D. Sphingomyelinase: This enzyme deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, another lysosomal storage disorder. It primarily affects lipid metabolism, leading to symptoms like enlarged liver and spleen, neurological decline, and lung disease. However, it doesn't typically present with hyperuricemia or self-mutilation behavior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HGPRT will convert the free bases hypoxanthine, or guanine, plus PRPP (5′-phosphoribosyl 1′-pyrophosphate) to the nucleotides IMP, or GMP, plus pyrophosphate in Salvage pathway.
  • Complete deficiency of HGPRT leads to Lesch Nyhan syndrome with clinical features of increased uric acid levels and self-mutilation behavior due to neurotoxic nature of increased PRPP.

 

Ref: Harper 30th/e pg. 820

questions.text: A mother complains of breast cramps during breastfeeding her child. Which hormone is responsible for this? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

Oxytocin helps in milk ejection by causing myoepithelial contraction, which is responsible for the cramps during breastfeeding. Oxytocin activates the Milk Let Down Reflex—suckling by the baby triggers touch receptors on the mother's breast, which stimulate the hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the contraction of myoepithelial cells in the breast tissue, leading to the compression of lobules and the subsequent ejection of milk.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is responsible for alveolar growth in the breast but does not play a role in causing cramps during breastfeeding.


Option B. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is responsible for ductal growth in the breast but does not cause cramps during breastfeeding.


Option C. Prolactin: Incorrect. Prolactin is responsible for milk production. It stimulates the breast alveolar epithelial cells to synthesize milk components, including lactose, casein, and lipids, but does not cause cramps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin helps in milk ejection by myoepithelial contraction which is responsible for cramp during breastfeeding

 

  1. Function of oxytocin – milk ejection (Galactokinesis)
    • Uterine contraction
    • Oxytocin activates Milk Let down Reflex – Suckling by baby triggers touch receptors of mother’s breast, which further stimulate hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release Oxytocin. Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells of breast tissue, leads to compression of lobules followed by ejection of milk.
  2. Function of prolactin – milk production
    • Prolactin stimulates the breast alveolar epithelial cells to synthesize milk components, including lactose (i.e., the carbohydrate of milk), casein (i.e., the protein of milk), and lipids.
    • The prolactin receptors are down-regulated on mammary glandular tissue during periods of elevated progesterone levels (i.e., during pregnancy).
  3. Progesterone is responsible for alveolar growth
  4. Estrogen is responsible for ductal growth

choices.text: Right ventricular myocardial infarction

questions.text: Pulsus paradoxus is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe asthma

 

Pulsus paradoxus is an exaggerated decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. Normally, systolic blood pressure drops by about 3 to 5 mm Hg during inspiration, but in pulsus paradoxus, the SBP drop is more than 10 mm Hg with normal breathing. This phenomenon is primarily associated with conditions that affect the pressure dynamics within the thorax.

 

The most important conditions associated with pulsus paradoxus are:

 

  • Acute severe asthma/acute COPD: This condition leads to significant variations in intrathoracic pressure, which can exaggerate the normal inspiratory drop in systolic blood pressure.
  • Cardiac tamponade: This is a medical emergency where fluid accumulation in the pericardium compresses the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration.

 

While other conditions like constrictive pericarditis, acute pulmonary embolism, right ventricular myocardial infarction, and tension pneumothorax can also cause pulsus paradoxus, they are less commonly tested or emphasized in exams compared to acute severe asthma and cardiac tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coronary artery disease: This condition primarily affects the blood supply to the heart muscle, leading to chest pain or myocardial infarction, but it does not typically cause pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option C. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Although literature mentions pulsus paradoxus can occur in some cases of restrictive cardiomyopathy, it is not a primary feature and is less relevant for exams.

 

Option D. Right ventricular myocardial infarction: This condition can lead to right heart failure and significant hemodynamic changes but is not a common cause of pulsus paradoxus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus paradoxus is an important clinical sign primarily associated with acute severe asthma and cardiac tamponade. Recognizing these associations is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: In which of the following disorder, ATP 7A protein is deficient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Menke’s Kinky hair syndrome

 

This is caused by a deficiency in the ATP7A protein. ATP7A is a copper-transporting ATPase, and its deficiency leads to a disturbance in copper metabolism.

 

Clinical features 

 

  • Premature birth
  • Hypotonia
  • Growth retardation
  • Mental retardation
  • Grey depigmented hair: tyrosinase (an oxidase) is affected as oxidases require Cu. But tyrosinase is required for synthesis of Melanin. So, melanin synthesis is decreased causing grey hair
  • Brittle kinky hair: As lysyl oxidase affected, so defective and weak collagen synthesis
  • Decreased Cu in blood and urine

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson’s hepatolenticular degeneration: This disorder is caused by a deficiency in the ATP7B protein.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Cu accumulates in liver causing liver damage
  • When excess in liver, ↑ Cu can go to other extrahepatic tissues and cause following changes:
    • In Brain – Neurological degeneration
    • In Kidneys- Renal damage, urolithiasis
    • In Bone marrow & RBC – Hemolytic anemia
    • In Eyes –
      • Sunflower cataract
      • Kayser-Fleisher (KF) rings – green/golden ring in Descemet’s membrane of cornea due to Cu deposition

 

 

Option B. Selenosis: This condition is related to excessive intake of selenium and is not due to a deficiency in the ATP7A protein. Selenosis can lead to symptoms such as hair loss, nail brittleness, and neurological abnormalities, but it is caused by an excess of selenium, not a genetic defect in copper metabolism.

 

Option D. Bronze diabetes: Also known as hemochromatosis, this condition is characterized by iron overload and is not related to a deficiency in ATP7A. It typically results from a genetic defect that leads to increased iron absorption, and it is not associated with copper metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disorders of Copper metabolism

 

 

Note: ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) is common between Menke and Wilson Disease

 

Ref: Harper 30th Ed., pg. 676

questions.text: A 24-year-old female came with complains of neurological deficits. Examination reveals pallor. Her blood picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia occurs when a lack of vitamin B12 causes the body to produce abnormally large red blood cells that cannot function properly. This type of anemia is associated with neurological deficits and pallor.

 

Key points about Vitamin B12 deficiency:

 

  • It leads to the production of large, dysfunctional red blood cells.
  • Common symptoms include pallor and neurological deficits due to impaired red blood cell function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: While folate deficiency also leads to megaloblastic anemia, it does not typically cause neurological deficits.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Thalassemia is a genetic disorder that leads to abnormal hemoglobin production, not associated with large red blood cells or neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic hypochromic red blood cells and does not typically cause neurological deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to the production of abnormally large red blood cells and can cause neurological deficits and pallor.

questions.text: A boy presents with features of shock and cold clammy skin. The next step in management is: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Normal saline

 

The next step in management for a boy presenting with features of shock and cold clammy skin would be to administer IV normal saline.

 

 

IV normal saline is the first-line treatment for hypovolemic shock, which can cause cold clammy skin and other features of shock. The saline solution helps to increase blood volume and improve circulation, which can help to reverse the symptoms of shock. Once the patient's condition stabilizes, additional treatments may be necessary depending on the underlying cause of the shock.

 

  • The first line of treatment for shock in children is Intravenous fluids.
  • Up to three normal saline boluses of 20 ml/Kg can be administered.
  • After each bolus, look for symptoms of fluid overload, such as respiratory difficulty or chest pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Dextrose: IV dextrose is not typically used as the initial management for shock. It is primarily used to correct hypoglycemia, not for fluid resuscitation in shock.

 

Option C. Inj. Adrenaline: Inj. Adrenaline (epinephrine) may be used in the management of anaphylactic shock or for patients with cardiac arrest, but it is not the first-line treatment for hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. IV Ringer lactate: IV Ringer lactate is also an appropriate fluid for resuscitation in shock, but IV normal saline is more commonly used initially due to its widespread availability and suitability for most types of shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of treatment for shock in children is intravenous fluids, with normal saline being commonly used initially to stabilize the patient. Up to three normal saline boluses of 20 ml/kg can be administered, monitoring for signs of fluid overload after each bolus.

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Lesch Nyhan syndrome? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase

 

  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase).
  • This enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of uric acid in the body.
  • Clinical features of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome include:
    • Developmental delay
    • Dysarthria (difficulty in articulating words)
    • Dystonia (involuntary muscle contractions)
    • Spasticity
    • Self-mutilation behaviors (such as biting of lips and fingers)
       
  • Management: Treatment involves measures to reduce uric acid levels, such as:
    • Hydration
    • Alkalinization of urine
    • Administration of allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, to decrease uric acid production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. Deficiency in this enzyme leads to xanthinuria, not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Option C. Biotinidase: Biotinidase deficiency causes biotinidase deficiency disorder, which can lead to neurological and dermatological symptoms but is not associated with the specific symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Option D. Aspartate aminotransferase: Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is an enzyme involved in amino acid metabolism. Its deficiency is not linked to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and does not lead to the characteristic symptoms of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase), leading to increased uric acid levels and a range of neurological and behavioral symptoms, including self-mutilation.

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal cartilages is least likely to be calcified?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Epiglottis

 

The epiglottis is least likely to undergo calcification compared to the other listed cartilages. This is primarily because the epiglottis is composed of elastic cartilage, not hyaline cartilage. Elastic cartilage is more flexible and is less prone to calcification. The primary role of the epiglottis is to protect the airway during swallowing by covering the glottis, and its elastic nature is crucial for its function.

 

Other Options Explanation:

 

  • Option A. Thyroid Cartilage: The largest of the laryngeal cartilages, forming the Adam's apple. It is primarily composed of hyaline cartilage, which is known to calcify or even ossify with age. Calcification commonly begins around the age of 25 and can be extensive by the age of 65. This process can stiffen the cartilage, which may have implications for surgeries involving the neck.
  • Option B. Cricoid Cartilage: A ring-shaped cartilage that encircles the trachea below the thyroid cartilage. Like the thyroid cartilage, it is made mostly of hyaline cartilage. Calcification of the cricoid cartilage also typically begins in early adulthood and can be quite advanced by elderly age, affecting the rigidity and structure of the laryngeal framework.
  • Option C. Arytenoid Cartilages: These are paired cartilages located at the back of the larynx, which play a key role in vocal cord movement. Most of the arytenoid cartilage is hyaline but the tips near the corniculate cartilages are elastic. The hyaline portions of the arytenoids are prone to calcification as one ages, similar to the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, though it usually starts a bit later than the thyroid cartilage.

 

Educational Objective

 

Thyroid, cricoid and most of the arytenoid cartilages are hyaline cartilages whereas epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform and tip of arytenoid near the corniculate cartilage are elastic fibrocartilage.

 

Hyaline cartilages can undergo ossification. it begins at the age of 25 years in thyroid, a little later in cricoid and arytenoids, and is complete by 65 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shown below has a false positive Barr body? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klinefelter’s syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Due to the additional X chromosome associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47XXY), the patient receives a false-positive Barr body test result.
  • The inactive X chromosome, known as the Barr body, is located peripherally in the cell as a darkly pigmented nodule, is chromatin positive, and is best observed in the nuclei of epithelial cells.
  • Male cells are referred to as chromatin negative because they lack a Barr body and only have one X chromosome.
  • Given that the inactivated X chromosome is regarded as the Barr body, the total number of Barr bodies can be calculated using the formula (X-1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Turner's syndrome: karyotype 45 XO , No Barr body

 

Option C. Down’s syndrome and Option D. Edward's syndrome are aneuploidies involving autosomes ( non-sex chromosomes ) downs is trisomy 21 and Edwards is trisomy 18.

 

*In Triple X syndromes there will be two Barr bodies (two X chromosomes will get inactivated)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Klinefelter syndrome (47XXY) results in a false-positive Barr body test due to the presence of an additional X chromosome.

 

 Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg444

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the following finding shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypo-estrogenic state

 

The image shows a condition called palmar erythema, which is characterized by redness of the palms. Palmar erythema can be caused by various conditions including rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, and liver cirrhosis. These conditions often result in increased levels of estrogen, leading to the vasodilation and increased blood flow that cause the redness observed in palmar erythema.

 

Hypo-estrogenic state do not cause palmar erythema. Instead, palmar erythema is associated with hyper-estrogenic state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: This autoimmune condition can lead to palmar erythema due to increased vascularity and inflammation

 

Option B. Pregnancy: Elevated estrogen levels during pregnancy can cause palmar erythema.

 

Option C. Liver cirrhosis: Liver disease often results in elevated estrogen levels, which can cause palmar erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palmar erythema is commonly associated with conditions that lead to increased estrogen levels, such as pregnancy, liver cirrhosis, and rheumatoid arthritis. Hypo-estrogenic states do not cause palmar erythema.

choices.text: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

questions.text: A newborn child presents with respiratory distress and gurgling sounds in chest on auscultation. The chest Xray is given below. Identify the condition?  (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect where there is a hole in the diaphragm, the muscle that helps with breathing. This hole allows abdominal organs, such as the intestines, stomach, and liver, to move into the chest cavity. This displacement can severely impede lung development, leading to respiratory distress shortly after birth. The gurgling sounds in the chest on auscultation are due to the presence of bowel loops in the thoracic cavity. On a chest X-ray, CDH typically presents with bowel loops or stomach in the chest cavity, which can be seen as air-filled structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax occurs when air leaks into the space between the lung and chest wall, causing the lung to collapse. On a chest X-ray, this appears as a clear space without lung markings where the lung has collapsed, often with a visible line marking the edge of the collapsed lung. This condition typically presents with sudden onset of sharp, unilateral chest pain and dyspnea, but not with gurgling sounds.

Option C. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardium (the sac around the heart), leading to impaired heart function. On a chest X-ray, one might observe an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle" shape). However, the primary diagnostic tool for cardiac tamponade is an echocardiogram, and it typically does not present with respiratory distress and gurgling sounds in the chest.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus. It often presents with excessive air in the stomach and intestines due to the passage of air from the trachea into the esophagus. On a chest X-ray, there might be evidence of excessive air in the stomach and intestines, but it would not show bowel loops in the chest cavity. Symptoms include coughing, choking during feeding, and recurrent respiratory infections, but it typically does not present with gurgling chest sounds due to bowel contents in the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) presents with respiratory distress and bowel sounds in the chest due to abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity, which can be confirmed by a chest X-ray showing bowel loops in the chest.

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is associated with which of the following? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

Explanation:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to

 

  •  
  1. Renal anomalies like
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys
    • Bilateral Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease
  2. Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes PPROM)
  3. Drugs like ACE inhibitors or ARB as these cause fetal renal hypoplasia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neural tube defect: Open Neural tube defects will cause polyhydramnios

 

Option C. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia will cause polyhydramnios
