Option D. Preterm birth: Preterm birth is seen more commonly in women who have polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oligohydramnios is associated with renal anomalies such as bilateral renal agenesis, which leads to decreased fetal urine production and a significant reduction in amniotic fluid.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 250,251

questions.text: 50-year-old woman presented to the medicine OPD with complaints of muscle weakness and blurring of vision following exertion more towards the evening. On examination, the patient had ptosis. The symptoms improved after edrophonium test. The person is likely suffering from? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia gravis

 

  • The symptoms of muscle weakness, blurring of vision and ptosis particularly towards the evening, with improvement on edrophonium test point towards the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is an auto immune disease due to formation of antibodies against the post synaptic Ach receptors. The characteristic features of muscle weakness with activity and improvement with rest are hallmarks in myasthenia.

  • Edrophonium, a short-acting anticholinesterase agent is used for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. It is also called the tensilon test. It leads to an increase in the level of Acetylcholine at the receptor sites, which subsequently leads to an improvement in the muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Syndrome: It is an autoimmune condition characterized by autoantibodies against the voltage gated presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced ACh release. Repeated muscle use improves the condition and there is no effect of Edrophonium.

 

Option C. Guillain-Barré syndrome: It is an autoimmune condition characterized by antibodies against the myelin sheath. It generally follows a viral infection and manifests as ascending paralysis. Edrophonium plays no role in the management of this disease.

 

Option D. Bronchial asthma: doesn’t present with the features of muscular weakness and diplopia. Edrophonium (anti-cholinesterase), if given may worsen the condition of the patient by increasing bronchoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is diagnosed by the presence of characteristic symptoms of muscle weakness that improves with anticholinesterase agents like edrophonium. This disorder requires careful management with medications that improve neuromuscular transmission and may also include immunosuppressants to control the underlying autoimmune process.

questions.text: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after weeks when on a daily corticosteroid therapy regimen? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4-6

 

Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is a condition in which the kidneys do not respond to corticosteroid treatment, leading to persistent proteinuria and edema. SRNS is defined as the failure to achieve remission after a certain duration of daily corticosteroid therapy. The definition and criteria for SRNS are as follows:

 

  • Failure to achieve remission after a 4-6 week course of daily corticosteroid therapy is considered SRNS according to various clinical guidelines.
  • According to Indian Pediatric (IP) guidelines, SRNS patients do not achieve remission even after 4-6 weeks of daily steroid therapy.
  • Current recommendations define SRNS as the absence of remission even after 6 weeks of therapy at a dose of 60 mg/m² per day.
  • Nelson and Ghai define SRNS as the absence of remission after treatment with daily prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg per day for 6 weeks, followed by alternate-day dosing for the next 4 weeks, for a total of 8 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SRNS is defined as the failure to achieve remission after 4-6 weeks of daily corticosteroid therapy. Recognizing and diagnosing SRNS is crucial for initiating alternative treatments and managing the condition effectively.

questions.text: Lady developed painless beefy red genital ulcer with swelling in inguinal area. On biopsy, safety pin appearance was noted. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Granuloma inguinale

 

Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

 

  • The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no inguinal lymphadenopathy, but a subcutaneous swelling (Pseudobubo) is classical for Granuloma inguinale.
  • The primary ulcer, if left untreated, heals spontaneously with scarring, or persists and spreads.
  • Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.
  • Granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Calymmatobacter granulomatis / Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.
  • Donovan bodies refer to the Gram-negative rod-shaped or oval organisms that show bipolar staining or safety-pin appearance, present intracellularly in the cytoplasm of large mononuclear cells.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

 

  • Caused by certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Initially, it may present as a self-limited painless genital ulcer, but it is followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, or "buboes." The nodes can rupture and form sinuses and fistulas.
  • LGV does not produce beefy red ulcers or the safety pin appearance on biopsy, which distinguishes it from granuloma inguinale.

 

Option C. Syphilis:

 

  • Caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.
  • Primary syphilis presents as a painless, clean-based ulcer known as a chancre. The ulcer is typically firm and indurated.
  • There is no beefy red appearance or safety pin appearance in the biopsy associated with syphilis.

 

Option D. Chancroid

 

  • Caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It presents as multiple painful genital ulcers as shown below

 

 

  • It is often associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Unlike granuloma inguinale, chancroid ulcers are painful and do not have the safety pin appearance on biopsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale is the likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with painless beefy red genital ulcers, supported by characteristic histopathology findings.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.25

questions.text: In a discussion about the funding sources for India's National Tuberculosis Program, it's noted that one global organization, despite its wide influence, does not directly contribute financially to this program. Which organization is it? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. UNICEF

 

UNICEF doesn’t fund National TB program of India.

 

Government of India, World Bank and Global Fund provide budget to obtain drugs, diagnostic equipments and certain work force for the National TB program.

 

Additional Information

 

UNICEF

 

 

  • Headquarters: New York.
  • UNICEF is promoting ‘GOBI Campaign’ to encourage
  • 4 strategies for a ‘Child Health Revolution’:
    • G: Growth Charts (to better monitor child development)
    • O: Oral Rehydration (to treat mild and moderate dehydration)
    • B: Breast Feeding
    • I: Immunization (against TB, Polio, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus and Measles)
  • GOBI-FFF Campaign:
    • F: Female Education
    • F: Family Spacing
    • F: Food Supplements
  • For applied nutrition program, seeds and manure supply under school health services has been done by UNICEF
  • District border cluster strategy is supported by UNICEF

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indian Government: Directly funds the program as a crucial part of its public health strategy.

 

Option C. Global Fund: Actively contributes to combating tuberculosis, HIV and malaria, globally, and ensure a healthier, safer, more equitable future for all.

 

Option D. World Bank: Provides both financial and technical assistance to India's tuberculosis control programs as part of its broader support for health sector projects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While UNICEF plays a crucial role in improving child health globally, it does not directly fund tuberculosis programs, focusing instead on primary health care and preventative measures that can indirectly benefit TB control efforts.

questions.text: Takayasu arteritis most commonly involves: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arch of aorta

 

Takayasu arteritis is a type of large vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects the aorta and its major branches. It is also known as "aortic arch syndrome" or "pulseless disease". The inflammation leads to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysms of the involved arteries.

 

The disease most commonly involves the arch of the aorta and the vessels that branch from it. The subclavian artery is the most frequently affected vessel, which can lead to arm pain, claudication, and an absence of the radial pulse. This absence of a pulse is a hallmark of the disease and gives rise to the term "pulseless disease."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary artery: Takayasu arteritis rarely involves the pulmonary arteries. The primary focus is usually the aorta and its major branches.

 

Option B. Coronary arteries: While coronary arteries can be affected, they are not the most common site of involvement in Takayasu arteritis. The primary target is the aorta and its immediate branches.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta: Although the abdominal aorta can be involved, it is less commonly affected compared to the arch of the aorta in Takayasu arteritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis most commonly involves the arch of the aorta and its branches, particularly the subclavian artery, leading to its nickname "pulseless disease" due to the characteristic absence of the radial pulse.

questions.text: A 3 months old baby is brought to you for an eye examination due to a concern raised by the mother. She noticed that the baby's left upper eyelid exhibits repetitive movement described as going "up and down" specifically during breastfeeding. The paediatrician initially diagnosed the baby with left eye ptosis. However, upon your examination, you observe an interesting phenomenon as shown in the given image. What is this phenomenon called?(FMGE June 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking

 

Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking - where the ptosis disappears when the baby opens their mouth or sucks their thumb

It is a rare condition characterized by an aberrant connection between the trigeminal and oculomotor nerves, resulting in involuntary eyelid movement during jaw movements.

 

Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. The vast majority are unilateral.

Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.

Signs: Retraction of the ptotic lid with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement, less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth, Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symblepharon:

 

  • Description: Adhesion between the palpebral conjunctiva and the bulbar conjunctiva.
  • Signs: Does not involve ptosis or jaw movements.

 

Option B. Blepharophimosis syndrome:

 

  • Description: Congenital condition characterized by narrow palpebral fissures, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus.
  • Signs: Does not involve the characteristic jaw-winking phenomenon.

 

Option C. Lagophthalmos:

 

  • Description: Inability to completely close the eyelids.
  • Signs: Does not involve repetitive eyelid movement during jaw movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus-Gunn jaw-winking syndrome is characterized by an involuntary upward movement of the eyelid in response to jaw movements. It is due to an abnormal neural connection and often presents with congenital ptosis. Recognizing this phenomenon is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: A small town in Uttarakhand is revising its water treatment protocols to ensure safe drinking water. They aim to accurately measure both active and inactive forms of chlorine to maintain effective disinfection levels. For this purpose, they are advised to use a specific chemical test. Which test is used to measure both active and residual chlorine levels in water? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Free chlorine & combined chlorine

 

OT test: The reagent used in chloroscope is Orthotoluidine. It measures free chlorine (within 10 seconds) and free + combined chlorine (15-20 mins) in water.

 

Tests for chlorination of water:

 

  • Ortho-toluidine (OT) Test
  • Ortho-toluidine Arsenite (OTA) Test: Measure the levels of Free chlorine and Combined chlorine

 

OTA test is better than OT test as:

 

  • Detects both free and combined chlorine separately
  • Not affected by interfering substances (nitrites, iron, manganese).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Orthotoluidine test is used to measure both free chlorine and combined chlorine in water, offering a comprehensive analysis critical for effective water disinfection management.

questions.text: A couple presented in the outpatient department with infertility. The husband's semen analysis done was normal. The wife reported menorrhagia and a hysterosalpingogram showed distal dilatation of the tubes like a 'tobacco pouch appearance'. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tubal salpingitis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Tubal salpingitis: The 'tobacco pouch appearance' seen on the hysterosalpingogram is characteristic of tubal salpingitis, particularly tubercular salpingitis. This appearance results from the dilation of the ampulla of the fallopian tube, leading to a retort-like shape. The tubes are typically filled with a transparent fluid. The fimbrial end of the tube is indrawn and closed, while the interstitial end remains open. Tubal salpingitis can cause infertility by damaging the fallopian tubes, preventing the sperm from reaching the egg or the fertilized egg from reaching the uterus.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tubal endometriosis: Tubal endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the fallopian tubes. While it can lead to tubal damage and infertility, it does not typically present with a 'tobacco pouch appearance' on hysterosalpingogram. Instead, it may show tubal obstruction or hydrosalpinx.

 

Option C. Tubal polyp: Tubal polyps are benign growths within the fallopian tube that can cause obstruction and infertility. They do not cause the characteristic 'tobacco pouch appearance' on hysterosalpingogram. The presence of polyps is usually identified through imaging techniques or laparoscopy.

 

Option D. Tubal spasm: Tubal spasm can occur during hysterosalpingography due to irritation or anxiety and can temporarily mimic tubal obstruction. However, it does not lead to a 'tobacco pouch appearance' and is usually transient, resolving with the relaxation of the patient or administration of antispasmodic agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 'tobacco pouch appearance' on hysterosalpingogram is characteristic of tubal salpingitis, specifically tubercular salpingitis, which is a common cause of tubal factor infertility.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 141

choices.text: Local treatment of wound + immunoglobulin + vaccine

questions.text: Dr. Kavita, a rural gynecologist in Madhya Pradesh, is approached by a pregnant patient who was scratched by a stray dog, which the local villagers suspect to be rabid. Understanding the critical nature of the situation, especially during pregnancy, Dr. Kavita needs to decide the safest and most effective treatment to minimize any risk from rabies. What is the best course of action? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Local treatment of wound + vaccination

 

In the case of a pregnant woman scratched by a potentially rabid animal, the appropriate management includes immediate local treatment of the wound combined with vaccination. This course of action aligns with established guidelines for Category II exposure (minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding), where immediate vaccination is recommended. It is important to note that pregnancy is not a contraindication for rabies vaccination, making it safe to administer to protect both the mother and the unborn child from the risk of rabies.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For scratches potentially contaminated by rabies, especially in pregnant women, the recommended treatment is thorough local cleaning of the wound and immediate vaccination. Pregnancy does not preclude the use of rabies vaccines, which are vital for preventing the development of the disease.

questions.text: In this image of basal ganglia, all of the following are correctly labelled except? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4- Internal Capsule

 

All are marked correctly except Option D which is External capsule and not internal capsule.

Internal Capsule: The internal capsule is a white matter tract that contains both ascending and descending nerve fibers. It serves as a major highway for communication between different regions of the brain, including the cortex and subcortical structures like the basal ganglia. The internal capsule is crucial for transmitting motor and sensory information.

 

External capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that surrounds and separates parts of the basal ganglia, including the putamen and globus pallidus, from the overlying insular cortex. It contains white matter tracts that connect various regions of the cortex to the basal ganglia and other subcortical structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped structure that is part of the basal ganglia. It is involved in various functions, including motor control, regulation of voluntary movements, and cognitive processes. The caudate nucleus is one of the components of the striatum.

 

Option B. 2. Globus Pallidus: The globus pallidus is a structure within the basal ganglia that is involved in motor control and regulation of movement. It is divided into two segments: the external globus pallidus (GPe) and the internal globus pallidus (GPi). These segments have different functions within the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

Option C. 3. Putamen: The putamen is another component of the striatum, along with the caudate nucleus. It is involved in motor control and coordination. The putamen and the caudate nucleus work together as part of the basal ganglia circuitry to modulate motor output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal Ganglia -

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It doesn't account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antigens to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure

 

Antigenic drift causes gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

 

Antigenic drift refers to the gradual and continuous process of genetic mutations that lead to changes in the antigenic properties of pathogens, particularly viruses like influenza. This process results in small, incremental changes in the virus's surface proteins (antigens), allowing the virus to evade the immune system of previously infected or vaccinated individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It doesn't account for the periodic epidemics of influenza: This statement is false. Antigenic drift is one of the primary reasons for the periodic epidemics of influenza. The gradual changes in the virus's antigens mean that people can get infected repeatedly over time, even if they have some immunity from past infections or vaccinations.

 

Option C. The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens: This statement is false. The new antigens formed through antigenic drift are related to the previous antigens but have slight variations. These variations are enough to evade the immune response but not so drastic that they are completely unrelated.

 

Option D. Antigens to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants: This statement is partially true. While antigenic drift does result in variants that can escape neutralization by antibodies to some extent, cross-protection can still occur to varying degrees. The immune system may still recognize and respond to the new variants, but not as effectively as it did to the predecessor viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigenic drift involves gradual and sequential changes in the antigenic structure of viruses, particularly influenza, leading to periodic epidemics and partial evasion of immune responses from previous infections or vaccinations.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing in the garden. On disturbing bee hives, he had several bee stings. After a few minutes, the child developed breathing difficulty and hypotension. What is the drug of choice for managing the child in this condition? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adrenaline

 

  • Difficulty in breathing and hypotension following bee sting indicates development of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction and warrants immediate resuscitative measures.
  • Intramuscular injection of adrenaline at a concentration of 1:1000 (undiluted) is drug of choice for anaphylactic shock.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dobutamine: This drug is primarily used in cases of heart failure and cardiogenic shock due to its inotropic (strengthening heart muscle contraction) properties but is not suitable for treating anaphylaxis, as it does not address severe allergic reactions effectively.

 

Option C. Noradrenaline (norepinephrine): While noradrenaline is a potent vasoconstrictor and can raise blood pressure, it does not have the bronchodilatory effects needed for treating anaphylaxis, where airway constriction can be life-threatening.

 

Option D. Isoprenaline: This medication is a beta agonist used primarily to treat bradycardia (slow heart rate) and certain types of heart block. Like dobutamine, it lacks the necessary profile to effectively treat anaphylaxis, especially with regards to reversing airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anaphylaxis, especially in children, immediate administration of intramuscular adrenaline is critical. It addresses multiple facets of the allergic reaction by improving breathing, increasing blood pressure, and reducing tissue swelling. Recognizing the signs of anaphylaxis and administering adrenaline promptly can be life-saving.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a lady with extremely low TSH and high T3 and T4? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Graves’ Disease

 

The given history is suggestive of Graves’ disease, which is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism. The presence of extremely low TSH and high T3 and T4 levels are indicative of this condition.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Characterized by a mildly elevated TSH and normal T3 and T4 levels, without significant symptoms of hypothyroidism.

 

Option B. Subclinical hyperthyroidism: Characterized by a mildly suppressed TSH and normal T3 and T4 levels, without significant symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

 

Option D. Subclinical thyroiditis: Typically presents with normal thyroid hormone levels and possible mild inflammation, not consistent with extremely low TSH and high T3 and T4 levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves’ disease is characterized by extremely low TSH and high T3 and T4 levels, indicating hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: Comment on the position of the pacemaker lead. (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The image provided shows an X-ray of a patient with a pacemaker. The pacemaker lead is seen extending from the pacemaker device to the heart. In most cases, whether the pacemaker is temporary or permanent, the lead is typically placed in the right ventricle.

 

  • Single Chamber Pacemaker: The lead is placed in the right ventricle.
  • Dual Chamber Pacemaker: One lead is placed in the right atrium and another in the right ventricle.

 

In this particular X-ray, we see a single lead extending into the right ventricle, indicating it is a single chamber pacemaker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Atrium: In a dual chamber pacemaker, one lead would be in the right atrium, but in the image provided, there is only one lead visible, and it is positioned in the right ventricle.

 

Option C. Left Atrium: Pacemaker leads are not typically placed in the left atrium.

 

Option D. Left Ventricle: Pacemaker leads are not typically placed in the left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacemaker leads are most commonly positioned in the right ventricle for both temporary and permanent pacemakers. In dual chamber pacemakers, an additional lead is placed in the right atrium.

choices.text: History of similar complaint in family members

questions.text: A patient has presented with blister on hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy. What will you ask the patient with regard to history? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) History of exposure to cat

 

Patient with blister on the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy is more suggestive of Cat scratch disease, a disease caused by Bartonella henselae, hence we should ask about the history of exposure to cat.

 

The symptoms of CSD usually begin with a small red bump or pustule at the site of the scratch or bite, followed by swelling of the nearby lymph nodes. The lymph nodes may become tender and may persist for several weeks or even months. Other symptoms can include fever, fatigue, headache, and loss of appetite.

 

Most cases of CSD are self-limiting and resolve on their own within a few weeks, although some individuals may require antibiotics to treat the infection, particularly those with weakened immune systems. In rare cases, complications such as neuroretinitis, encephalopathy, or endocarditis can occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. History of exposure to rat: Exposure to rats might be associated with diseases like rat-bite fever or leptospirosis, but these typically do not present with the specific combination of blister and lymphadenopathy described in this case.

 

Option C. History of similar complaint in family members: A history of similar complaints in family members might suggest a contagious infection or a genetic condition, neither of which fit the presentation of Cat Scratch Disease.

 

Option D. History of tick bite: A history of tick bites might be relevant for diseases like Lyme disease or Rocky Mountain spotted fever, but these diseases do not typically present with a blister and subsequent localized lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient presents with a blister on the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy, it is important to ask about exposure to cats, as this history is highly suggestive of Cat Scratch Disease caused by Bartonella henselae.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman with a past history of Caesarean section and a Dilatation and curettage, presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen and Fetal heart rate is weak. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine rupture

 

  • The above clinical situation is suggestive of uterine rupture.
  • Scar dehiscence and uterine rupture occur in cases with previous caesarean sections, dilatation, and curettage.
  • C/F of rupture uterus
    • Shock (Hypotension and tachycardia)
    • Sudden cessation of contractions
    • Sharp abdominal pain
    • Fresh vaginal bleeding
    • Fetal parts palpable easily
    • Fetal heart rate is usually absent
    • Uterus felt separately/ loss of normal uterine contour
    • Hematuria
    • P/V: loss of station

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid embolization: Amniotic fluid enters maternal circulation through a break in the membranes or placenta. Thromboplastin rich fluid containing debris are deposited in vessels trigger coagulation ultimately leading to DIC.

 

Option B. Placental abruption: It refers to premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It may be revealed or concealed. The uterus is tonically contracted

 

Option D. Local anesthesia anaphylaxis: It is an allergic reaction to drugs used such as lignocaine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine rupture in a woman with a history of Caesarean section or uterine surgery presents with hypotension, tachycardia, severe abdominal pain, palpable fetal parts in the abdomen, and weak or absent fetal heart rate.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 496

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She was informed to have fibroids for a long time. The radiological investigation is shown below. What is the type of degeneration that occurred in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcific degeneration

 

Explanation:

 

  • The X-ray shows calcified fibroids and is due to the calcific degeneration of fibroids.
  • In postmenopausal women, subserous fibroid with tiny pedicle or myomas are the most typical symptoms of calcific or calcareous degeneration.
  • Lime phosphates and carbonates are deposited in the vessels' outermost regions during calcareous degeneration. The best cases of calcareous myomas are those in elderly individuals who have had them for a long time. These resemble "womb-stones" in cemeteries.
  • The most common degeneration seen in fibroids is hyaline
  • The degeneration in fibroids seen in pregnancy is red degeneration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fatty degeneration: fat globules deposited in muscle cells, usually at or after menopause.

 

Option B. Hyaline degeneration: Hyaline Changes in muscle and fibrous tissues, feel becomes soft elastic.

 

Option D. Cystic degeneration: It occurs due to liquefaction of areas with hyaline change. may appear as hypoechoic or anechoiec areas on USG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calcific degeneration of fibroids is characterized by the deposition of lime phosphates and carbonates, typically seen in elderly individuals with long-standing fibroids.

 

Ref: Duttas textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition Page275

questions.text: Mutation in which gene is seen in Wilson disease? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ATP 7B

 

  • Wilson’s disease
  • Autosomal recessive
  • ATP7B gene (copper transport protein, chromosome 13)
  • Abnormal copper accumulation in the body

 

Pathogenesis: - Impaired biliary excretion of copper leads to excessive copper deposition throughout the body.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Jaundice
  • Tremor
  • Personality change
  • Hallucination
  • Infertility
  • Joint pain
  • Physical exam
  • Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
  • Asterixis
  • Chorea
  • Loss of coordination
  • Dementia
  • Pathognomonic Kayser-Fleischer rings 

 

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • liver biopsy not always indicated
  • copper studies
  • ↓ serum ceruloplasmin and ↓ serum copper
  • 24-hour urinary copper ↑ excretion
  • AST:ALT ratio usually > 2

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line -d-penicillamine
  • chelating agent to remove excess copper
  • co-administer with pyridoxine
  • oral zinc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: ATP7A is associated with Menkes disease: Wilson's disease and Menkes disease are both genetic disorders that affect the body's ability to process and utilize copper, but they have distinct differences. Here is a comparison of Wilson's disease and Menkes disease:

 

 

In summary, while both Wilson's disease and Menkes disease affect copper metabolism, they have different genetic inheritances, clinical presentations, and treatment options. Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes copper accumulation, while Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder that causes copper deficiency.

 

Option C. ATP 7C and Option D. ATP 7D is not associated with Wilsons disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutation in ATP7B gene is seen in Wilson disease.

 

Ref - Nelson 20th Edition Page No- 1940.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-depressant drugs act by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and nor-adrenaline? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Venlafaxine

 

Venlafaxine belongs to the class of drugs known as serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs). It works by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and noradrenaline in the brain, which helps to elevate mood and alleviate the symptoms of depression. SNRIs are particularly effective in treating major depressive disorders by enhancing the levels of these two neurotransmitters in the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: This is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It specifically targets serotonin reuptake, increasing serotonin levels in the brain, which helps improve mood, sleep, and appetite, typical symptoms associated with depression. Fluoxetine does not significantly affect noradrenaline levels.

 

Option C. Phenelzine: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI). It inhibits the enzyme monoamine oxidase, which breaks down neurotransmitters such as serotonin, noradrenaline, and dopamine in the brain, thus increasing their levels. However, its action is not by inhibiting reuptake but by preventing degradation.

 

Option D. Nortriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that primarily inhibits the reuptake of noradrenaline and, to a lesser extent, serotonin. TCAs like nortriptyline tend to have a broader spectrum of action on neurotransmitters compared to SSRIs but are not as selective as Venlafaxine for both serotonin and noradrenaline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venlafaxine is an effective antidepressant for the treatment of major depressive disorders due to its dual action on serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake inhibition, making it a valuable option for patients who do not respond adequately to SSRIs alone. This dual mechanism can provide more comprehensive management of depression symptoms compared to drugs that target a single neurotransmitter pathway.

 

Serotonin Noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRI) drugs are:

 

  • Venlafaxine

  • Duloxetine

  • Milnacipran

questions.text: A patient was given halothane for general anesthesia. He developed rigidity and hyperthermia. These symptoms are most likely due to which ion? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca2+

 

Explanation:

 

A patient who was administered halothane, a volatile anesthetic, and subsequently developed muscle rigidity and hyperthermia is likely experiencing a reaction called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH).

 

Malignant Hyperthermia (MH):

  • Definition: MH is a life-threatening pharmacogenetic disorder characterized by a hypermetabolic response to certain volatile anesthetics (like halothane) and neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • Etiology: The primary defect in MH is associated with the Ryanodine receptor (RyR1), which is a calcium release channel in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles. Some individuals possess a genetic mutation in the RyR1 gene that makes them susceptible to MH.

 

Mechanism:

  • In a normal muscle contraction, the L-type calcium (Ca2+) channel (or dihydropyridine receptor) in the T-tubules of the muscle fiber acts as a voltage sensor. When triggered, it indirectly causes the Ryanodine receptor to release calcium ions (Ca2+) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm.
  • In individuals with the MH mutation, certain volatile anesthetics like halothane can abnormally activate the mutated Ryanodine receptor. This results in a massive, uncontrolled release of Ca2+ into the cytoplasm of the muscle cells.
  • The surge in intracellular Ca2+ concentration leads to sustained muscle contraction, increased metabolism, and heat production, manifesting clinically as muscle rigidity and hyperthermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mg+: Magnesium plays a role in muscle relaxation and nerve function, but it is not directly implicated in the pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option B. K+: Potassium is involved in maintaining cellular function and electrical stability but is not the primary ion causing the symptoms in MH.

 

Option D. H+: Hydrogen ions relate to acid-base balance, and while metabolic acidosis can occur secondary to MH, they are not the primary cause of muscle rigidity and hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) is primarily associated with an uncontrolled release of calcium ions (Ca2+) due to a defect in the Ryanodine receptor. This leads to sustained muscle contraction, increased metabolism, and hyperthermia. Recognizing MH and understanding its pathophysiology is crucial for prompt and effective treatment.

questions.text: A young patient from Uttar Pradesh underwent surgery under general anesthesia with Oxygen, nitrous oxide and Desflurane. Just after extubation, the patient develops desaturation and crepts. What could be the possible cause? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negative pressure pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

Given the immediate onset of symptoms after extubation, the presentation of crepitations, and the clinical context, Negative Pressure Pulmonary Edema (NPPE) is the most plausible diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion refers to the accumulation of fluid in the space between the layers of the pleura. While it can cause shortness of breath and decreased oxygen saturation, the immediate onset after extubation and use of general anesthesia make it a less likely cause in this specific scenario.

 

Option B. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): ARDS is a severe lung condition causing low oxygen levels in the blood due to widespread inflammation in the lungs. Although it can be a complication after surgery, the acute onset just after extubation makes ARDS less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D. No Crepitations: The scenario clearly mentions the presence of crepitations, indicating the presence of fluid in the alveoli. Therefore, the option of no crepitations can be ruled out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative Pressure Pulmonary Edema (NPPE) can occur when a patient takes a forceful breath against a closed airway, such as in laryngospasm. This creates significant negative pressure in the chest, leading to fluid being pulled into the lungs from the bloodstream. The rapid onset of symptoms and the described clinical signs post-extubation make NPPE the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2593

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with body pain, easy fatigability, and problems while standing. Neurological examination revealed loss of vibration sense and proprioception. Investigations revealed a Hb level of 7 g/dL. Which of the following should be administered for the patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vit B12

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of anemia and neurological deficits, specifically the loss of vibration sense and proprioception. These findings are characteristic of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can cause both hematological and neurological abnormalities.

 

  • Anemia with low Hb (7 g/dL): Indicates a significant deficiency state.
  • Neurological symptoms: Loss of vibration sense and proprioception are specific signs of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, commonly due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms due to its role in the synthesis of myelin and DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vit B1: Deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine) leads to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome but does not typically cause the described hematological and neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which presents with symptoms such as bleeding gums and bruising, not neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Vit D: Vitamin D deficiency can cause bone pain and muscle weakness, leading to conditions like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, but does not cause the described neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with macrocytic anemia and specific neurological symptoms such as loss of vibration sense and proprioception. The appropriate treatment is vitamin B12 supplementation.

choices.text: Pityriasis rubra pilaris

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with lacy lesions in oral cavity and genitals. Her proximal nail fold has extended into the nail bed. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lichen planus

 

Lichen planus is the diagnosis from the clinical scenario given. The skin lesions of LP are purple, flat, polygonal papules.

 

Lichen Planus:

 

  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia.

 

 

  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop. It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

 

Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

 

 

Puptent sign:

 

 

Longitudinal ridging & nail plate thinning

 

 

Anonychia:

 

 

The image below shows thinning of nail plate (the Most common feature) & longitudinal striations & Trachyonychia –

 

 

Nail changes in Lichen planus

  • Up to 10% of Lichen planus cases can involve the nails, but this is usually a minor aspect of the condition.
  • The most distinctive nail change in lichen planus is a dorsal pterygium, which results from the fusion of the proximal nail fold and nail bed.
  • Thinning of the nail plate is the most common nail change.
  • Pup tent sign – elevation of nail in shape of tent
  • Trachyonychia – 20 nail dystrophy
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis & onycholysis
  • Longitudinal melanonychia in Lichen planus of the nail bed
  • Image shows Nails in lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves & ridges.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP):

 

  • It is a rare skin disorder that causes skin inflammation and scaling.
  • PRP can sometimes resemble psoriasis, but it's characterized by salmon-colored patches with well-defined borders and areas of spared skin, known as islands of sparing as depicted in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is an autoimmune condition characterized by raised, red, scaly patches on the skin.
  • It can also affect nails (leading to nail pitting, thickening, or separation from the nail bed) but does not produce the specific nail changes described in the question.
  • While psoriasis can involve the genital area, it doesn't produce lacy oral lesions.
  • Hence, this presentation is not typical for psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited rash that starts with a single large pink or tan oval area called a "herald patch" followed by the appearance of smaller patches on the torso, often arranged along the lines of skin tension in a “Christmas tree” pattern as depicted in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen planus is diagnosed with the characteristic findings of lacy white lesions on mucosal surfaces and specific nail changes.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 page no 37.1-5

choices.text: ATP 7A gene on chromosome 13
ATP 7B gene on chromosome 13
ATP 7C gene on chromosome 13
ATP 7B gene on chromosome 12

questions.text: A teenager presents with features of liver disease, tremor and poor incoordination, mask like facies, and psychiatric symptoms. Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ATP 7B gene on chromosome 13

 

Wilson disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13. This gene is involved in the transport of copper and its incorporation into ceruloplasmin. Defects in ATP7B lead to decreased excretion of copper into bile and its accumulation in various tissues, including the liver and brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key points about other genes:

 

  • HNF1-ALPHA - HEPATIC ADENOMA
  • FIBRILLIN –MARFAN SYNDROME
  • COL1A1-OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA
  • WILSON DISEASE-ATP 7B gene (Chromosome 13)
  • MENKES DISEASE – ATP7A gene
  • HEMOCHROMATOSIS- HFE gene (chromosome 6P)
  • ALPHA1-ANTITRYPSIN DEFICIENCY- SERPINA 1 gene (chromosome 14)
  • CYSTIC FIBROSIS – CFTR gene (chromosome 7)

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who has worked for many years in the dye industry, dealing with aniline, visits the hospital with bladder issues. Considering his occupational exposure, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transitional cell carcinoma

 

Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder is strongly associated with exposure to aniline dyes. The carcinogenic properties of aniline and related compounds in the dye industry have been well-documented, with TCC being the most common type of bladder cancer linked to these chemicals. This type of carcinoma arises from the transitional epithelium, a tissue lining the bladder, which is particularly vulnerable to such chemical exposures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: Incorrect, as this type of cancer is primarily skin-related and not associated with aniline exposure.

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Incorrect, this refers to cancers originating in glandular tissue and is less commonly linked to aniline exposure than TCC.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Also incorrect as it is not the most common type associated with chemical exposures in the dye industry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aniline exposure is carcinogenic to bladder and most common cancer it can cause is Transitional cell carcinoma 

 

 

Additional Information

 

Carcinoma Bladder in Occupational Exposures

 

  • Cancer bladder was first noted in man in Aniline industry in 1895
  • Possible bladder carcinogens:
    • Beta-napthylamines
    • Benzidine
    • Paraamino-diphenyl
    • Auramine
    • Magenta
    • Certain drugs: Cyclophosphamide, Phenacetin
  • Industries associated with cancer bladder
    • Dye-stuffs and dyeing industry
    • Rubber, gas and electric cable industry
  • Most common symptom: Blood in the urine (haematuria)
  • Most common type: Transitional Cell (urothelial cell) carcinoma (TCC) [90%]
  • Immunotherapy in the form of ‘Intravesical (pharmacotherapeutic) BCG instillation’ is also used to treat and prevent the recurrence of superficial tumors

questions.text: Dr. Kapoor is assessing key reproductive health statistics to guide policy recommendations and queries about the optimal Total Fertility Rate (TFR) for maintaining population stability in India. What is the target TFR for India? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2.1

 

  • Total Fertility Rate indicates average children a woman would have throughout her reproductive life.
  • The desired goal is to achieve a Couple Protection Rate (CPR) of >60%, so as to get a Total fertility rate of 2.1 and NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) of 1.
  • TFR is a synthetic rate - it is not actually counted, as this would involve waiting until women complete childbearing
  • TFR (India): 2.0 (2019-21, NFHS-5)
  • Replacement level of fertility (TFR = 2.1): TFR at which newborn girls would have an average of exactly 1 daughter over their lifetimes (women have just enough babies to replace themselves)
    • Replacement TFR (industrialized countries) = 2.1
    • Replacement TFR (developing countries) = 2.5–3.3
    • Replacement TFR (globally) = 2.33
  • Total cohort fertility rate (TCFR) is a better estimate of completed family size than TFR
  • Relationship between Crude birth rate (CBR) and Total fertility rate (TFR):
    CBR = (8 × TFR) + 1 [approx.]

 

Educational Objective:

 

The target Total Fertility Rate (TFR) for India is 2.1, which is considered the replacement level fertility.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best diagnostic method? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Widal test

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and the best diagnostic test for a patient symptomatic for 2 weeks is the Widal test.

 

The Widal test is typically used in the second week of illness when antibody titers are high enough to be detected. It helps in diagnosing typhoid fever when the patient has been symptomatic for over a week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stool culture: Stool cultures are more effective in the later stages of the disease, particularly in the third week when the bacteria are being shed in the stool. It is less useful in the initial stages or at the two-week mark.

 

Option C. Blood culture: Blood culture is the most reliable diagnostic test during the first week of illness when the bacteria are present in the bloodstream. It is considered the gold standard for early diagnosis but is less effective after the first week when the bacteria may no longer be present in the blood.

 

Option D. Urine culture: Urine cultures may be positive for Salmonella in the fourth week of illness. They are less useful in the earlier stages of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a case where a child is exposed to a contagious viral illness, there's a unique opportunity for a vaccine to confer immunity more quickly than the disease can develop. Which vaccine is known for this ability to induce rapid seroconversion post-exposure, outpacing the disease's incubation period? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Measles

 

The measles vaccine is particularly effective in post-exposure scenarios because it can induce protective antibodies within a week. This is significantly faster than the measles virus's incubation period of 10-14 days. Administering the measles vaccine promptly after exposure can prevent the disease from developing, making it a critical intervention in outbreak settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flu: Incorrect, as the flu vaccine typically requires more than a week for antibody development, which may not prevent illness after immediate exposure.

 

Option C. Rubella: Incorrect, since the antibodies for rubella generally take 2-4 weeks to develop, often exceeding the incubation period.

 

Option D. Mumps: Incorrect, as the mumps vaccine does not usually confer immunity quickly enough to outpace the incubation period in post-exposure situations.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Flu: I.P is 7 days: after vaccination the antibodies take more than 7 days to develop.
  • Measles: I.P is 10-14 days: after exposure If we give vaccines antibodies will develop within 7 days
  • Rubella: I.P is 14-21 days: whereas antibodies take 2-4 weeks time to develop.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presented with history of recurrent episodes of early morning lethargy and seizures. On examination, the child had doll like faces and hepatomegaly. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis and hyperlipidemia. Which enzyme is deficient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose 6 phosphatase

 

The clinical picture, biochemical findings, hypoglycemia are all characteristic of Von Gierke’s disease which is a Glycogen storage disease (GSD) Type I.

 

Affected enzyme: glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Affected tissue: Liver and kidney

 

Clinical features: large quantities of glycogen are formed and stored in hepatocytes, renal and intestinal mucosa cells. The liver and kidneys become enlarged.

 

Abnormalities of lipids may lead to xanthoma formation.

 

Uric acid is often elevated and may cause clinical gout. Galactose, fructose, and glycerol are metabolized to lactate. The elevated blood lactate levels cause metabolic acidosis.

 

Treatment - Blood loss may require oral iron.

 

Treatment of hyperuricemia and pyelonephritis protect renal function.

 

Diazoxide to maintain blood glucose has been disappointing.

 

Liver transplantation for primary disease or for hepatocellular carcinoma seems effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Muscle phosphorylase: Deficiency in muscle phosphorylase leads to McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V), which primarily affects muscle tissue, causing muscle cramps and exercise intolerance, not the systemic symptoms described.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase: Deficiency in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase leads to G6PD deficiency, which causes hemolytic anemia, not glycogen storage disease with the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Hepatic Phosphorylase: Deficiency in hepatic phosphorylase leads to Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI), which presents with mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly but not the severe systemic symptoms seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is characterized by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. Holter study was done and his 24-hour ECG strip obtained is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Permanent pacemaker

 

The ECG strip shows a Mobitz type 2 atrioventricular (AV) block. This type of block is characterized by a constant PR interval with intermittent dropped beats. The patient has symptoms of palpitations and syncope, which are indicative of significant bradyarrhythmia.

 

Mobitz type 2 AV block, particularly if it persists beyond 48 hours after a myocardial infarction, is usually due to scar formation rather than acute ischemia. Long-term treatment involves the placement of a permanent pacemaker to ensure stable cardiac rhythm and prevent further episodes of syncope and associated risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: This antiarrhythmic drug is not indicated for the treatment of Mobitz type 2 AV block. It is primarily used for tachyarrhythmias.

 

Option B. Atropine only: Atropine can be used temporarily to increase heart rate in cases of bradycardia, but it is not a long-term solution for Mobitz type 2 AV block.

 

Option D. Atropine and isoproterenol: Both medications can be used temporarily to manage bradycardia but are not suitable for long-term management of Mobitz type 2 AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mobitz type 2 AV block, especially when symptomatic and persistent beyond 48 hours post-myocardial infarction, requires the placement of a permanent pacemaker for long-term management.

questions.text: In India's dynamic public health landscape, various organizations contribute to health promotion and awareness. Which organization is primarily tasked with these initiatives? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central Health Education Bureau

 

Central Health Education Bureau under the Directorate General of Health Services, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India works in the field of health education, health promotion, capacity building, developing IEC materials, and behavioural research.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indian Council of Medical Research: This body primarily focuses on biomedical research and is not directly involved in health promotion on a community level.

 

Option C. Central Bureau of Health Intelligence: It deals with the collection and analysis of health data rather than direct public health education.

 

Option D. National Health Library: Primarily provides resources and information services to health professionals, rather than engaging directly in public health education campaigns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Central Health Education Bureau is integral to driving health promotion and awareness strategies in India, ensuring that health information is accessible and impactful for the vast and varied population of the country.

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with complaints of primary amenorrhea. On evaluation axillary and pubic hair were present and other secondary sexual characteristics normal. LH and FSH levels are normal, and USG showed absence of uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRKH syndrome

 

  • The diagnosis is consistent with MRKH syndrome (mullerian agenesis)
  • The secondary sexual characters are present which means ovaries are functional and this rules out gonadal dysgenesis (Turner and Swyer)
  • As pubic and axillary hair is present, this rules out androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • In mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome)
    • There is absent uterus, cervix, upper vagina and fallopian tubes
    • Ovaries are present
    • Karyotype is 46XX
    • All hormone levels are normal
    • Treatment
      • Fertility: Surrogacy/ uterine transplant
      • Sexual function: Vaginoplasty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome:

 

  • Karyotype 45XO
  • Streak gonads, low E2
  • Clinical features: primary amenorrhoea, short stature, poor secondary sexual characters, webbing of neck, cubitus valgus

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Testicular feminization (46XY):

 

  • Primary amenorrhoea, female phenotype
  • Absent axillary, pubic hair
  • Breast development and external genitalia developed
  • Gonads are testes

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome:

 

  • Karyotype 46 XY
  • Mutation in SRY gene of Y chromosome responsible
  • External and internal genitalia are female
  • Gonads are fibrous
  • Secondary sexual characters absent

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRKH syndrome is characterized by the absence of the uterus, cervix, upper vagina, and fallopian tubes, with normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition Pg 446

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not form a grey-white membrane over the tonsils? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ludwig’s angina

 

Ludwig’s angina is infection of submandibular space. Patient presents with complaint of difficulty in eating and speaking. However, there is no membrane formation over tonsils.

 

It is characterized by the rapid onset of cellulitis involving the floor of the mouth and the neck, leading to severe swelling that can compromise the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcal tonsillitis: Can form a grey-white exudate over the tonsils as a result of inflammation and pus from the bacterial infection, which is often due to Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Characteristically forms a grey-white pseudo membrane that is tough, fibrous, and adherent. When forcibly removed, it tends to bleed, and typically extends beyond the tonsils to the pharynx and nasal cavity.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to the formation of a fine white to grayish film over the tonsils along with marked tonsillar enlargement, though it is not as thick or adherent as the membrane seen in diphtheria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ludwig's angina, though a severe infection near the tonsils, does not create a membrane over the tonsils and is primarily known for its potential to cause significant swelling that may obstruct the airway.

 

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

 

  1. Membranous tonsillitis - ﻿﻿Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms forming exudative membrane.
  2. ﻿﻿Diphtheria - the membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils, on to the soft palate and is dirty grey in color. It is adherent and its removal leaves a bleeding surface.
  3. ﻿﻿Infectious mononucleosis - Both tonsils are very much enlarged, congested and covered with membrane, posterior lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
  4. ﻿﻿Vincent's angina - Membrane, which usually forms over one tonsil, can be easily removed revealing an irregular ulcer on the tonsil
  5. ﻿﻿Leukemia
  6. ﻿﻿Candida
  7. ﻿﻿Agranulocytosis - presents with ulcerative necrotic lesions not only on the tonsils but elsewhere in the oropharynx.
  8. ﻿﻿Malignancy
  9. ﻿﻿Aphthous ulcer
  10. ﻿﻿Traumatic ulcer

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 293, 294, 297

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes of iodine is used for treatment of thyroid cancer? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. I-131

 

I-131 is used for the treatment of thyroid cancer due to its ability to emit beta particles, which have a therapeutic effect by destroying thyroid tissue, including cancerous cells. It's particularly effective because thyroid cells naturally absorb iodine, and thus selectively take up the radioactive isotope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. I-123: This isotope is used primarily for diagnostic purposes, particularly in thyroid imaging (scintigraphy). It has a short half-life and emits gamma rays, making it suitable for imaging but not for therapy.

 

Option C. I-127: This is the non-radioactive, stable isotope of iodine, which is naturally occurring and is the most common form of iodine found in nature and in the human body. It is not used for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes in the context of radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Option D. I-125: This isotope is used primarily for research, diagnostic purposes, and in some cases for brachytherapy (a form of radiation therapy), but not typically for thyroid cancer treatment. It emits gamma rays and has a relatively long half-life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of thyroid cancer, radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy is commonly used, and the specific isotope employed is Iodine-131 (I-131).

questions.text: In a global discussion about entities that spearhead initiatives for sustainable growth, which organization is primarily recognized for its significant role in advancing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. UNDP

 

 

UNDP: United Nations Development Program:

 

  • Headquarters: New York USA
  • The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) was established in 1966. It is the main source of funds for technical assistance. The member countries of the United Nations meet annually and pledge contributions to the UNDP.
  • The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The UNDP is crucial in orchestrating global efforts towards sustainable development, providing leadership, funding, and support across a broad spectrum of SDG-related activities, ensuring comprehensive and inclusive progress.

choices.text: MR can be used, discard Pentavalent

questions.text: During a national vaccination campaign in Himachal Pradesh, a health worker inadvertently left two vaccine vials uncapped after the session: one containing Measles-Rubella (MR) and the other, Pentavalent vaccine. Concerned about potential contamination, the supervising health officer needs to decide which vial to discard based on their stability and safety guidelines. What is the appropriate action? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Discard MR, use pentavalent

 

The MR vaccine is sensitive to being left open and does not follow an open vial policy, meaning it must be used within 4 hours after reconstitution with diluent. Leaving an MR vaccine vial open potentially compromises its efficacy and safety, warranting its disposal.

 

On the other hand, the Pentavalent vaccine can remain viable for up to 28 days after opening, provided it is not contaminated, the expiry date has not passed, and the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) has not indicated otherwise. This makes the Pentavalent vaccine usable even if the vial was left open temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open Vial Policy 2015

 

  • Applicable for Vaccines: OPV, DPT, Hepatitis B, TT, Liquid Pentavalent
  • Not applicable for Vaccines: Measles, BCG, JE
  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UP TO 4 WEEKS’
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

choices.text: T cell-mediated cytotoxicity
IgE-mediated reaction
IgG-mediated reaction
IgA-mediated hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A boy, upon disturbing a bee hive, received several stings. After a few minutes, he developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. This is an example of? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE-mediated reaction

 

Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is a classic example of an IgE-mediated reaction, also known as a Type I hypersensitivity reaction. This type of reaction occurs when an individual who has been sensitized to an allergen is re-exposed to it, leading to the cross-linking of IgE antibodies on mast cells and basophils. This cross-linking triggers the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators, causing symptoms such as shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T cell-mediated cytotoxicity: T cell-mediated cytotoxicity, also known as Type IV hypersensitivity, involves T cells recognizing and destroying infected or abnormal cells. This type of reaction is not typically associated with anaphylaxis or immediate allergic responses.

 

Option C. IgG-mediated reaction: IgG-mediated reactions, also known as Type II hypersensitivity, involve IgG antibodies targeting and destroying cells with specific antigens, such as in hemolytic anemia or Goodpasture's syndrome. These reactions are not associated with the immediate onset of anaphylaxis.

 

Option D. IgA-mediated hypersensitivity reaction: IgA-mediated hypersensitivity reactions are not a recognized category of hypersensitivity reactions. IgA antibodies primarily function in mucosal immunity and are not typically involved in systemic anaphylactic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylaxis, such as that triggered by bee stings, is an IgE-mediated reaction or Type I hypersensitivity. This reaction involves the rapid release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils, leading to symptoms like shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse.

questions.text: A 30-year-old chronic smoker is brought to the ER with severe respiratory distress. His vitals are unstable. His X-ray chest was done which showed the following. Possible diagnosis in this patient?  (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

The given chest X-ray shows features indicative of a tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure. This pressure pushes the mediastinum, including the heart, great vessels, and trachea, to the opposite side of the chest (mediastinal shift). This condition is life-threatening and requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Key features of tension pneumothorax include:

 

  • Respiratory distress: Severe difficulty in breathing due to collapsed lung.
  • Unstable vitals: Due to obstructive shock caused by compression of the superior vena cava and decreased venous return to the heart.
  • Mediastinal shift: Visible on chest X-ray as displacement of the heart, trachea, and other mediastinal structures to the opposite side of the pneumothorax.
  • Decreased breath sounds: On the affected side during physical examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax is the presence of air or gas in the pleural space causing the lung to collapse. It appears on an X-ray as a clear space without lung markings. However, unlike a tension pneumothorax, it does not cause significant mediastinal shift or severe hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Hemothorax: Hemothorax involves the accumulation of blood in the pleural space. On an X-ray, it appears as a homogeneous opacity with a fluid level, causing the affected lung to appear whited out. This condition does not cause the severe mediastinal shift seen in tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition is the simultaneous presence of air and fluid in the pleural space. On an upright chest X-ray, it shows a fluid level with an air-fluid interface. It would not typically cause the severe respiratory distress and unstable vitals associated with a tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by severe respiratory distress, unstable vitals, and mediastinal shift on chest X-ray, requiring immediate medical intervention.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of digoxin induced ventricular arrhythmias is? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lidocaine

 

Lidocaine is the drug of choice for the treatment of digoxin induced ventricular arrhythmias. Lignocaine has the least effect on AV nodal conduction and is the most appropriate drug for the treatment of digoxin-induced arrhythmias.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Atropine: It is an anticholinergic agent which is mainly used for the bradyarrythmia’s. It may worsen the arrythmias caused by digoxin toxicity.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Is contraindicated in digoxin induced arrythmias because amiodarone increases the plasma level of digoxin and precipitates its toxicity

 

Option D. Propranolol: Is used for atrial tachyarrhythmias associated with digoxin toxicity. Propranolol with digoxin increase the risk of bradycardia and severe heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For ventricular arrhythmias caused by digoxin toxicity, Lidocaine is preferred due to its effective suppression of abnormal ventricular rhythms without adversely impacting AV nodal conduction.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized weakness. His Hb level was low and serum iron was low. Which of the following vitamins help in iron absorption? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid), aids in the absorption of iron by converting ferric iron to ferrous iron, which is more easily absorbed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is essential for red blood cell formation and neurological function but does not play a direct role in the absorption of iron.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A is important for vision, immune function, and skin health, but it does not directly influence iron absorption.

 

Option D. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage but does not affect iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C enhances iron absorption by converting ferric iron to the more readily absorbed ferrous iron.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for delirium tremens?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiamine + diazepam

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that requires medical intervention. The mainstay of treatment is benzodiazepines, which can effectively control agitation, seizures, and autonomic hyperactivity seen in DT.

 

Thiamine is essential to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy in chronic alcohol users. Diazepam, a benzodiazepine, is widely used for its anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and sedative effects, making it an ideal choice for DT.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Methylcobalamine: While it's a form of vitamin B12, it's not specifically used for DT.

 

Option B. Thiamine alone: Thiamine is vital in alcohol users to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy but by itself won't manage DT symptoms.

 

Option D. Lorazepam: Another benzodiazepine that can be used for DT, but when combined with thiamine, diazepam is more commonly preferred in many clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 282.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical parameters are correct in Vitamin D-dependent rickets? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

  • Rickets is a condition characterized by a softening and weakening of bones in children due to a vitamin D dietary deficit.
  • Lab tests for rickets show a normal or decreased serum calcium and phosphorus, raised parathyroid hormone (PTH), and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels.
  • Poor absorption of vitamin D causes a decrease in calcium and phosphate levels.
  • The decrease in calcium levels stimulates the generation of PTH, while the rise in ALP levels is due to its role in bone mineralization.
  • Hypophosphatemic rickets is an X-linked dominant condition caused by a mutation in the PHEX gene.
  • This condition leads to elevated levels of the hormone phosphatonin, which in turn causes hypophosphatemia and impaired bone mineralization.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Rickets radiological characteristics:

 

  • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate)
  • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis)
  • Spawning at the metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends)
  • Widespread rarefaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D-dependent rickets presents with decreased or normal serum calcium, increased PTH levels, decreased serum phosphate, and increased serum alkaline phosphatase. This profile reflects the body's compensatory responses to impaired vitamin D metabolism and resultant hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient of Covid-19 requires oxygen therapy. What color of cylinders should be used to provide oxygen to this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Black body with white shoulder

 

Explanation:

 

For providing oxygen therapy, the correct cylinder to use is the one with a black body and a white shoulder. This color coding is universally recognized to indicate an oxygen cylinder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blue body: Blue color is typically used for nitrous oxide cylinders.

 

Option C. Blue body with white shoulder: This color coding is used for Entonox, a mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen.

 

Option D. Grey: Grey is color coding for carbon dioxide cylinder.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The color coding for oxygen cylinders is a black body with a white shoulder. This ensures proper identification and safe administration of oxygen therapy in clinical settings.

questions.text: In an asymptomatic patient, on routine screening a small mass was detected in the rectum which looked like a suspected neoplasm. What is the next step in the management? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sigmoidoscopy with lesion biopsy

 

The next step in the management of a small mass detected in the rectum suspected to be a neoplasm is to perform a sigmoidoscopy with lesion biopsy. Sigmoidoscopy is an endoscopic examination of the rectum and the sigmoid colon. This procedure is quicker than a colonoscopy, less invasive, and does not require full bowel prep. If the mass is located in the rectum or sigmoid colon, sigmoidoscopy is a suitable method to examine the lesion and take a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum CEA levels: While serum CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen) levels can be elevated in colorectal cancer and are useful for monitoring response to treatment and recurrence, they are not the first step in the management. Serum CEA testing might be done after confirming the diagnosis of malignancy to establish a baseline.

 

Option C. CT pelvis:  A CT (Computed Tomography) scan of the pelvis can provide detailed images of the rectum and other pelvic organs and structures. It is useful in staging the disease, assessing the extent of the lesion, involvement of surrounding tissues, or presence of lymph node enlargement. However, it is not the first diagnostic step. It is typically used after the malignancy is confirmed by biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium enema: A barium enema is a radiologic examination of the colon using barium sulfate as a contrast. While this can highlight masses or abnormalities in the colon, it is not as sensitive as endoscopic methods and does not allow for biopsy. Therefore, it is not the preferred initial diagnostic method for a suspected neoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a suspected rectal neoplasm detected on routine screening is to perform a sigmoidoscopy with a lesion biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is not amenable to growth on standard artificial culture media? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy also called Hansen's disease, cannot be grown in a pure culture media. It is an intracellular pathogen and has extremely slow growth requirements. It cannot be cultured using conventional artificial culture media and methods.

 

It is grown in a specialized laboratory setting using an animal footpad model or through the use of an armadillo, which is a natural host for the bacterium.

 

It does not obey Koch's postulates and cannot be grown in vitro.
