Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a common bacterium that grows readily on standard culture media, such as blood agar and nutrient agar, under aerobic conditions. It is known for its ability to cause a range of infections, from minor skin infections to more severe diseases like pneumonia and sepsis.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis, can be cultured on specialized media such as Löwenstein-Jensen medium or Middlebrook agar, though it requires several weeks to grow due to its slow replication rate. It is a well-studied pathogen with established culture techniques.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae grows well on enriched media like blood agar, where it typically produces alpha-hemolysis (a greenish discoloration) around the colonies. It is a major cause of bacterial pneumonia, meningitis, and other infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium leprae is unique among these bacteria in that it cannot be cultured using standard artificial media due to its specific growth requirements and extremely slow replication rate, necessitating the use of animal models for its study.

 

Note – Microorganism not meeting the criteria of Koch’s postulates:- (No LPG)

 

  • M. Leprae
  • T. Pallidum
  • N. Gonorrhea

questions.text: Dopamine at low doses? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases renal blood flow

 

At low doses (typically less than 2 mg/kg/min), dopamine acts primarily on dopamine-1 (D1) receptors, which are predominantly located in the renal vasculature. Activation of these receptors leads to renal vasodilation, thereby increasing renal blood flow. This effect is beneficial in clinical settings where it is crucial to support renal function, especially in cases of shock or heart failure where renal perfusion might otherwise be compromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increases cardiac contractility: At moderate doses (2-10 mg/kg/min), dopamine acts on beta-1 (β1) adrenergic receptors, which enhances cardiac contractility and output, beneficial in acute congestive heart failure (CHF).

 

Option B. Causes vasoconstriction: At high doses (greater than 10 mg/kg/min), dopamine activates alpha-1 (α1) adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction. This action increases systemic vascular resistance and helps to elevate blood pressure in the treatment of shock.

 

Option C. Increases blood pressure: While high doses of dopamine can increase blood pressure through vasoconstriction, low doses primarily focus on enhancing renal blood flow without a significant increase in overall blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effects of Dopamine at different doses:

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2A1 at 18 weeks of gestation came with complaints of draining PV for the past 4 hours. On examination, membranes are ruptured, and uterine contractions present. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a short cervix <25 mm and funneling of internal os >1 cm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical incompetence

 

  • Cervical incompetence: Cervical incompetence (or insufficiency) is characterized by features of a short cervix (<25 mm) and funneling of the internal os (>1 cm). This condition typically presents with a history of recurrent painless mid-trimester abortions. In this case, the patient presents with draining PV, ruptured membranes, and uterine contractions at 18 weeks gestation, which are indicative of cervical incompetence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and is accompanied by painless profuse vaginal bleeding. This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix. However, it is not characterized by a short cervix or funneling of the internal os, which rules it out in this scenario.

 

Option C. Abruptio placenta: Abruptio placenta refers to the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It may be revealed or concealed and characteristically shows a tonically contracted uterus. It presents with painful vaginal bleeding, which is different from the symptoms of cervical incompetence.

 

Option D. Traumatic injury: Traumatic injury can cause bleeding and other symptoms, but it is not typically associated with a short cervix and funneling of the internal os, as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cervical incompetence is characterized by a short cervix (<25 mm) and funneling of the internal os (>1 cm) on transvaginal ultrasound, often leading to painless mid-trimester abortions.

  

 Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 197-198

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was brought to the emergency room with fever since 2 days, along with dyspnea, drooling and inspiratory stridor. Lateral X-ray neck findings were as seen below. Which is the most common organism (in India) which causes this condition in children? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemophilus influenza B

 

Based on the child's clinical features of fever, dyspnea, drooling, and inspiratory stridor, as well as the thumb sign seen on the lateral X-ray of the neck, this is a case of acute epiglottitis. Acute epiglottitis is a life-threatening condition that involves inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, which can obstruct the airway.

 

  • Hemophilus influenza B (Hib) is the most common organism causing acute epiglottitis in children, especially in countries like India where vaccination rates may vary. Hib infection can lead to severe epiglottitis, presenting with the classic symptoms and radiographic findings described.
  • The lateral X-ray of the neck showing the "thumb sign" is indicative of a swollen epiglottis, a hallmark of epiglottitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Influenza virus: Influenza virus can cause respiratory infections and complications, but it is not the most common cause of acute epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species can cause various infections, including skin and respiratory infections, but they are not the primary causative agents of epiglottitis.

 

Option D. RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus): RSV is the most common cause of bronchiolitis in infants and young children, not epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute epiglottitis, especially in regions with variable vaccination coverage, Hemophilus influenza B (Hib) should be considered the most common causative organism. Recognizing the clinical presentation and radiographic findings, such as the thumb sign on a lateral neck X-ray, is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent airway obstruction and other complications.

 

Ref - Most recent edition of O.P. Ghai.

questions.text: In PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chloride

 

Explanation

 

Concentration of the chloride increases (Relatively High Due to Less Absorption).

 

  • Sodium potassium and water (67%)
  • Calcium (70%)
  • Phosphate and HCO3 (80%)
  • Glucose and amino acid (100%)
  • Sodium carries glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate.
  • ﻿﻿This leaves behind the solute, that has a higher concentration of the chloride, since Maximum reabsorption of chloride also occurs in PCT.

 

Absorption and secretion in PCT

 

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Amino acid: Incorrect. The concentration of amino acids decreases as they are 100% reabsorbed in the PCT.


Option B. Glucose: Incorrect. The concentration of glucose decreases as it is 100% reabsorbed in the PCT.


Option D. Bicarbonate: Incorrect. The concentration of bicarbonate decreases as 80% of it is reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other solutes due to its lower rate of absorption.

choices.text: Isoniazid + Rifampicin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol
Cefepime + Vancomycin + Ampicillin
Liposomal amphotericin B + Flucytosine

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness for the last month. His eyes are in a down and out position. On examination, Kernig's and Brudzinski sign is positive. CSF reveals the predominance of mononuclear cells with low glucose and forms cobweb coagulum on standing. MRI shows basal exudates with meningeal enhancement. What is the therapy of choice for this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isoniazid + Rifampicin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol

 

The patient's presentation with headache, photophobia, neck stiffness, and cranial nerve involvement (down and out position indicating third nerve palsy) is suggestive of meningitis. The CSF findings showing mononuclear cells, low glucose, and cobweb coagulum formation on standing, along with MRI findings of basal exudates and meningeal enhancement, strongly suggest tuberculosis (TB) meningitis.

 

  • Mononuclear cells with low glucose in CSF: This is characteristic of chronic meningitis, particularly TB and fungal infections.
  • Cobweb coagulum formation: This is a classic finding in TB meningitis.
  • Basal exudates with meningeal enhancement: This triad, along with hydrocephalus and infarcts, is typical of TB meningitis on imaging.

 

The standard treatment for TB meningitis involves a combination of anti-tubercular drugs:

 

  • Isoniazid
  • Rifampicin
  • Pyrazinamide
  • Ethambutol

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin: This regimen is used for acute bacterial meningitis but is not appropriate for TB meningitis.

 

Option C. Cefepime + Vancomycin + Ampicillin: This combination is also used for bacterial meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised patients, but not for TB meningitis.

 

Option D. Liposomal amphotericin B + Flucytosine: This regimen is used for fungal meningitis, such as cryptococcal meningitis, and is not suitable for TB meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis meningitis presents with mononuclear cells, low glucose in the CSF, and characteristic imaging findings of basal exudates and meningeal enhancement. The treatment involves a combination of anti-tubercular drugs: isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

questions.text: Which of the following radio-isotope is used for detection of carcinoma thyroid? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) I-123

 

Iodine-123 (I-123) is a radioisotope commonly used in nuclear medicine for the detection and diagnosis of thyroid carcinoma. It has a half-life of 13 hours, which is suitable for diagnostic imaging. The isotope emits gamma rays that can be detected by a gamma camera, allowing for detailed imaging of the thyroid gland. This helps in assessing the function and structure of the thyroid, detecting nodules, and evaluating the nature of thyroid masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. I-125: Iodine-125 (I-125) has a half-life of about 60 days and is primarily used for brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation treatment, especially in prostate cancer. It is not typically used for thyroid imaging.

 

Option C. I-127: Iodine-127 (I-127) is a stable, non-radioactive isotope of iodine. It is the naturally occurring form of iodine found in food and is not used in diagnostic imaging or therapy.

 

Option D. I-141 There is no iodine isotope I-141. This option is incorrect as it does not exist in practical applications for medical use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iodine-123 (I-123) is the preferred radioisotope for the detection and diagnostic imaging of thyroid carcinoma due to its appropriate half-life and gamma emission properties.

choices.text: Yolk sac tumor

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient has a complaint of a painless testicular mass. His blood sample revealed non-elevated alpha fetoprotein levels. Which of the following is the most likely because of his testicular mass? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Classical seminoma

 

SEMINOMA

 

  • The commonest variety of testicular tumor
  • Adults are the usual target (4th and 5th decade)
  • Right > Left Testis
  • Starts in the mediastinum: compresses the surrounding structure.
  • Patients present with painless testicular mass
  • 30% have metastases at presentation, but only 3% have symptoms related to metastases
  • 90% of patients stain for PLAP.
  • AFP is normal

 

Classification

 

      1. Classical – 85%
      2. Anaplastic – 5-10%
      3. Spermatocytic

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yolk sac tumor: Typically associated with elevated AFP levels.

 

Option C. Teratoma: May have variable tumor markers, not specifically associated with non-elevated AFP.

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma: Usually associated with elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical seminoma is the most common testicular tumor in adults, presenting as a painless mass with normal AFP levels and positive PLAP staining.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathological image of the growth is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by several different species of fungi, including Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Cladophialophora carrionii, and others. The disease is typically characterized by the formation of nodules, papules, or verrucous lesions on the affected skin, which may spread to adjacent areas over time.

 

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment is done with antifungals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, it typically presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels. Histopathology would show cigar-shaped yeast cells.

 

 

Option B. Mycetoma: Characterized by the triad of swelling, sinus tracts, and discharge of granules. Histopathology shows grains or granules composed of fungal or bacterial colonies.

 

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis: Caused by dematiaceous fungi, it presents as a range of clinical syndromes from superficial to deep infections. Histopathology shows hyphae and yeast-like cells with melanin in their cell walls.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by chronic verrucous cutaneous lesions with histopathological features of sclerotic bodies or "copper penny" bodies, typically affecting individuals with occupational exposure to soil and organic matter.

questions.text: Which of the following sequences is shown in the image below?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T2 MRI

 

Explanation

 

The MRI shows CSF as hyperintense, hence this is a T2 weighted MRI image

 

(WW2 - Water is white on T2)

 

In T2 imaging, fluids such as CSF appear white, which is a key feature for identifying this type of sequence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. T1-weighted MRI:

 

  • Fluids like CSF are hypointense (dark).
  • Fat appears hyperintense (bright).
  • White matter appears brighter than gray matter.

 

Option. C. STIR (Short TI Inversion Recovery):

 

  • Fluids are still bright, but fat signals are suppressed.

 

Option. D. SWI (Susceptibility Weighted Imaging):

 

  • Used to highlight blood, iron, and calcium deposits; fluids do not specifically appear hyperintense as they do in T2 sequences.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with pinpoint pupil, diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation and garlic odor. On examination there is bradycardia, BP is 80/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 56/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 52 U/mL. Which of the following is antidote for treatment of this patient?  (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

The clinical scenario of a farmer presenting with increased secretions, pin point pupil, bradycardia and hypotension along with a reduced plasma cholinesterase activity is suggestive of Organophosphorus poisoning. The antidote for the Organophosphates poisoning is IV Atropine.

 

Organophosphates causes irreversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase enzyme which leads to raised Acetylcholine levels and so cholinergic side effects (DUMBELSS).

 

The cholinergic side effects include –

Diarrhea

Urination

Miosis

Bradycardia, bronchospasm

Emesis

Lacrimation

Salivation

Sweating

 

  • The antidote is I.V Atropine.

  • Atropine is repeated every 5 minutes until the signs of Atropinization are seen. These include mydriasis, decrease in secretions, tachycardia. The most common sign is mydriasis whereas the most reliable/specific sign is decreased secretions. Atropine can reverse all the symptoms except for muscle weakness.

  • Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment.


Other Options:

 

Option A.  Flumazenil: Is the antidote of choice for benzodiazepine poisoning

 

Option C. Epinephrine: Is the drug of choice for treating allergic reactions and anaphylaxis and also as a vasoconstrictor.

 

Option D.  N-acetylcysteine: Is the antidote of choice for paracetamol poisoning

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cases of organophosphate poisoning, Atropine is the primary antidote due to its ability to block the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. Prompt administration and proper dosing are critical to reverse the life-threatening cholinergic symptoms effectively. Additionally, Pralidoxime may also be administered alongside Atropine to reactivate cholinesterase and further improve recovery in organophosphate poisoning.

choices.text: Pentavalent can be used and MMR must be discarded
MMR can be used and Pentavalent should be discarded
Both vials can be reused

questions.text: 2 open vials of pentavalent vaccine and one open vial of MMR vaccine is given back after an immunization session. What should be done with those vials? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pentavalent can be used and MMR must be discarded

 

As per the open vial policy, the following guidelines apply for the reuse of vaccines:

 

  • The policy allows the use of partially used multidose vials for a maximum of four weeks, provided the vials are within their expiry date and have been properly stored within the cold chain.
  • Mentioning the date and time of vial opening is crucial for compliance.
  • The Open Vial Policy is applicable to the following vaccines: DPT, TT, PCV, Hep B, Hib, OPV, and IPV.
  • Vaccines not included in the policy and thus must be discarded after the session includes BCG, Rotavirus, Measles/MR, and Japanese Encephalitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both should be discarded: This is incorrect because the pentavalent vaccine can be reused under the open vial policy.

 

Option C. MMR can be used and Pentavalent should be discarded: This is incorrect because MMR is not included in the open vial policy and must be discarded, while the pentavalent vaccine can be reused.

 

Option D. Both vials can be reused: This is incorrect because MMR must be discarded as per the policy, while the pentavalent vaccine can be reused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Open Vial Policy allows for the reuse of certain vaccines like the pentavalent vaccine if stored correctly, but vaccines such as MMR must be discarded after an immunization session.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones regulate serum calcium levels? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All the above

 

Explanation

 

All of these hormones—Calcitonin, Parathormone (PTH), and Vitamin D—regulate serum calcium levels.

 

Option A. Calcitonin: Calcitonin decreases serum calcium levels by inhibiting bone resorption. It also decreases serum phosphate (PO43-) levels.

 

Option B. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) increases serum calcium levels by stimulating bone resorption and decreases serum phosphate levels.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Vitamin D increases serum calcium and phosphate levels by promoting bone calcification and enhancing intestinal absorption of calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Genioglossus

 

The structure marked A in the image is Genioglossus muscle.

 

 

The genioglossus is a paired muscle located in the tongue. It is the largest and most prominent extrinsic muscle of the tongue.

 

Origin: The genioglossus muscle originates from the genial tubercle on the inner surface of the mandible (lower jaw) and the anterior surface of the body of the mandible.

 

Insertion: It inserts into the inferior aspect of the tongue.

 

Function: The genioglossus muscle plays a critical role in tongue movement and protrusion. It assists in various tongue movements such as sticking the tongue out, retracting it, and altering its shape during speech, swallowing, and other oral functions.

 

Innervation: Hypoglossal nerve.

 

Blood supply: Lingual artery with contributions from the tonsillar artery.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Hyoglossus: The hyoglossus is another extrinsic muscle of the tongue, located below the genioglossus.

 

Origin: It originates from the greater horn of the hyoid bone, which is a U-shaped bone located in the neck.

 

Insertion: The hyoglossus muscle inserts into the inferior aspect of the tongue and blends with the fibers of the genioglossus.

 

Function: The primary function of the hyoglossus muscle is to depress and retract the tongue. It works in coordination with other tongue muscles to aid in speech, swallowing, and tongue movement within the oral cavity.

 

Option C. Styloglossus: The styloglossus is also an extrinsic tongue muscle.

 

Origin: It originates from the styloid process of the temporal bone, a slender bone projection located in the neck.

 

Insertion: The styloglossus muscle inserts into the inferior aspect of the tongue.

 

Function: The main function of the styloglossus muscle is to retract and elevate the tongue. It helps in various tongue movements during speech and swallowing, as well as assists in maintaining the tongue's position within the mouth.

 

Option D. Palatoglossus: The palatoglossus muscle is unique among the muscles mentioned because it is a component of the palatine tonsil and also contributes to the tongue's movement.

 

Origin: It originates from the palatine aponeurosis, which is a thin, fibrous structure located at the back of the roof of the mouth.

 

Insertion: The palatoglossus muscle inserts into the inferior aspect of the tongue.

 

Function: The primary function of the palatoglossus muscle is to elevate the back of the tongue and assist in swallowing. It also helps close off the nasopharynx during swallowing, preventing food or liquids from entering the nasal cavity.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Genioglossus muscle is a critical component for tongue mobility, playing a significant role in tasks such as speaking, swallowing, and breathing by enabling the tongue to protrude and change shape effectively. Its adequate functioning is essential for normal oral and respiratory functions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an SNRI? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venlafaxine

 

Venlafaxine is classified as a Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor (SNRI).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: This is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).

 

Option C. Escitalopram: This is also an SSRI.

 

Option D. Amitriptyline: This is a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs) act by inhibiting reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine, unlike SSRIs that primarily affect serotonin reuptake. Drugs in this category include venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, milnacipram and levomilnacipram.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 632-635.

questions.text: A 7-year-old immunized child presented with 'thumb sign' on X-Ray. Which organism is most commonly responsible? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus

 

  • Acute epiglottitis is the diagnosis based on the clinical history and radiographic finding of the 'thumb sign' on X-ray, which indicates swelling of the epiglottis.
  • Streptococcus species, particularly Streptococcus pneumoniae, are the most common organisms responsible for acute epiglottitis in vaccinated children. This shift has occurred due to the widespread vaccination against Hemophilus influenzae type B (Hib), which used to be the predominant cause before the introduction of the vaccine.
  • Clinical Presentation: Children with acute epiglottitis present with rapid onset of sore throat, high fever, and difficulty breathing. They may also exhibit drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a characteristic "tripod" position to help open the airway.
  • X-ray Finding: The 'thumb sign' on a lateral neck X-ray is a classic finding, indicating an enlarged and swollen epiglottis.
  • Management: Immediate securing of the airway is crucial, which often involves intubation. Once the airway is secured, treatment includes IV antibiotics and supportive care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H. influenza: Hemophilus influenzae type B was historically the most common cause of acute epiglottitis, but due to effective vaccination programs, it is now less common in immunized children.

 

Option C. Parainfluenza virus: Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of croup, not epiglottitis. Croup presents with a "steeple sign" on X-ray and a characteristic barking cough, unlike the presentation of acute epiglottitis.

 

Option D. Influenza virus: Influenza virus can cause upper respiratory infections but is not typically associated with acute epiglottitis, especially in immunized children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis in immunized children is most commonly caused by Streptococcus species, with the 'thumb sign' on X-ray being a classic diagnostic feature. Immediate airway management is critical.

questions.text: A criminal can be charged in juvenile court if he is below ----- years of age? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18

 

According to the Juvenile Justice Board, an individual below 18 years of age is considered a juvenile and can be charged in juvenile court for applicable cases.

 

Educational Objective

 

An individual below 18 years of age is considered a juvenile and can be charged in juvenile court for applicable cases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal distension. On examination, he was found to have anemia, short stature and failure to thrive. An upper Gl endoscopy along with duodenal biopsy revealed villous atrophy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical features is Celiac disease.

 

  • Most all patients with celiac disease express (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, which facilitate the immune response against gluten proteins (gliadin).
  • Gluten is present in→ barley, rye, oat, wheat - Resulting in loss of bowel villi - Associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Signs and Symptoms

 

  • Abnormal liver function
  • Vomiting
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Neurologic dysfunction
  • Constipation
  • Nausea
  • Common
  • Diarrhea
  • Fatigue
  • Borborygmus
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal distention
  • Flatulence

 

Diagnosis of Celiac Disease

 

  • Clinical Findings
  • Small Intestines Mucosal Biopsy
  • Gluten Re-challenge

 

 

Serologic testing

 

  • IgA antigliadin antibodies
  • IgA endomysial antibodies
  • IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies

 

Management of Celiac Disease

 

  • Gluten avoidance is the mainstay of treatment
  • Prior to the introduction of a strict gluten-free diet, prognosis was very poor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intestinal lymphangiectasia: It is a condition characterized by dilated lymph vessels in the intestines, leading to protein-losing enteropathy, not typically associated with villous atrophy seen on biopsy.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung Disease: It is a congenital condition affecting the colon, leading to severe constipation or intestinal obstruction, rather than recurrent diarrhea and villous atrophy.

 

Option D. Inflammatory bowel disease: Conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis can cause abdominal pain and diarrhea but are not typically associated with villous atrophy on biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac Disease is characterized by an immune response to gluten leading to villous atrophy, diagnosed through clinical findings, serologic testing, and biopsy, with the primary treatment being a strict gluten-free diet.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 387- Page No 8386.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented to emergency following sudden fall at school. His pH was 7.2, PaCO2 was 64, HCO3 was 26, pO2 was 44. The most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory failure

 

The findings of ABG are suggestive of Respiratory acidosis associated with respiratory failure

 

As the pH is 7.2, pCO2 is elevated, HCO3 is over the upper limit, and p02 is lowered at 44.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumonia: Pneumonia can cause respiratory distress and hypoxemia, but it typically does not cause such a pronounced acute respiratory acidosis without accompanying metabolic compensation. The elevated PaCO2 and normal HCO3 point more towards respiratory failure.

 

Option B. Salicylate poisoning: Salicylate poisoning typically leads to mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis rather than pure respiratory acidosis. Elevated salicylate levels usually result in hyperventilation, reducing PaCO2 levels, not increasing them.

 

Option C. Acute renal failure: Acute renal failure primarily causes metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of acids that the kidneys normally excrete. It does not typically cause the respiratory acidosis seen in this ABG result.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The findings of pH 7.2, elevated PaCO2, and low pO2 are indicative of respiratory acidosis, pointing towards a diagnosis of respiratory failure.

choices.text: Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness, reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen and similar history is seen in elder brother. The most probable diagnosis is: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

 

Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease is a hereditary neuropathy that typically presents with distal muscle weakness and atrophy, reduced muscle stretch reflexes, and relatively preserved sensation, although sensory symptoms can occur. The classic clinical finding is the "inverted champagne bottle" appearance of the legs, where the distal muscles are atrophic compared to the proximal muscles.

 

  • Inverted champagne bottle appearance: This appearance is due to the distal muscle atrophy, particularly in the calves, making the legs appear thin at the distal end and relatively normal or hypertrophic proximally.
  • Atrophy of muscles below the knee: This is typical in CMT due to the length-dependent nature of the neuropathy, affecting the longest nerves first.
  • Family history: CMT is often familial, with autosomal dominant inheritance being the most common pattern. The presence of similar symptoms in an elder brother supports this diagnosis.

 

Other associated problems - High arches feet, other foot deformities, claw toes & claw hands

 

Note - There are different types of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease like type 1, type 2, type 3, type 4, and type X; but type 1 and type 2 are very common. Type 1 is typically a demyelinating type and type 2 is typically an axonal type.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Refsum's disease: This is a rare genetic disorder that involves the accumulation of phytanic acid, leading to symptoms like retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, cerebellar ataxia, and ichthyosis. It does not typically present with the classic inverted champagne bottle appearance.

 

Option C. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome: This can cause peripheral neuropathy but is usually associated with sensory symptoms and other systemic manifestations of Sjogren's, such as dry eyes and mouth.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: This is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the joints and does not typically cause the described pattern of distal muscle atrophy and weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary neuropathy characterized by distal muscle weakness and atrophy, reduced reflexes, and a characteristic "inverted champagne bottle" appearance of the legs. It often has a familial occurrence and can present with minimal sensory symptoms.

questions.text: A child is infected with a negative sense RNA virus which also contains neuraminidase receptors. What is the causative organism? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza virus

 

Influenza virus is a segmented, negative-sense/negative-strand RNA virus with neuraminidase receptors/peplomers projecting from the envelope. It belongs to the family of orthomyxoviruses. The hemagglutinin and neuraminidase receptors are present as two different spikes on the envelope.

 

Parainfluenza virus, Newcastle disease virus, and Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses with a linear genome. No neuraminidase is seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): RSV is a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus but does not possess neuraminidase receptors. It primarily causes respiratory infections in children and has a different mechanism of cell entry and release.

 

Option C. Parainfluenza virus: Parainfluenza viruses are also negative-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses and belong to the Paramyxoviridae family. They cause respiratory illnesses but do not have neuraminidase receptors. They use hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) glycoproteins, but the function and structure are different from those of influenza neuraminidase.

 

Option D. Newcastle disease virus: This virus primarily affects birds and is also a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family. Similar to parainfluenza, it does not have the distinct neuraminidase receptors found in influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza virus is a negative-sense RNA virus that contains neuraminidase receptors, which play a key role in the release of newly formed viral particles from infected cells.

choices.text: It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks
Can be done on an OP basis
The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml
It creates a negative pressure of 660 mm Hg

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument/procedure? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) syringe.
  • The correct capacity of the MVA syringe is 60 ml, not 30 ml.
  • This device is used for the termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks or for early pregnancy failures.
  • The procedure can be performed on an outpatient basis (OP basis) and is often used in low-resource settings.
  • The MVA syringe creates a negative pressure of 660 mm Hg to aspirate the products of conception.
  • This procedure is similar to other surgical methods but the complications may be less severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks: The MVA syringe is indeed used for the termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks, making this statement true.

 

Option B. Can be done on an OP basis: The procedure can be performed on an outpatient basis, which is true.

 

Option D. It creates a negative pressure of 660 mm Hg: The MVA syringe creates a negative pressure of 660 mm Hg, which is true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) syringe used for termination of pregnancy has a capacity of 60 ml, not 30 ml, and creates a negative pressure of 6

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 646

choices.text: De quervain thyroiditis

questions.text: A middle-aged lady presents with weight gain, constipation, hoarseness of voice and lethargy. On examination, she is found to be having anti TPO antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis in her? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This is also called Hashimoto’s disease, Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, a disorder in which the immune system turns against the body’s own tissues.in people with Hashimoto’s, the immune system attacks the thyroid. This can lead to hypothyroidism, a condition in which the thyroid doesn’t make enough hormones for the body’s needs.

 

Located in front of neck, the thyroid gland makes hormones that control metabolism. This includes your heart rate and how quickly your body uses calories from the foods we eat.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riedel’s thyroiditis: A rare form of chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland that leads to extensive fibrosis, presenting as a hard, fixed thyroid mass.

 

Option B. Graves’ disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, exophthalmos, and anti-TSH receptor antibodies, not anti TPO antibodies.

 

Option D. De Quervain thyroiditis: A subacute thyroiditis that typically follows a viral infection and presents with a painful, tender thyroid gland and elevated ESR, not anti TPO antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of anti TPO antibodies, leading to hypothyroidism with symptoms such as weight gain, constipation, hoarseness of voice, and lethargy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitiligo 

 

The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

 

Vitiligo

 

  • It is a common form of localized depigmentation. Vitiligo is distinguished by its clearly defined depigmented macules.
  • It is an autoimmune condition brought on by the body's destruction of the dopa-positive melanocytes that make up the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Vitiligo can appear at any age, but it typically first manifests itself in the third decade of life.
  • Most likely, there is no difference in prevalence between the sexes or only a slight female preponderance.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place. It is categorized as:

 

  • Segmental vitiligo - which appears as unilateral depigmented macules in a segmented or band-shaped pattern.
  • Non-segmental vitiligo - which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

  • Melasma is a common skin problem that causes brown to gray-brown patches, primarily on the face.
  • Most people get it on their cheeks, bridge of their nose, forehead, chin, and above their upper lip.
  • It can also appear on other parts of the body that get lots of sun exposure, such as the forearms and neck.
  • It's due to hyperpigmentation as depicted in the image below. rather than depigmentation

 

 

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes the rapid buildup of skin cells.
  • This buildup of cells causes scaling on the skin's surface.
  • Psoriasis does not typically result in depigmented lesions. Instead, the scales might be silvery white, and the underlying skin might be red.

 

Option D. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is a skin manifestation of celiac disease. It is characterized by intensely itchy, chronic papulovesicular eruptions, usually distributed symmetrically on extensor surfaces (like elbows) as depicted in the image below.

 

 

  • These lesions are not typically depigmented. Instead, they might form blisters filled with a clear fluid.
  • The rash is associated with gluten sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose Vitiligo based on the presence of well-demarcated depigmented patches, differentiating it from other skin conditions like Melasma, Psoriasis, and Dermatitis herpetiformis which present with hyperpigmentation, scaly plaques, and vesicles, respectively.

 

Additional Information

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have iso(same), morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

The image below shows vitiligo that exhibits the Koebner phenomenon:

 

 

 

Strongest association of vitiligo is with Autoimmune thyroid disorders (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism).

 

Other disorders associated with vitiligo are:

 

    •    ﻿Pernicious anemia

    •    ﻿Addison's disease

    •    ﻿Diabetes type I

    •    ﻿Myasthenia gravis

    •    ﻿Alopecia areata

    •    ﻿Uveitis

    •    ﻿Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

    •    ﻿Autoimmune polyendocrine syndromes (types I and II)

 

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

 

    •    ﻿Positive family history

    •    ﻿Mucosal vitiligo

    •    ﻿Lesions over bony prominences

    •    ﻿Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon

    •    ﻿Non-segmental vitiligo

 

Treatment options for vitiligo:

 

1. ﻿Topical agents:

  • Topical corticosteroids
  • Calcineurin inhibitors – tacrolimus
  • ﻿Vitamin D Analogs – calcitriol

 

2. Systemic agents:

  • Corticosteroids
  • ﻿Azathioprine

 

3. Phototherapy:

  • ﻿PUVA
  • PUVASol – sunlight
  • NBUVB - narrow band UV B radiation at 311nm
  • Targeted phototherapy using excimer laser 308nm

 

4. Surgical treatment:

  • Ultrathin partial thickness skin grafting
  • Non-cultured autologous melanocytic transfer
  • Cultured autologous melanocytic transfer

 

Indications for Surgical treatment in vitiligo:

 

  • Patients with stable vitiligo (a period of disease inactivity ranging from six months to two years)
  • Vitiligo patients who failed to respond to non-surgical treatment.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 21.1-21.4, 70.4 and 70.5, 88.34

questions.text: Cherry red color post mortem staining of body is attributed to what poisoning? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CO


In CO poisoning the color of Post Mortem staining (PMS) is cherry red due to COHb which has cherry red color. The below image shows cherry red PMS in CO poisoning:

 

 

Option B. H₂S (Hydrogen Sulphide):

 

  • PMS Color: Bluish green.
  • Mechanism: Hydrogen sulphide poisoning leads to the formation of sulfhemoglobin, which gives the blood and tissues a greenish-blue hue.

 

Option C. Nitrate:

 

  • PMS Color: Red brown or chocolate brown.
  • Mechanism: Nitrate poisoning results in the formation of methemoglobin, which imparts a brownish color to the blood and tissues.

 

Option D. Hydrogen cyanide (HCN):

 

  • PMS Color: Bright red.
  • Mechanism: Cyanide poisoning prevents cells from using oxygen, leading to a high concentration of oxygen in venous blood, which appears bright red.

 

Educational objective

 

 

The terminology Cherry red, Bright red, and Bright Pink are used sometimes interchangeable in some books. Choose the best choice accordingly

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient presented in the emergency services after head trauma. On examination, he was able to open his eyes on painful stimuli, withdraws hand to pain and is shouting inappropriate words. What is the Glasgow coma score of this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2M4V3

 

The patient opens his eyes on painful stimuli, so his eye score is E2. The patient withdraws hand to pain, which corresponds to a score of M4. The patient is shouting inappropriate words, so his verbal score is V3.

 

Adding the scores together: E2 + M4 + V3 = GCS 9 (E2M4V3).

 

Thus, the correct answer is C. E2M4V3.

 

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) - 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of E2M4V3 represents a moderate level of impairment and is important for assessing and monitoring patients with head trauma.

questions.text: A patient presents with flaccid bullous lesions as shown in the image below involving the entire trunk and oral cavity. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzanck smear. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by flaccid bullae and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes. The presence of oral cavity involvement and flaccid bullae that easily rupture to form erosions is highly indicative of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

  • Acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear: These are detached keratinocytes found in blister fluid, a hallmark of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Mucosal involvement: Pemphigus vulgaris typically involves mucous membranes, unlike the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus foliaceus: This form of pemphigus involves superficial blisters but does not typically affect mucous membranes.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with celiac disease and presents with grouped vesicles and intense itching, typically on extensor surfaces. It does not present with flaccid bullae or mucosal involvement.

 

Option D. Bullous pemphigoid: This autoimmune blistering disorder typically presents with tense bullae and does not usually involve mucous membranes. It also affects older adults and is less likely to show acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid bullae and erosions involving the skin and mucous membranes. The presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear confirms the diagnosis. Recognizing these key features is crucial for differentiating it from other blistering disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is major surfactant producing cell in lungs?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Type 2 pneumocyte

 

Explanation

 

Type 2 pneumocytes secrete surfactant in the lungs. These alveolar cells are responsible for producing and secreting pulmonary surfactant, a mixture of lipids and proteins that lines the inner surface of the alveoli. Surfactant reduces the surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli, preventing alveolar collapse during expiration. Without sufficient surfactant, conditions such as respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants and other lung diseases in adults can occur.

 

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Type 1 pneumocyte: Incorrect. Type 1 pneumocytes are alveolar cells that line the alveolar surface and are primarily involved in gas exchange.


Option B. Alveolar macrophage: Incorrect. Alveolar macrophages are involved in local immunity within the lungs, not in surfactant production.


Option C. Basal cell: Incorrect. Basal cells act as stem cells, helping in cell differentiation, but they do not produce surfactant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 pneumocytes are the major surfactant-producing cells in the lungs, essential for reducing surface tension in the alveoli and preventing their collapse during expiration.

questions.text: An elderly male developed the symptoms of dementia and was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Levels of which of the following neurotransmitters are reduced in this disease? (Fmge June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acetylcholine

 

In Alzheimer's disease, there is a notable reduction in the levels of Acetylcholine, a key neurotransmitter involved in memory and learning. The decline is particularly prominent in the Nucleus Basalis of Meynert, an area in the brain that is crucial for cognitive function and alertness. This reduction is linked to the characteristic memory deficits and cognitive decline observed in Alzheimer's patients. Acetylcholine's role in the disease is so central that many treatments for Alzheimer's aim to increase acetylcholine levels or mimic its action to alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: While dopamine levels are indeed reduced in Parkinson’s disease, leading to motor symptoms characteristic of that disorder, changes in dopamine are not primarily associated with Alzheimer's disease. However, some overlapping symptoms like rigidity and bradykinesia can occur in later stages.

 

Option C. Adrenaline and D. Serotonin: Both adrenaline (epinephrine) and serotonin levels are known to be altered in depression. While changes in serotonin levels have been noted in Alzheimer's disease, these are not as pronounced or as directly linked to the core symptoms of the disease as the changes in acetylcholine levels. Serotonin impacts mood, appetite, and sleep, and its dysregulation may contribute to the behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary neurotransmitter deficit in Alzheimer's disease is acetylcholine, which is crucial for memory formation and cognitive function. Understanding this helps in comprehending the rationale behind the use of cholinesterase inhibitors, a common class of drugs used in Alzheimer's treatment, which work by blocking the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby enhancing cholinergic transmission in the brain.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, vomiting and distension. An erect Abdominal X-ray as given in the image below. Identify the bowel which is obstructed?( FMGE 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

  • The given clinical scenario and X-ray suggest multiple air fluid levels with complete mucosal folds suggestive of step ladder pattern of small bowel obstruction due to jejunum obstruction.
  • The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes/ valves of Kerkring which are complete mucosal folds that cross the entire lumen of the bowel.
  • The gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes give a string of beads appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Rule: 3-6-9

 

  • 3 cm dilated bowel loops: Small bowel obstruction
  • 6 cm dilated bowel loops: Large bowel obstruction
  • 9 cm: Cecal obstruction

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia

 

Chronic vomiting, especially due to conditions such as pyloric stenosis or gastric outlet obstruction, leads to the loss of stomach contents, which are rich in hydrochloric acid (HCl), potassium, and sodium. This results in a specific set of metabolic abnormalities:

 

  • Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium in the vomitus.
  • Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride ions, which are a major component of HCl.
  • Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of HCl leads to a reduction in the acidity of the body, causing metabolic alkalosis.
  • Hyponatremia: Vomiting leads to loss of sodium as well.

 

Additionally, chronic vomiting can result in paradoxical aciduria, where the urine becomes acidic despite the systemic metabolic alkalosis. This occurs as the kidneys attempt to conserve sodium and excrete hydrogen ions in exchange for potassium, which is lost due to vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia: Hypernatremia is not expected since vomiting leads to sodium loss.

 

Option C. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia: Hypercalcemia is not associated with chronic vomiting.

 

Option D. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia: The metabolic disturbance in vomiting is alkalosis, not acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vomiting leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia. The treatment involves replacing the lost electrolytes, particularly chloride, which is often achieved with normal saline.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a child is presented with symptoms of fever, severe pain, and swelling of the left eye. The child had sustained a dog bite over the eye a few days ago. Upon examination, mild proptosis (forward displacement of the eye) is observed along with restricted ocular movements. Based on these findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?(FMGE June 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orbital cellulitis

 

  • In the given case, the combination of symptoms including fever, severe pain, swelling of the left eye, mild proptosis (forward displacement of the eye), and restricted ocular movements following a dog bite suggests the most likely diagnosis of orbital cellulitis.
  • Orbital cellulitis most commonly occurs when a bacterial infection spreads from the paranasal sinuses into the orbit. In children under the age of 10 years, paranasal sinusitis most often involves the ethmoid sinus which spreads through the thin lamina papyracea of the medial orbital wall into the orbit.

 

Pathophysiology

  • Orbital cellulitis most commonly occurs in the setting of an upper respiratory or sinus infection. The human upper respiratory tract is normally colonized with Strep pneumoniae and infection can occur through several mechanisms. Strep pyogenes infections also occur primarily in the respiratory tract. The complex cell surface of this gram-positive organism determines its virulence and ability to invade the surrounding tissue and incite inflammation. Staph aureus infections occur commonly in the skin and spread to the orbit from the skin. Staphylococcal organisms also produce toxins which help to promote their virulence and leads to the inflammatory response seen in these infections. The inflammatory response elicited by all these pathogens plays a major role in tissue destruction in the orbit.

 

Clinical features of orbital cellulitis include:

  • Eyelid swelling, pain (Patients typically experience severe pain in the affected eye, which may worsen with eye movements or palpation), Proptosis, Restricted ocular movements, Redness and warmth, Vision changes, Fever and systemic symptoms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Description: Inflammation of the internal structures of the eye, typically following surgery or trauma.
  • Symptoms: Severe eye pain, vision loss, and pus in the anterior chamber (hypopyon). Not typically associated with proptosis or restricted eye movements.

 

Option C. Panophthalmitis:

 

  • Description: Inflammation of all layers of the eye, including the intraocular structures and the orbit.
  • Symptoms: Severe pain, vision loss, and a swollen, red eye. More severe and involves the entire eye and surrounding tissues.

 

Option D. Preseptal cellulitis:

 

  • Description: Infection of the eyelid and surrounding skin anterior to the orbital septum.
  • Symptoms: Swelling and redness of the eyelids without proptosis or restricted ocular movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis presents with fever, severe pain, eyelid swelling, proptosis, and restricted ocular movements. It commonly follows an infection or trauma and requires prompt medical intervention to prevent complications such as vision loss or intracranial spread.

questions.text: In the sundarbans region of West Bengal, a proactive strategy is employed to address the rising cases of malaria. A health worker visits each household every two weeks, asking residents about recent fevers and preparing slides for malaria testing if needed. This method ensures prompt detection and intervention. What type of epidemiological surveillance does this represent? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Active

 

This scenario exemplifies "active surveillance" in epidemiology. Unlike passive surveillance where data on disease incidence is collected from established reports or data streams (often from hospitals and clinics), active surveillance involves direct and regular outreach by health workers to identify potential cases. In this case, the health worker actively seeks out information and tests for malaria within the community, ensuring early detection and response to the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Passive: Incorrect because passive surveillance relies on routine reports from healthcare providers, without additional active seeking of cases by health officials.

 

Option C. Sentinel: Incorrect as sentinel surveillance involves monitoring disease trends in a specific, designated sample of the population, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malarial surveillance was done by MPW (Male) at Subcenter level (once every fortnight)

 

  • Passive: Hospital reporting Most convenient way of sample
  • Active surveillance - as the health worker is going in search for cases of fever house to house.

choices.text: Distended gall bladder

questions.text: A 35-year-old male died due to starvation. What is the most expected finding in the body of this patient during autopsy? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distended gall bladder

 

Post mortem appearance in death due to starvation

 

A distended gall bladder filled with bile is a common finding during the autopsy of an individual who has died from starvation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enlarged heart: Starvation typically leads to atrophy of organs rather than enlargement. The heart would likely be reduced in size due to muscle wasting.

 

Option B. Enlarged stomach: The stomach is more likely to be shrunken or empty in cases of prolonged starvation.

 

Option D. Expanded lungs: The lungs are not typically expanded in starvation; they usually appear normal unless affected by other concurrent conditions.

 

Postmortem appearances

 

Internal examination

 

  • Bowel contain offensive watery fluid and gas
  • Liver is atrophied show necrosis due to protein deficiency
  • Spleen is shrunken
  • Gall bladder is distended with bile
  • Kidney shows atrophy of nephrons
  • Blood volume is markedly reduced

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase

questions.text: A child with hypoglycemia was found to have burnt sugar urine odor. Which enzyme is deficient in this child? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Burnt sugar urine odor is seen in case of Maple Syrup Urine Disease. It is due to the deficiency of Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogentisic acid oxidase: Deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase causes alkaptonuria, which leads to darkening of urine upon standing, but not a burnt sugar odor.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase causes phenylketonuria (PKU), characterized by a musty or mousy body odor, not a burnt sugar odor.

 

Option D. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of glucose 6 phosphatase causes glycogen storage disease type I (Von Gierke disease), which presents with severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly, but not with a burnt sugar urine odor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is identified by a burnt sugar odor in the urine and is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase. Early recognition and management are crucial to prevent neurological damage.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ebstein anomaly

 

Lithium should be stopped during pregnancy, as the prenatal consumption of lithium in pregnancy may lead to Ebstein abnormality.

 

Ebstein’s anomaly

 

 

The tricuspid valve is malformed such that it leaks, and is set further into the right ventricle than normal.

 

Clinical features

 

  • Cyanosed at birth
  • Loud murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • Can be very sick
  • May be associated with maternal lithium ingestion

 

ECG

 

  • Prolonged PR interval.
  • May have a superior axis

 

Chest X-ray

 

  • Massive cardiomegaly (wall-to-wall heart)
  • Reduced pulmonary vascular markings

 

Management

 

  • Resuscitate
  • Pulmonary vasodilator therapy (ventilation, oxygen)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VACTERAL defects: VACTERAL is an acronym representing a group of birth defects that affect various parts of the body (vertebral defects, anal atresia, cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal anomalies, and limb abnormalities). These are not typically associated with lithium use during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Coarctation of aorta: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta, often associated with Turner syndrome. It is not commonly linked to maternal lithium use.

 

Option D. Supravalvular aortic stenosis: Supravalvular aortic stenosis is a narrowing of the ascending aorta above the aortic valve and is associated with Williams syndrome. This condition is not related to lithium exposure during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prenatal exposure to lithium can lead to Ebstein's anomaly, characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, resulting in significant cardiac defects and requiring prompt medical management at birth.

 

Ref - OP Ghai 9th Edition. Page No- 420-423.

questions.text: In an infant, which of the following milestones is achieved the earliest? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulnar palmar grasp

 

Ulnar palmar grasp, develops by 6 months of age, is the milestone that is attained the earliest than the other mile stones mentioned in the question.

 

  • Ulnar palmar grasp – 6 months
  • Radial palmar grasp – 8 months
  • Immature pincer grasp – 9 months
  • Mature pincer grasp – 12 months

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature pincer grasp: The immature pincer grasp usually develops around 9 months of age. It involves using the thumb and the index finger to hold objects but not yet with the refined precision seen in a mature pincer grasp.

 

Option B. Mature pincer grasp: The mature pincer grasp, typically seen around 12 months of age, allows the infant to pick up small objects using the tips of the thumb and index finger with precision.

 

Option C. Radial palmar grasp: The radial palmar grasp develops around 8 months of age and involves the infant using the thumb and all fingers to hold objects against the palm, signifying a more advanced level of motor control compared to the ulnar palmar grasp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar palmar grasp is one of the earliest fine motor skills developed by infants, usually around 6 months of age, highlighting the progression of motor skills from gross to more refined movements.

choices.text: Strangulated paraumbilical hernia

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with vomiting and severe pain in epigastrium which is radiating to back. On examination a bluish discoloration is seen on the abdomen as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute pancreatitis

 

The given image shows Cullen’s sign, a bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which is indicative of acute pancreatitis. Cullen’s sign occurs due to retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which is a severe complication of acute pancreatitis.

 

Key features of acute pancreatitis include:

 

  • Symptoms: Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and possibly fever.
  • Pathophysiology: Release of pancreatic enzymes leads to autodigestion of the pancreas and surrounding tissues, which can cause hemorrhage.
  • Cullen’s sign: Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemorrhage.
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Bruising on the flanks, also indicative of retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute cholecystitis:

 

  • Symptoms include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever.
  • It is associated with inflammation of the gallbladder, usually due to gallstones.
  • Cullen’s sign is not associated with acute cholecystitis.

 

Option C. Acute hepatitis:

 

  • Symptoms include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice.
  • It involves inflammation of the liver.
  • Cullen’s sign is not a characteristic finding in acute hepatitis.

 

Option D. Strangulated paraumbilical hernia:

 

  • Symptoms can include localized pain, vomiting, and a visible or palpable hernia.
  • Strangulation leads to compromised blood supply to the herniated bowel, causing ischemia and pain.
  • The image suggests bruising (Cullen’s sign), not indicative of a strangulated hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cullen’s sign is a key indicator of retroperitoneal hemorrhage often associated with acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 59 years old chronic alcoholic presents to casualty history of sharp central abdominal pain and vomiting since 12 hours, which is aggravated by lying down. Pulse is 132/min, BP 118/82 mmHg, temperature is 38.3 degree Celsius. On examination he has mild jaundice. There is periumbilical and flank discoloration as shown in the image and minimum tenderness in epigastrium. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute pancreatitis

Key points: bluish discoloration of the flanks =grey turner sign& discoloration around

Umbilicus = Cullen sign

Both these signs are seen in acute pancreatitis

questions.text: What is the GCS of a patient with a head injury who opens her eyes in response to a loud voice, localizes pain, and is confused and disoriented? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E3M5V4

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess a patient's level of consciousness after a head injury. It consists of three components: eye-opening response (E), motor response (M), and verbal response (V). Each component is scored separately, and the total score is the sum of these components.

 

 

Given the patient's responses:

 

  • E3: Eyes open in response to a loud voice.
  • M5: Localizes pain.
  • V4: Confused and disoriented speech.

 

Thus, the GCS score for this patient is E3M5V4.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E3M6V5: This would indicate the patient obeys commands and has normal, oriented speech, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. E4M4V5: This would indicate spontaneous eye-opening, withdrawal from pain, and normal, oriented speech, which does not match the patient's presentation.

 

Option D. E3M5V5: This would indicate normal, oriented speech, which does not match the patient's confused and disoriented speech.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GCS is a useful tool for assessing the level of consciousness in head injury patients. Understanding and correctly applying the scoring criteria is crucial for accurate assessment.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation
Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.27, pCO2 = 28, HCO3 = 13. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation

 

 

Thus, the patient has metabolic acidosis (indicated by low HCO3) with respiratory compensation (indicated by low pCO2).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation: This would present with a high pCO2 and a high HCO3. Here, pCO2 is low, which is inconsistent with respiratory acidosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation: This would present with a high pH. Here, the pH is low, indicating acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation: This would present with a high pH and high HCO3. Here, HCO3 is low, indicating metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABG results indicate metabolic acidosis (low pH and HCO3) with respiratory compensation (low pCO2).

choices.text: Swan neck deformity
Z line deformity

questions.text: Identify the deformity depicted in the image: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Boutonnière deformity

 

The image shows a finger with hyperextension at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and hyperflexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. This characteristic appearance is known as a Boutonnière deformity.

 

Boutonnière deformity: This deformity occurs due to injury or chronic inflammation affecting the central slip of the extensor tendon, leading to PIP joint flexion and DIP joint extension. It is often seen in rheumatoid arthritis and traumatic injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swan neck deformity: This involves hyperextension of the PIP joint and hyperflexion of the DIP joint, the opposite of Boutonnière deformity.

 

Option C. Z line deformity: Occur in the thumb, here the deformity is hyper extension at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and hyper flexion at the MCP joint of the thumb.

 

Option D. Trigger finger: This condition involves a locking or catching sensation in the finger due to inflammation or narrowing of the sheath around the tendon. The finger may be flexed and require manipulation to extend, but it does not present with the described joint position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boutonnière deformity is characterized by flexion at the PIP joint and extension at the DIP joint, commonly seen in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and traumatic injuries to the extensor tendons.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placental abruption

 

Explanation:

 

  • Placental abruption: In obstetrics, placental abruption is the most frequent factor in severe consumptive coagulopathy. It occurs due to the release of thromboplastin, which triggers the coagulation cascade, leading to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). DIC is a pathological disturbance of hemostasis that results in widespread clotting and subsequent bleeding due to the consumption of clotting factors.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intrauterine death (IUFD): Intrauterine death can lead to consumptive coagulopathy, particularly if the fetal demise goes unrecognized for an extended period, resulting in the release of thromboplastic substances from the retained fetal tissues. However, it is not the most common cause compared to placental abruption.

 

Option B. Amniotic fluid embolism: Amniotic fluid embolism can cause DIC due to the entry of amniotic fluid into the maternal circulation, which contains thromboplastic material. While it is a severe and often fatal condition, it is less common than placental abruption as a cause of DIC.

 

Option C. Sepsis: Sepsis can lead to DIC due to the systemic inflammatory response and the release of pro-coagulant factors. However, in the context of obstetrics, sepsis is not as common a cause of DIC as placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placental abruption is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy (DIC) in obstetrics due to the release of thromboplastin from the abrupted placenta.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page712

questions.text: A child admitted with iron overload. Which of the following is iron chelator used in the treatment? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desferrioxamine

 

This is the correct answer. Desferrioxamine is a specific chelator for iron and is used in the treatment of iron overload, such as in conditions like hemochromatosis or in patients who have received multiple blood transfusions. It works by binding to excess iron in the body, which is then excreted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): This is a chelating agent used primarily for the treatment of heavy metal poisoning, particularly lead poisoning. It is not effective as an iron chelator and is not used for the treatment of iron overload.

 

Option C. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): This chelating agent is used primarily for arsenic, mercury, or lead poisoning. It is not used for iron chelation.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: This is primarily used as a chelator for copper in the treatment of Wilson's disease and also has some use in rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective for iron chelation and is not used in the treatment of iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed pg. 364

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?(FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 18F-FDG

 

18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

 

  • PET scan: Positron emission tomography.
  • IOC for metastatic staging.
  • 18 FDG: 18 F is combined with deoxy glucose (ligand)
  • Functional metabolism is tested

 

Warburg Effect: Malignant cells → Anaerobic glycolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Gallium: Used in some types of scans but not commonly for PET; Gallium scans are different and used for specific cases like infection or inflammation.

 

Option. C. Iodine 131: Mainly used in the treatment and diagnosis of thyroid disease, not for PET scans.

 

Option. D. Tc 99: Used in nuclear medicine in the form of technetium-99m for a variety of imaging studies, predominantly in SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) rather than PET.

 

Educational Objective:

 

18F-FDG is the radiotracer of choice in PET-CT scanning to evaluate metabolic activity and is key in oncology for identifying and monitoring malignant cells due to their increased glucose uptake relative to normal cells.

questions.text: Dr. Rajan reviews the dental examination of a 50-year-old man from Andhra Pradesh, who exhibits distinct dental lesions. He uses this case to help students make a diagnosis by connecting the patient's regional background to the dental findings. What condition is most likely responsible for the observed dental lesions? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fluorosis

 

The image given shows mottled and pitted enamel and is suggestive of Dental fluorosis.

 

Dental fluorosis occurs when excess fluoride is ingested during first 7 years of life (years of tooth calcification)

 

  • It occurs at levels above 1.5 mg/litre intake
  • It is characterized by 'Mottling', which is best seen on incisors of upper jaw.

 

Fluorine is a double edged sword: Inadequate intake is associated with ‘dental caries’ whereas excess intake with ‘dental and skeletal fluorosis’

 

Optimum level of fluorine in drinking water: 0.5 - 0.8 ppm (0.5 - 0.8 mg/litre)

 

  • Level > 1.5 ppm: Dental fluorosis (mottling)
  • Level 3.0 - 6.0 ppm: Skeletal fluorosis
  • Level > 10.0 ppm: Crippling fluorosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plumbism: Incorrect, as plumbism or lead poisoning does not typically result in mottled teeth.

 

Option C. Lathyrism: Incorrect, lathyrism is caused by consuming certain legumes and does not affect teeth.

 

Option D. Selenosis: Incorrect, selenosis results from excessive selenium and does not manifest as dental mottling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dental Fluorosis is characterized by changes in dental enamel that occur due to excessive fluoride intake during tooth development. Recognizing the signs of fluorosis is important for diagnosing and preventing further fluoride exposure, especially in regions known for high fluoride levels in drinking water.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man, recently arrived from an international trip, presents with a mild fever at a medical screening facility. Given the need for accurate and timely identification of viral infections, especially in travelers from regions with known disease outbreaks, which diagnostic test is most appropriate for detecting viral RNA? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Real time RT- PCR

 

RT-PCR uses RNA as starting material for in vitro nucleic acid amplification.  Reverse transcriptase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, catalyzing DNA synthesis using RNA as the template. The end product is known as complementary DNA (cDNA). cDNA is not subject to RNase degradation, making it more stable than RNA.

 

In RT-PCR, the starting RNA is subsequently degraded, dsDNA is produced, and PCR amplification proceeds in the usual manner. RT-PCR is commonly used in the diagnosis and quantification of RNA virus infections e.g., HIV, hepatitis C virus, COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): Mainly used for the rapid diagnosis of Tuberculosis (TB) and detection of drug resistance.

 

Option B. Dimer: Refers to the D-dimer test, which is a fibrin degradation product and is often elevated in conditions like deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

 

Option D. CRP (C-Reactive Protein): It's an acute-phase protein and is elevated in inflammation, infection, and other conditions. It does not specifically diagnose viral infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In scenarios requiring the identification of viral infections in symptomatic individuals, especially in the context of potential exposure during international travel, Real-Time RT-PCR remains the gold standard due to its accuracy and rapid processing time.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a high fever and a cough productive of rust-colored sputum presents to the clinic. A chest X-ray shows a lobar consolidation, and a sputum sample is taken for Gram staining and culture. The laboratory technician performs a Quellung reaction on the sputum sample, which comes back positive. Which organism is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Option A:

 

The Quellung reaction is a serological test used to detect the presence of capsular polysaccharide antigens of certain bacteria, particularly Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia with lobar consolidation and rust-colored sputum.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Neisseria gonorrhoeae does not commonly cause pneumonia and is not detected by the Quellung reaction.

 

Option C: Streptococcus pyogenes can cause pharyngitis and other diseases but is not associated with the Quellung reaction, which is specific for encapsulated organisms like S. pneumoniae.

 

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, typically after influenza, but is not detected using the Quellung reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quellung reaction is used to detect the presence of the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is an important pathogen in community-acquired pneumonia with characteristic rust-colored sputum.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p241

questions.text: Which virus is responsible for causing Orchitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mumps virus

Orchitis is inflammation of the testis. It is most commonly caused by Mumps virus

Treatment: Analgesics and anti-inflammatory agents

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with road traffic accident. The patient has raised ICP without intracranial hematoma. Which of the following is the preferred drug for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mannitol

Raised ICP without intra cranial bleed can be managed with osmotic diuretic Mannitol.

Important indications of mannitol are:

  • Acute congestive glaucoma (DOC)
  • Cerebral edema (DOC)
  • Incipient renal failure

Contra-indications of Mannitol are:

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute renal failure
  • Cerebral hemorrhage

questions.text: A patient was given halothane for general anesthesia. He developed rigidity, and hyperthermia. These symptoms are most likely due to which ion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ca2+

A patient developing rigidity and hyperthermia after inhalation of halothane indicates Malignant Hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia occurs due to the overactivity of the ryanodine receptors present on the sarcoplasmic reticulum and it helps in release of the Ca2+ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

DOC for malignant hyperthermia: Dantrolene Na.

Maximum risk of malignant hyperthermia is with Succinylcholine.

Local anesthetic agent associated with malignant hyperthermia: Lidocaine.

questions.text: A patient of COVID- 19 requires oxygen therapy. Which of the following cylinder should be used to provide oxygen to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.

• Fig. A is Entonox Cylinder with blue body and white shoulder.

• Fig. B is Helium Cylinder which is brown in colored.

• Fig. C is Oxygen Cylinder with black body and white shoulder.

• Fig. D is N,O Cylinder which is blue colored.

Hence, option C is the correct answer.

The oxygen cylinder has a pin index 2,5

Entonox is a mixture of 50% nitrous oxide along with 50% oxygen. It has a pin index of 7
